main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Good Work Life Balance and excellent compensation
cons: Huge company, non-human HR department
advice_management: Keep up the good work!

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than a year
pros:
* Widespread acceptance of remote workers, provides home office setup.
* Lots of very smart and knowledgeable people.
cons:
* Big company. Sometimes the left hand doesn't know what the right hand is doing. 
* Lots of (long) meetings.
advice_management:
* Software developers generally hate open plan offices. Don't do it!
* Help managers and workers to cut down on meetings. It's excessive!

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: The variety of work, and projects to be involved in is staggering, there are endless opportunities.  Yes you'll have to work hard, but you get to do that as yourself which is so much easier than trying to mute yourself.  It's about the customers and getting the work done, not looking, sounding and working like a machine
cons: Repeat after me - change is good!  The company and therefore the work is constantly evolving and innovating, so if you like routine and repetition you're going to be uncomfortable.  Also be prepared for diversity of people but also locations, you're not likely to be part of a team all in one place.  That's going to be tough when you start, but once you've been here for a bit, it's great!

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 5 years
pros: The name Cisco...  The campus is nice.
cons: Just a bunch of pre madonnas. They acquired companies too quickly and lost the culture that made them great.
advice_management: Go back to investing in great candidates instead of investing in great LOOKING resumes.  You have no skill in finding great people you are surrounded by mediocrity and happy to wallow in it. Process is everything the outcome is nothing. It took you 12 years to quire open DNS and Sourcefire... Duh!! And you try to claim security leadership... Just another follower. Lame...

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Intelligent, hard working people.  Flexible work environment . Great work site/facilities and technology.
cons: In the HR organization there is limited opportunity and focus on career growth.  Compensation strategy is lacking - no regular merit increases,   strong performance is not rewarded in significant ways.     Limited to no stock options in most positions.   Fear of constant lay offs impacts morale... its discouraging to watch long time hard working employees who have given 10+ years to the company be laid off by new managers.  More work needs to be done on the "moments that matter" -  acknowledgement is inconsistent across teams and not creating a positive experience for everyone.
advice_management: Expect more from your leaders at all levels of the organization.  Focus on building leaders not working managers.  Bring back the Pulse survey and listen to employee feedback from all levels of the organization.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Great Vacation - 4 Weeks
cons: Not enough job opportunities in the Richardson location

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Cisco policies address the issues that face LGBT+ employees head-on.  I've only recently come out and it was difficult, but there does not seem to be any backlash to my face.
cons: The issue comes when the local employees disagree with the corporate inclusion policies.  When the people around you get their news from Fox and Friends.......it's still an uphill battle for equality.
advice_management: Leave your religious views at the door.  Treat people fairly regardless of your beliefs.  We all have a job to do, let's get on with doing our best!

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Real budget to make a difference in your field. No micky-mousing around here, everything is a billion dollar bet. Try to find a team that isn't getting re-organized and can actually see project all the way to success.
cons: Too many 20-year veterans playing politics in their BU.  Looming cloud of entire 50 person blue badge team disappearing overnight (twice in last 3 years for me), because you only have a few weeks to find that new project. Change does drive innovation & opportunity though.
advice_management: The Cisco Beat monthly telepresence event is excellent.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 5 years
pros: benefits growth compensation projects and culture
cons: not latest technology, not enough work
advice_management: try to get updated from the market and get some new and latest projects to lead the market.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than a year
pros: Lots of opportunities and market presence.
cons: Big, cumbersome... tough to get things done.
advice_management: Let acquired companies continue doing what they do best

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Competitive benefits, amazing work-from-anywhere culture (in marketing), family services to help manage the challenges of bay area living and traffic
cons: big company - comes with big company issues; lots of matrixing, lots of re-orgs, silos and overlaps in priorities, gaps in other places.
advice_management: Give every employee a clear vision to follow - not goals for what needs to happen this year, but a vision that inspires the masses for the next decade.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than a year
pros:
1. Great work-life balance
2. Manageable work-pressure, not too much not too less
cons:
1. Benefits are not great
2. Career-progression up is slow

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
total compensation package and benefits
hands-on experience with products while delivering services
face-to-face customer interactions and relationships
relationships with managers, directors, and higher levels of leadership hierarchy
innovation actively pursued and appreciated
departmental alignment and support, inter-team relationships
cons:
inconsistent contracts compared to customer expectations
high expectations of service delivery with significant churn of tools and techniques
information glut
difficulty tracking higher level leaders compared to day-to-day operations
increasing inequality between leadership levels and individual contributors

summary: "Creative, smart, nice people with a shared mission"
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than a year
pros: Virtually everyone I work with in the company is cheerful and helpful, which is rare and amazing. The pay and benefits are quite good, and the work is fascinating.
cons: The company is huge and spread around the world, making it hard to feel fully connected.  The wide array of product offers makes it challenging to get a full understanding of the product line
advice_management: Ensure that employees feel there are opportunities for growth and advancement

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Having Cisco on a resume isnt a bad thing, because people that see your resume that also worked there know you are survivor of ITs Auschwitz.
cons: Worked at Cisco as Blue bad/Red badge. Very much 4 legs good/2 legs bad kind of place. If you are a contractor, youre an invisible pariah. Excluded from meetings, etc. As employee, the expectations and stress are enormous, and they use their name to avoid paying you what youre worth. They totally enslave H1Bs but thats another story. Ive been asked 50 times since I left if I wanted to go back and the answer remains the same-Id rather flip burgers than work at Cisco.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Great People, Good Company to work for with highly skilled employees.  Some opportunities to grow but only based on geographic locations.
cons: People choices like all big companies can be lacking in some strategic positions.  Sales support has dwindled down a ton leaving the account teams with little help on complex order issues.
advice_management: Invest in all your customers not just the large enterprise organizations.

summary: "Great Place to work but does have some areas better than others"
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: I've been at Cisco for 18years and it's the only company that I've stayed at for more than 5yrs.  Ability to move around to very different roles, support for continuous development, and support in taking risk.   But all of this, though company wide can be hindered by a few leaders in some groups.   Sr. Leadership is very open in monthly all employee meetings.
cons: It's a big company!  Thus not agile as we once were but the Sr. Leadership is always working on that.
advice_management: Keep up the good work.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems
pros: Flexibility to work from home. Easy to find a project/product you like to work on. Benefits are industry standard. Time off for volunteering work. People around you are talented and versatile.
cons: Due to the large size, there are gaps in communication with management. Frequent layoffs creates insecurity among employees. Management need to show some transparency.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than a year
pros: Great work culture, great compensation page , embrace innovation
cons: No comments   at  this time
advice_management: Be more aggressive in  the IOT/Cloud Computing space

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 8 years
pros: flexibility, work from home, work ethic, good pay
cons: fight for a small scope of work. not enough articulation of strategy to execute. too many concepts and abstracts
advice_management: the growth is slow so people fight over a lot of small things. the career move is difficult even lateral move. there is no systemic rotation process. the basic idea you need to reach out as many as people and hope for a luck.  The inflexible org structure can  diminish the innovation and slow down the transformation.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than a year

cons: Processes can get bureaucratic and complex due to the company's large size.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Some of the best people to work with....very collaborative environment! Great work/life balance. Virtual offices work very well for those that are disciplined. Great technology to collaborate with customers, partners and internal folks.
cons: Mobility is more of a challenge. Tend to get "stuck" in the same position. Number of immediate managers is constantly changing.
advice_management: Do everything you can do to prevent the annual layoffs. You have dedicated employees and ask the same from management.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 8 years
pros:
•	Big and established company
•	Flexible to work from anywhere
cons:
•	Employee morale and culture is negatively affected while the management is trying to make the numbers and company look better, causing to lose many valuable talents
•	Very hierarchical, traditional, and process-oriented structure 
•	 Top down decision-making approach 
•	Overall if flexibility is not a big issue, I would not recommend working there!
advice_management:
•	Empower employees
•	Allow more recognition
•	Increase morale

summary: "Great Perks for a Price You May Nor be Willing to Pay"
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros:
Flexible work options 
Competitive pay
Great Benefits

Long hours 
Lack of work life balance 
Continuous lay-offs for the past 8 years 
Infrequent salary increases

advice_management:
Stop the layoffs.  Encourage a better work life balance. Replace some of the toxic upper management.  Really take a look at the subcultures that will bring the company down. 
Salary increases should be annual 
Clean house of toxic employees at all levels

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Great smart people to work with. Flexibilty in working locations, facilitate work/life balance.  Good people in Mgt who seems to care and wanting to do the right thing for emplyees.
cons: Promo/advancement driven by quotas not actual performance.  Salaries/comps are never discussed.  Performance review not happening.  Lots of  promises about people deals that are not fulfilled.   Bureaucracy dictates most decisions  despite encouraging employees to be self empowered
advice_management: Employee should be  first priority not always come after stockholders.  Real compensation and advancement policy changes needed to reward performance.  15y veteran

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than a year
pros:
I worked at Cisco in RTP for a few years. Over time it become obvious that my project peers were working other full-time jobs and shouldering me with an unfair amount of project burden. I made management aware of this issue but they were too busy to effectively look into the matter. It was a complicated issue; management typically doesn't have time to manage staff at Cisco and actually see whats going on. Many managers have too many employees, some like mine have the title of manager but are really too busy working a sales role. This puts them in the place of trusting mid-level employees.If your under a shady one theres not much you can do.
It got very shady in my exit interview when no HR representative was present. In lieu of that I was given a web form to fill out.

Pros: Great opportunities do exist. as with most large companies Its really a roll of the dice as to who you work for.
cons: As stated the cliques and poor ethics that grow in certain areas.
advice_management: Allow mid level managers to have the time and visibiilty to know what their direct reports are doing and not doing.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Autonomy, working with great people, benefits, freedom of movement, opportunities for advancement, great customers, great culture
cons: Internal tools changing every couple of years being advertised as the best ever every change
advice_management: Continue to focus on diversity.  Do not let up

pros: Because Cisco is the king of collaboration, you can get your job done essentially anywhere. Access to many offices. Decent work/life balance (at times)
cons: I would not recommend Advanced Services. We often have to deal with thousands of Sales People. Management and Senior leadership tends to be quite out of touch from the top down. Very difficult to grow.
advice_management: Take care of your employees. Listen to them. Invest in them.

Great benefits including tuition reimbursement, Time2Give for community service, and competitive health coverage.
cons: Improving the current lay-off culture

summary: "A really good company, yet can improve!!"
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than a year
pros: Global, flexibility of work location, and seems profitable. Very receptive to younger generation employees and tries to make fun, and not just work!
cons: Lack of diversity, especially in leadership or managers.  Lots of employees from Inida who do not understand US culture. Can make meetings and IT support very difficult and getting work done unproductive.  Understanding how things work as a new employee is not very good; confusing.
advice_management: Invest in tools and systems to support employees internally.  Look at offering cultural understanding from country to country.  Make management more diverse.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 5 years

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Transparent leadership, lots of fantastic benefits, great culture considering it's size, easy to move around within the company, great support for work/life balance (working from home, flexible schedules, etc. )
cons: Upward mobility can be difficult given the long tenure of many of the employees
advice_management: Don't focus so much on your new early-in-career hires at the expense of  your core mid-career employees

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
Overall, Cisco is a pretty great place to work!
-Great benefits like stock options, cheap health insurance, volunteering time off and donation matching, remote work options, the list goes on.
-Endless learning and job opportunities. Ability for stretch assignments to try other job roles or locations. Emphasis on self training and certifications to help further your career.
-Work with some of the smartest people in the industry. Great mentorship programs to learn from the best and get career advice.
-Leadership and executives that are receptive to change, new ideas and transparency.
cons:
-Big company. A bit overwhelming at times. Can be hard to find resources or people necessary to perform your job.
-Annual layoffs without an emphasis on retraining current talent.
advice_management: Continue being transparent and receptive to input from employees. The company cultural shift happening right now is a good thing, but the there are still a significant amount of bureaucracy and corporate politics that need to be addressed.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Flexibility, Innovation, and ability to work on lots of different efforts.
cons: Yearly layoffs are a concern for me
advice_management: Mentor your high performers and give them the opportunity to work on projects that will expose them to leadership.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years

advice_management: Identify the difference between productivity and being busy

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than a year
pros: Most employees have the ability to work from home. I personally work from home about 3 days per week. As long as I get my work done, my manager doesn't pressure me. The compensation isn't as high as some of the hotter tech companies in the bay area but you're definitely comfortable (assuming you don't buy a home out here). I constantly have opportunities for learning and self-growth. I also enjoy the ability to switch roles/teams should I want to in the future. At such a large company, moving around/getting promoted is easier because there are usually positions available.
cons: Cisco could push its employees to work harder. The working environment is almost too relaxed at times. Sometimes upper management can be slow to come up with ideas on their own.
advice_management: Free snacks in every building (there are in some) and renovating the buildings to have more open space would help attract millennials. Find a better way to solicit employee feedback to senior management beyond online surveys.

Relaxed pace of work

advice_management: Promote the hard working people instead of hiring new ones or promoting the people who are working for managers that are reporting high in the chain

summary: "Leading the Black Employee Experience at Cisco HQ"
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
Cisco leadership is passionate about the employee experience and invests time/resources in the employee resource organizations.
Ability to shape and drive initiatives that directly impact Cisco's people culture.
Developing my leadership skills.
cons:
Large company with flexible work style makes coordinating within and across employee resource groups challenging.
No digitized employee insights tool to properly track employee experience and high potential areas of impact.
advice_management:
Remove political roadblocks(people/teams/contracts) that impede work on our most critical programs.
Continue investing in the employee experience, and further digitize the HR space so we can more accurately track our potential or lack of for innovation with relation to the demographic of our company, supported by the data.

Good people
Chance to hop teams for diverse challenges

Legacy monolith

Mediocre benefits for such a large company (many startups are better!)
Culture and diversity are more talk than walk
advice_management: Get back to your roots, and figure out how to leverage the intelligent, hard-working people you have to innovate vs firing thousands every quarter just to finance your next acquisition.  Stop flip-flopping on business strategy (every few months with mass turn-overs in sr mgmt), which from my direct experience is why you failed at cloud.

job_title: Current Employee - Senior Manager, Cisco Collaboration Software Group
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 8 years

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Culture is absolutely fantastic. Managers are trained to be managers and handle people effectively. I love coding as spare activities, my manager encourages this and it has led to very creative and interesting results. We feel like part of a family and the benefits are outstanding. I just told my parents 'hey this colleage gave me $100 on a connected recognition award because I helped him outside my normal activities" and they were like 'wait, you guys send MONEY to each other just because?" and I explained, not just because, there is a way for us to recognize one another with giftcards, of course supervised and honor-based. They could NOT believe it. sometimes neither can I. Tons of benefits. would recommend 10/10.
cons: some roles (like mine) are not fully mobile, meaning I need to visit partners every now and then, this doesn't allow me to go for example to a friend's apartment in new york and work from there, and explore NYC at night. (just an example).
advice_management: Keep doing what you're doing! I know you're Listening to us staff contributors, and sometimes you're between a rock and a hard place. Assign your quarterly performance key-sales-objectives - KSO taking into account what we LIKE to do and what we're supposed to do anyway, we'll feel great getting paid for it!

summary: "Not the same as most of Cisco ..."
main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than a year
pros: I was employed by the Cisco Consulting Services organization.  The was truly nothing positive about it.  I have never been a member of a more dysfunctional organization.  The only good thing I can think of is that four years have passed and perhaps corporate leadership has finally figured out how to build and operate a consulting services organization.
cons: Everything ... poor mission ... poor leadership and management ... severe political infighting ... truly perverse managers with no understanding of how to lead and direct effort ... everyone watching out for themselves and "assassinating" others in order to advance.   I have never been a member of a more dysfunctional organization.
advice_management: Junk it all and start over again!!!  Hopefully that is what has happened during the past four years.

summary: "Foster innovations, avoid hiring or promoting people like you"
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for less than a year

advice_management: Protect innovators from group think, promote people who will take risks and think outside of box.  Promote people who are not like you, especially coming from different ethnic background.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for less than a year
pros: The Cisco Benefits are unmatched.  However, beyond the benefits, 4.5% match in the 401(k), the extra time off, is the overall culture of the company and those that ensure that the culture of inclusion and diversity endures.  As a Veteran of the Marine Corps with 29-years of service, I was concerned that a civilian company would not share the same values or have a level of camaraderie even close to that of a military organization.  I was very wrong.  I have found that and more here at Cisco.
cons: Open working areas can be more collaborative but not appropriate for all practice areas, such as areas that may require sensitive HR or Legal type discussions.  Although there are Privacy Rooms available, having to search one out due to an impromptu meeting or call is counter productive.
advice_management: Continue to foster and maintain the inclusiveness that helps build strong teams.    Reconsider placement of teams with other department teams to mitigate "downtime" or wasted time searching for a place to conduct a sensitive call or meeting.

summary: "Doesnt know how to retain talent ! Huge politics involved"
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than a year
pros: Big name and wonderful sales engine, set frameworks and legends in networking work here !
cons: not so cool any more, does it the cisco way and say it is the right way ! tough competitors in the market !
advice_management: Please have a new employee fostering program and give clear tasks so they can feel accomplished and not have the fear of loosing the job !

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: 1. Industry  / Market Leader 2. Executive Leadership 3. Product / Solutions Roadmap 4. Compensation
cons: In the past, there's bee a challenge bringing synergy to the various silo's. Each group has a responsibility for a specific outcome which can often be driven without consideration for other groups. We are seeing a vast change in this old culture, which makes this con more of a pro!
advice_management: Drive more value pertaining to strategic career paths.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: People, benefits, remote work locations
cons: It feels like a pressure cooker trying to make Wall Street happy!!
advice_management: Communicate with your employees.  Tell them how they are doing and if you like their work, give them a pat on the back.  If there's room for improvement, provide feedback so they can improve.  Most of the time, there is no feedback until it's time for the yearly reviews.

summary: "You're on your own (that's good and bad)"
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than a year
pros: You're given the tools you need to do your job and you're entrusted to "do the right thing" (that was in the orientation).  There's a complete absence of micromanagement -- no one will tell you what to do, though they will sometimes provide guidance if asked, or as part of regular team operations.  Work/life balance is great; everyone is given a CVO to support working from home, which can be expected when you're working with teams all around the world.
cons: Everyone is doing their own thing.  Sometimes the pieces come together to make a functioning product/service, but only at the lowest levels.  The higher you go, the less likely it is that what you're working on will play nicely with what someone else is working on, and there is little broad leadership to tie all of the pieces together.
advice_management: There is more success among individuals than for the company at large.  Help us help you with plans we can understand and implement.  We know what the goals are, and we're all smart people, but we can't all row the boat in different directions at the same time.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems
pros: Work life balance, smart teammates, industry leader. Technology leader and trusted advocate for customers in all verticals. Great on a resume. Give time for charitable give back opportunities of your choice
cons: Sales targets are aggressive each week. Know your business, constant portfolio offerings that you need to learn to sell. Organizational skills are a must to ensure no task is dropped
advice_management: Management ranges from person to person. Managers who have been in sales on the front line identify with daily circumstances that arrive to work with you to find a solution

summary: "Fantastic colleagues, great culture, jury is out on corporate strategy"
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros:
Smart people everywhere.   Non-hierarchical culture, good ideas from anywhere can get attention and support.   Best flexible work practices in the industry, hands down.   Cisco really walks the talk and shows how a virtual corporate culture can flourish and pay off.   

New benefit offerings also speak volumes about how they care for the whole employee - longer paid bonding leaves for parents and grandparents, flexible emergency time off policy that each manager can tailor to meet their employee's needs, Time2Give which provides a full extra week of paid time off per calendar year to volunteer for a non-profit or educational institution of the employee's choice (above and beyond any team volunteering and give back events).
cons:
Cisco did not act quickly enough to shift its business model when AWS and other cloud vendors became threats.  Now we are playing catch-up.  Don't get me wrong, we have ALL the resources needed to win the catch-up game: cash on hand,  transformation strategy, excellent CFO explaining it to the street, excellent people...   

But we have some things that could drag us down:  sheer size (lack of agility),  continued success in high-margin core business (hard to decide to cannibalize yourself), high-level leaders who have been around too long, have too internal a view, little outside experience and who have succeeded too long in the old way to be willing to jump quickly to innovative strategies or new business models.
advice_management: Strategically clean house at Sr Dir and above levels.   Who can lead the future?

job_title: Current Employee - Senior Linux Systems Engineer
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Strong technology company. They have a huge global presence.
cons: Right hand, meet your left! They hire & fire based on numbers. They do not like to get personal.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Depending on the business unit, seems like a fun place to work.  Everyone else I see throughout the typical day seems to have plenty of free time to socialize.  Good benefits.
cons: Depending on the business unit, you may be asked to save the world with d t tape and baling wire.  Running WAY too lean.  Lots of lip service about customer satisfaction but when you're capped at 50-75% of what your headcount should be based on volume, customer sat is out of your hands...
advice_management: Either get serious about moving into the software sales and service market and invest accordingly, or GTFO.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 3 years

advice_management: Acknowledge workers more, give desks back, allow people to settle in where they spend most of their week.  We are more than just a number

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 5 years

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: A good Life/ work balance.  Work hard, play hard, rinse and repeat.
cons: Company is in the midst of re- inventing itself.  As such, many great people have been laid off, and other great people have left on their own accord for much greener pastures.   Morale is very low.  A once great culture has been lost.
advice_management: You have too many internal meetings.  Let your people go out and sell!  Call on customers  yourselves so that you don't always have to play CYA with your upper management.

Co-workers are diverse with lots of immigrant background, lots of Asian, so I never feel outcasted as a first generation Asian women.  Great benefits which keep getting better, including paid family leave, backup home care, etc. Easy to move around within the company, job rotation is highly encouraged.
cons: Not many opportunities to move up if that's your ambition, sometimes feel a bit too political.

I volunteered numerous hours with coworkers at Second Harvest Food Bank, the American Red Cross and RAFT (Resource Area For Teaching).  Cisco will donate $10 per hour of your donated time to the non-profit for which you volunteered.

advice_management: Focus on the customer.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Amazingly smart and dedicated people work at Cisco.  Many work very hard and demonstrate excellence and passion.  You can learn a LOT if you take initiative and get involved.  Lots of career growth opportunities possible.
cons: Technology shifts in industry, moves to Saas and open source are tricky waterrs to navigate.  Cisco has some huge advantages but getting alignment across the entire company can be difficult for any company of our size.
advice_management: Keep recognizing employees and making bold moves.  Now is not the time to be conservative or rest on our past success.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems  for more than a year

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Many good talented and dedicated people.  If they can get a consistent vision and strategy it is not too late.
cons: What was once a company of the best and brightest in the industry is being replaced with entry level or outsourced resources in an effort to keep costs down.  Regular quarterly reductions in force have everyone looking over their shoulder and fearing the next cut.  Employee Innovation and inspiration has been replaced with fear and top down direction.  No one wants to rock this unstable boat.  Those left behind are looking for careers outside of a Cisco before they are hit next layoff.
advice_management: Look to the people you have left and what that experience means to the bottom line.  A less experienced person can take up to 4 times as long to do the same work -

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Cisco has a really established name in the industry. So the place of work is great with a nice airy office. The people I worked with were really good and I cherish my time at Cisco because of the great friendships I have formed over time. The benefits are good.
cons: There is a lot of hierarchy and corporate bureaucracy.  Things don't move fast because the approval processes can be long and lengthy.  Salaries are not competitive at all.
advice_management: Please invest in your people more and don't treat them like they are the least important part of your company.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Great company to work for if you're motivated and passionate about technology. Pay and benefits are outstanding. Well run company that has weathered storms, recognized market shifts, and made changes when necessary. Lots of opportunities for promotion and trying on different hats if you're willing to make it happen.
cons:
Penny pinching to a fault at times. Bottom line is everything, often cutting into training and travel opportunities, or getting necessary resources.
Management is varied. Not all opportunities are equal, but with such a large company expect that. You need to make your own opportunities. Sometimes by working outside your job.
advice_management: Rewarding innovation and productivity is great. But measuring productivity only by how much people do can be misleading. Quality suffers when doing things fast matters more than doing them well.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years

pros: Good company to work for with lot of focus on gender equality.
cons: Frequent restructuring has become a norm.
advice_management: Cuts are dragged for weeks and months, casuing negative impact on productivity.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Good salary and life/work balance.
cons: Promotions are very difficult to get.  And they don't give out RSU stocks like they did 10 years ago or so.

summary: "Great Company to Learn From and Grow Network"
job_title: Current Employee - Sales Program Manager & Bow Tie Guy
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for less than a year
pros:
Cisco has 70k employees and somewhere around 40k contractors/vendors (total guesstimate) that work with us full time. We do business in over 120 countries worldwide. If you are a go-getter and have a passion for learning from work experience and global coworkers, Cisco is a perfect place to gain knowledge and grow your network which will help you through the duration of your career. Also, many roles are partial or full telecommute-roles, aka, work from home roles. Helps a lot for families with small children or folks who just live too far from a Cisco campus. There is a good range of younger, fresh out of college employees to seasoned veterans who have been in the industry for 10-30 years - so it's easy to find people that you want to hang out with or learn from.
Their social media teams are very engaged and a lot of the groups make working at Cisco fun! The different work teams and affinity network groups host fun events such as sports tournaments, concerts, outdoor lunches, networking events, and many more. We are partnered with Ticketmaster/Live Nation, as well as sports leagues like the MLB and NBA, so you may run into free tickets occasionally.
Great benefits (health, dental, vision, stock purchase program, 401k, life insurance), although salary is a bit low.
cons:
Free food is not a company standard, although many groups offer some free meals and snacks in the office.
The pay is lower than the likes of Google, LinkedIn, Facebook.
The company is so big and complex that sometimes, shy, young new hires are underutilized and underdeveloped.
Too many meetings.
Relatively low base salary, but benefits make up for it.
advice_management:
Really take the time to teach and develop new hires. Give them a good understanding of their role and why it is important to Cisco's larger mission. 
Be strategic about what meetings you are making people attend - in a world of meetings, everyone is multitasking. Too many meetings lowers engagement and job satisfaction.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Excellent compensation and benefits. Decent work environment. Generally good training opportunities (although not so great this year.) Excellent benefits, and very nice recent improvements to family leave policies.
cons: Internal support (e.g. IT support) is a complete train wreck. For your product, expect regulation after regulation after regulation (all internal). A tendency to use low quality internal tools instead of commercial ones. Layoffs, layoffs, layoffs. Except you don't call them layoffs, you call them LRs.
advice_management: Terminate the entire "acquire, then LR, then rinse and repeat" cycle with extreme prejudice. Don't outsource internal support. Perform satisfaction surveys for EVERY INTERNAL TOOL and replace the ones that don't work (i.e. most of them.)

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Greatest time there, accomplished a lot and always worked with a great team in the early years
cons: Growth can slow down, and be hampered because of politics.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: passionate and intelligent coworkers who drive the networking industry, great work/life balance, always challenging work
cons: politics within senior management is always a distraction, yearly restructuring is costly and can be blindsiding, process is heavy but getting more agile
advice_management: be more transparent on company and business growth and reorganization plans

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time
pros:
Huge opportunity to take your skills to the next level with the resources available if sought out.
Great teams and employees, benefits, work/life balance is very flexible.
cons: Management issues.  Direction changing constantly and seems like theyre stretched thin/overworked
advice_management: N/A

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than a year

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 3 years
pros: As an early in career employee at Cisco, I have been able to gain exposure to many organizations within the business and with upper management. I love that you have the autonomy to make your own schedule, which enables a great work-life balance. The company really values their employees and customers - and I love that we come first.
cons: If you are not able to manage your own time, you might be overwhelmed with getting tasks done and managing the distractions that might arise in this environment.
advice_management: Continue to encourage the workforce to adapt to change - in business models and in employee processes.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years

summary: "Great Company to Have a Work-Life Balance"
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for less than a year
pros: As someone early in their career, I've found that Cisco is a very welcoming environment. Individual contributors have the opportunity to work from home two days per week, and managers are very accommodating to working with occasional schedule conflicts. The benefits (401K employer-match, health insurance, PTO) are fantastic, and employees are also given the opportunity to earn Connected Recognition (awards via gift cards) for outstanding work. In addition to regular PTO, employee are given 40 hours of PTO per year designated to volunteering for the community, and Cisco will give $10 to the organization for every hour and employee volunteers. The cafeterias on campus are delicious and a great deal, and many of the floors in the buildings are being newly renovated. Overall, Cisco is a great place to work!
cons: It is a very large company, so you do have to work alongside people in other time zones via WebEx.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for less than a year
pros:
- Work flexibility
- Able to work from home on some days and when needed
- Get days off to volunteer
- SJ and RTP locations have a gym and medical facility 
-  ECN - Early in Career Network that hold social ,professional development, and volunteer events to meet other Early in Career employees. 
- Stretch assignments that allow you to take on tasks outside of your organization. All you have to do is signup on the portal.
cons: #NAME?

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Management empowers you to voice your new ideas and proposal improvements to the organization. Management will place you with meaningful work that is yours to own start to end. Culture really embraces to influence without authority from all levels which is great. I'm also a board member for one of Cisco's Employee Resource Organization's -- Early Career Network. It's an inclusive community for young professionals starting their careers to network & develop cross functional on the campus. Some of our events include happy hour events, professional development workshops-- negotiate your salary, and volunteer opportunities.
cons: very fast-paced culture and competitive. there's never not enough work to do.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for less than a year
pros:
-Flexible work hours and location. I can work remote on days I need to
-Visibility to upper-level employees. Frequent events for early in career to learn from the best wisdom at Cisco
-Meaningful tasks. I already feel like a value-adding employee after 2 months.
-Amazing teaching and learning opportunities. Entire online database of internal education that we are encouraged to learn from
-Amazing family. Cisco teammates are excited to help me grow, I do not feel like the environment is negative and competitive. Other young Cisconians willingly have helped me adjust to Cisco
cons: Make sure you are excited about the technology industry and the future that connection can bring the world. Otherwise, you won't like working here.
advice_management: New Hire Orientation did need a better explanation of stock options and help deciding health care plans

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems part-time for more than a year
pros: Work environment, pay, onsite facilities
cons: None that I can think of

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 5 years
pros: good work life balance and benefits
cons: due to size and product variety  in company can be difficult to implement changes globally

summary: "Company is in transition for the last few years..."
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Work-live balance. Culture can be good in some groups, but quite bad in others
cons: Constant re-org and LR;  Upper management care more about their jobs than doing the right thing
advice_management: You don't need to be a FANG (Facebook, Amazon...). Cisco is a great company in its own right, and you should value your own people and their experience, and not just try to replace them with Gen X and Y...

job_title: Current Employee - Senior Software Development Manager
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years

- Good vacation package
cons:

- SVPs don't seem to have a vision

-
advice_management:
- Growth opportunities are less

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Great work, life balance. Unlimited access to training and networking opportunities both inside and outside the company. Great pay and benefits.
cons: Ongoing shift in priorities. The current climate in the IT industry affects job security.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
The people are fantastic, personally and professionally.

Very good benefits.

Some of the projects are very interesting.

Perfect work life balance. I almost never take my work home with me.
cons:
Being such a large company, your satisfaction will entirely depend on your current team and project.

Some of the projects are very boring.

There's lots of bad upper management.

Product managers don't know what they're doing.

Not much room for growth unless you have a manager that advocates for you.

There are many layoffs per year after Chuck took over, most of which come as a surprise.
advice_management: Pay closer attention to individual contributors' morale. Stop with the surprise layoffs, and stop laying off people for bureaucratic reasons. Get a product management team that knows how to both listen to customers and properly convey customer requirements to the engineering teams.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than a year
pros:
Great on benefits.
Best in class work/life balance.
cons: Bad in salary growth. Lot of politics, which might limit your growth, if the environment is not conducive to you.
advice_management: Remove

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than a year
pros: Good collaborative atmosphere. Teammates care about each other and are excited to tackle challenging problems.
cons: Base salary is on the low side. Delivery estimates are sometimes too aggressive. Sometimes slow to move to new technologies.

summary: "Some business units are always on the verge of re-orgs"

pros: great benefits and people are wonderful
cons: management has some issues...they just come up with goals and have no intent on implementing
advice_management: change it up and respect everyone

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for less than a year
pros: The leadership team has made a conscious effort to improve the employee morale.  More work needs to be done to enhance employee experience by investing in Leadership capabilities at all levels
cons: Still operating in Functional Silos.
advice_management: Engineering needs to be held more accountable. A VP/GM structure may help

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Getting a paycheck is the only reason to work for Cisco
cons:
-"limited restructuring" every quarter that's not based on merit but rather if your manager likes you
-Select few get rewarded
-Majority of new technical leaders aren't technical.  They schedule meetings with engineers who do the work.  After that they present to managers & get the credit for  showing leadership.
advice_management: A culture of "limited restructuring" demonstrates the company doesn't value it's employees and is an example that company is not honest with it's own employees.

summary: "Mixed bag - okay for a short stay."
main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros:
many different business units - so lots of opportunity to learn 
mix of good and bad organizations: do your homework before joining.  Each business unit has its own culture

Overall good company to spend a couple of years in and then leave.
cons:
-low pay, not much advancement
-lots of nepotism.  I worked in ~ 5 business units and each of them were stacked with their own 'in' crowd
-lack of innovation
advice_management: Way too many layers.  Reduce the number of directors, senior directors, VP's and above.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for less than a year
pros: Good entry level on sales
cons: Salary is not bad but no possibilities to have a growth on my careaar

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros:
Somewhat flexible working hour, depends on managers. 
Onsite kids day care, onsite gym and health center. Close to lightrail stations, and easy access to major freeways.
cons: tough working environment, no fair review process. Personal favorism is played a big role here.  Management has no vision for future roadmaps, not openminded for all voices.
advice_management: Management needs to spend time to listen to all inputs, has clear vision for future product lines, roadmaps etc. Fair review system needs to be built up.

summary: "Best place to work as an early in career professional"
job_title: Current Employee - Digital Skills Enablement Coordinator
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than a year
pros: Great exposure to stretch assignments outside your role as an early in career professional; access to training, career development, and fun extra-curricular activities; fun and easy-going culture inclusive of everyone; great benefits and work-life  balance
cons: Some teams are stuck in the habit of old processes, get ready to learn lots of acronyms
advice_management: Give early in career professionals more responsibility and more opportunity to showcase their leadership

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for less than a year
pros:
Excellent benefits, newly introduced 13 weeks of maternity leave,  flexible work hours, allow occasional telecommuting. Board spectrum of internal positions available for career advancement. Many great managers who care about you as a person and as a professional, although there are also bad ones. Some groups are financially doing better than the others so sentiments across the board vary a lot.  Most employees are terrific. 
Many office spaces are remodeled recently and  snacks/coffee/fruits are provided as perks.
cons: There is constant restructuring of the company due to technology focus shift. Instability caused star/good employees to leave and laying off the existing ones, whether or not performance related, resulted in constantly low morale. It's a vicious cycle. Many are staying because they have family and they need the benefits.
advice_management: Sales team is not compensated entirely to be aligned with the company and business units' strategies. Please update the compensation model.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Great pay and doors always are opened to Cisco
cons: Staying up nights and weekends working and stressing while waiting for the next layoff.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 8 years
pros:
Market Leader in many product categories
Good pay and benefits
Telecommute options
Amenities at HQ: Medical, dental and vision services on-site, subsidized cafeterias, big gym
cons:
Annual layoffs and re-orgs
Not many opportunities for advancement

summary: "Cisco overall pretty good, but stay away from Service Provider Video"
main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Base pay and annual bonus are very good.
cons: Cisco has struggled to remain relevant among the leading IT and technology companies today - do you think of Cisco the same way you think of Google, Amazon, Facebook, Tesla, etc.?  I worked in Service Provider Video for 11 years. Since the acquisition of NDS it was all downhill with routine layoffs and a gloomy work environment.  Other business units may be different, but I would not recommend SP Video to any of my friends.

summary: "Good career opportunity if you can remain employed."
main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Access to many relevant technologies and certifications.  Great experience and well-known company to have on your resume.  Excellent benefits.
cons: Massive company, so I felt like a number and not a person.  More importance is often placed on following process than achieving results.  Company has been through many large-scale layoffs due to its many acquisitions and frequent reorganizations.
advice_management: Value your employees.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Individuals are great, benefits are pretty good, especially parental leave, and work/life seems fine.
cons:
Company messaging is contradictory with company action at times.  Particularly when it comes to their agile transformation.
And yearly layoffs are stressful, and seem to happen to just about anyone.
advice_management: There seems to be a disconnect between engineering and senior management and vice versa. Estimates and warnings seem to diminish the closer they get to the top, and directives from the top seem to be politely ignored in favor of bug counts and rushed feature completions.

summary: "Amazing company if you are in Sales"
job_title: Current Employee - Senior Manager, Strategy & Planning
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros:
Sales driven company
Innovative
Great culture and office environment
Career opportunity and development
cons: It can be difficult to navigate through complexities if you are silo'd in specific Business Entities.
advice_management: Keep moving forward on the transition from only box sales to services. Our customers are asking us to continue on this important journey.

summary: "Great on Internal Use of Tech.  Not good at execution for a while now."
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for less than a year
pros: Internal use of technology is to die for. 1, 2 or even more work from home days in not an issue. Company stands behind you in case of any kind of personal or family emergency.  Some really good talent in engineering and elsewhere. Switching job roles is relatively easy - a good way to get a well rounded experience.
cons: Poor execution is a norm. Too much money is wasted on consultants as most employees just like to manage at higher level.  Mid level management is ineffective and 'siloed'. Big and small layoffs are a norm. I see a lot of seasoned talent leaving.
advice_management: Promote talent from inside. You have tried revenue growth and it is  not working a lot, focus on executing operational improvements and retain talent - there is a lot to be done there which will go a long way in improving gross margins.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for less than a year

cons: back company culture, large LR not good
advice_management: not a very good choice

cons: old fashion way working culture

advice_management: Eliminate waste and operation expense. Performance based Lay Offs

cons: Yearly layoffs; Americans are substituted by folks from India; projects are moving to India.
advice_management: Loos around! Hire local people too.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for less than a year
pros: High impact work, highly resourceful teammates, flexible environment
cons: lack of fresher mentoring, process heavy workflow, not an easy job, easily siloed
advice_management: empower (not just inform) employee to take advantage of their benefits.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Flexible working in the office or at home. A lot of nice and friendly people that willing to help the peers. A lot of volunteer hours as well as matching funds to school or charity of your choice.
cons: Reorganization and reorganization. It happened at least 2 rounds per year.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
Solid technology in core areas
Brand reputation with customer base is still solid - if aging.
cons:
Losing market share in EU across all product lines
As a high performer/high potential employee you will be asked to pursue projects or possibly rotate into another group to do something new.  The moment that "new" thing loses its political backing you WILL be laid off in a "Limited Restructure".  
A good Cisco employee is 60% worker and 40% politician.
advice_management: Stop having Directors with no reports reporting to Sr. Directors with one report who in turn report to a VP with only 1 or 2 reports and no real purpose.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Great place to work, lots of wonderful people and tons of growth opportunity.
cons: Promotions and pay increases were hard to come by but not impossible.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time
pros: Its very slow in decision making
cons: It adds delay to project completion.
advice_management: Reduce too many layers.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems  for more than 10 years
pros: (1) Trying to address major shifts in the market. (2) Great people. (3) Admirable culture
cons: (1) Appears to be more tactical, but 3-5 year strategy and "big bets" aren't evident.  (2) Lots of layoffs of very good people (3) Great culture may be changing
advice_management: Develop, communicate, and execute on new "big-bets" that will return the company to growth

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros:
Benefits are OK, not great
Working from home is a plus
cons:
Untrained management with little accountability
Says one thing concerning the people who work here but acts differently
For a Tech company, there are much fewer perks than most tech companies but the work is still hard
Yearly layoffs hurt morale and add work to the "survivors"
The company has gotten a bit bloated and "focused" on too many different areas to be effective in any of them
Not much ability to move into management.  Current managers are not going anywhere
advice_management: Clean house in the management area, stop laying individual contributors ONLY off.  train and hold managers more accountable.  help people move up.

job_title: Former Employee - Senior Technical Marketing Manager
main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Company is run as a business.  Great access to variety of technologies.  Great access to training certifications/materials
cons: Too many mid level managers who don't add any value.
advice_management: Company needs to focus on retraining talent from within instead of laying off and hiring externally.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Good overall package and opportunities
cons: old style process and systems

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for less than a year
pros: It has been exciting to join a team where you have opportunities to shape the team culture, participate in process improvement initiatives, and be immersed in innovative technology solutions.  There are plenty of opportunities to learn and grow at Cisco. Our executives within Customer Success are open minded and engaged with us to continue to improve and identify how best to serve and help us succeed in our roles. Good benefits
cons: Despite Cisco being a large company, you should expect and be comfortable with change. Processes are continuing to evolve and adapt as Cisco aligns its efforts with its strategic vision. It can be a fun challenge to contribute to and be a part of that change but it also requires patience along the way. The tools and resources provided to us to do our jobs can at times feel numerous and complicated trying to piece it all together but great effort is being put into tying it all together
advice_management: Continue soliciting feedback from and working with employees to improve the department.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems  for more than a year
pros: Great benefits, strong culture, great campus
cons: Mundane, not feeling like you're doing important things all the time

summary: "Cisco IT as an Early in Career employee"
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than a year
pros:
The work /life balance is fantastic. I'm able to work from home whenever I'd like, and since Cisco is a global company, I've been able to travel on my own and work out of other Cisco offices without taking time off.    

5 days of paid time off to volunteer. 

The people! Everyone I've worked with has been very nice and eager to share knowlege.  

On campus gym and doctors office at a very reasonable price. 

Dogs can come in the office on Wednesdays and Fridays.
cons:
There's no IT training program for recent grads like there is for sales and HR. 

Initial team placement after recruitment was off, but I was able to rotate into an area that I'm really excited about after about a year. 

Continuous layoffs really impact office morale.
advice_management: Try to match the skills and interests people have to the needs of the team you place them on. It seems like a lot of early in career employees in IT have just been thrown onto random teams without regard to our skills or the types of projects we would like to work on.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
-Excellent salary, benefits, perks, work/life balance (most of the time)
-Great early in career presence, support, and opportunities 
-People are friendly, welcoming, helpful; fun culture 
-Lots of great resources on campus (doctor, gym, cafes)
cons:
-Leadership information and decisions not always transparent, don't always trickle down well 
-Internal movement can be difficult and political

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for less than a year
pros:
Awesome company to work with.

Good Culture and flexi benefits.

Work life balance , trust in employee at every level. Lot of positive environment around to work with.
cons:
Too many managers ? 

No RSU

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Flexible, remote work environment. Strong PTO policy and benefits
cons: overall growth a challenge with the company--core business contracting
advice_management: Keep doing what you've been doing

summary: "One of the top most employee friendly Company"
main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 8 years
pros:
Technological Leader in Networking Gear
Flexible working hours, working from home options in some of the jobs
Salary at par with Market
cons: nothing I can think of. Be positive always!
advice_management: Business Heads leading Technologies that are in adoption or evloving need to pay attention to alleviate work pressure otheir respective employees

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time
pros: great culture, solid leadership, good opportunities for rotations
cons: sometimes moves too slow; lack of decisions
advice_management: continue to push transformation into new markets outside of core networking

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than a year
pros: When engineering was more diverse before round after round after round of 're-structuring' work/life balance used to be decent.
cons:
In Engineering, if you are not part of the 'in crowd' (aka Indian) you will quickly notice the politics around you.   There are issues with upward mobility, projects you are given, and if you refuse to work nights and weekends you are seen as "not doing enough".  

Also, you can tell by working with others that many people got their jobs simply from being being connected to another Indian.
advice_management: Take a look at the hiring practices of H1B's, stop hiring from overseas for lower wages to displace American workers.  Why is the majority of the Engineering org not diverse?  Stop the nepotism, but maybe its too late... from the lower tiers all the way up, zero diversity.

Lack of ethnic diversity in Engineering.  If you're not part of the friends and family program, you will quickly get discouraged by the unethical work environment, favoritism, hiring practices, and promotions. 

Work life balance:   Heard of groups demanding engineers to come work on Sundays while preaching to have fun.    

Over the years through numerous restructuring and reorgs, they've lost key talent to maintain and keep quality of core software

summary: "Cisco culture degraded after Chunk Robbins' taking over"
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros:
We can meet many talents (may be old ones) here. Overall legacy benefits are still good enough in this industry (at around, or a bit above average).
If you can lock high position/salary, you shall take it.
cons:
After Chunk took over 2 and half year ago, he only give regular employees 2 times of promotion/salary increasing. First interval is 12 months, 2nd interval is 18 months.
In John Chambers' time, this interval is 6 months. 
Normally, at Cisco, each time only 8 - 15% employee got promoted. Even the interval is 6 months, it takes > 3 years for a regular staff to get chance promoted in average. Now Chunk make it 18 months or more, the simple calculation will tell you that each promotion takes more than 10 years in average !
So unless you are at your later stage of career and secure a top position, it's not wise to join Cisco. It's not friendly to its employees anymore. For average people,
if he/she joins Cisco now, his/her career development is stalled.
advice_management: Treat employee in some way, our customers will be treated in the same way.

advice_management: Stop treating Engineers bad, they are the one building systems.  Instead layoff paper pushers, managers, pathetic leadership

job_title: Current Employee - Virtual Customer Success Manager-CSAP
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than a year
pros:
This is a great sales training rotational program for people with sales experience who want to first learn about and understand the Customer Success role. Cisco in general is an amazing company to work for and our leaders are just that; intelligent, committed, individuals who strive to ensure our success.

Customer Success is the new era of sales and I would highly reccomend this position. This role is unique in how it exposes you to the new way of not just selling products, but selling business outcomes. It's also exciting for those who like to innovate, value relationship-building with the customer, and pioneer new processes and ideas. I really enjoy being able to have direct impact at a company this big and being a member of the Customer Success Team here at Cisco gives you that unique opportunity. 

I can't emphasize enough the responsiveness of our executives and leaders; I'm honestly amazed at how Cisco has given new employees the ability to have exposure with our senior management and how willing and compasionate they are about our sales team.

I would reccomend Cisco, Customer Success, and Sales to anyone, hands down.
cons:
Working at a fortune 100 company as large as Cisco, especially as we migrate our revenue model and product offerings, means there will be holes. I think this is natural at any large company but the mindset of adapting to ever-changing processes, acquisitions, etc. is crucial in order to thrive. Not necessarily a con if you like a challenge and put in a lot of effort. 

No "work from home" but not necessarily a con either; I personally prefer to come in the office but just something to keep in mind as people have different views on this.
advice_management:
Stay engaged with your team members and keep developing talent; leadership and management does a great job of doing this. 

Minor constructive criticism from personal perspective: I think it's important for our leaders (and fellow Customer Success Managers/Sales counterparts) to keep in mind that we are experienced sellers even though we are "CSAP". CSAP traditionally has been an ASR training program for individuals straight from college and it sometimes feels as if people forget that we are 25-35 year olds; the vibes come off the wrong way occasionally. This could be due to the fact that this is the first year this role was launched but awareness is key. Super minor but that would be my only advice.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years

cons: No diversity in engineering. It’s operated as a compete sweatshop. Nights and weekends are normal working hours for some BUs. No advancement if you are not part of the same ethnic group.. You are replaced by someone who can work the extra hours and has the yes sir attitude. Contractors are flown in over a span of two days and stuffed into apartments with others to do sub par work for sub par pay.
advice_management: HR needs to review each of the candidates and make sure there is diversity in engineering. A lot of unethical hiring practices have gone unnoticed and it continues to happen. Hiring managers are paid under the table to bring in talent from contracting companies which are brining in the same ethnic group. There needs to be diversity and not the same shade of color across 95% of your engineering team.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years

I must say I am very very impressed by the way Cisco takes care of their employees and former employees.
cons: I don't like the new open workspace concept. It's very chaotic and highly unproductive. Most of the employees at Cisco don't like it. I didn't meet anyone who liked it. But still, it was enforced. It was disappointing to see Cisco didn't care about employees opinion. I can understand that it's highly cost-effective to stuff double the employees in the same old space.
advice_management: Most of the engineering managers in Cisco are actually technical leaders. They have absolutely no idea on dealing with people. I agree they are highly technical. But that's the point. They are good technical leaders. My advice to management is that please ensure that people managers should be trained and evaluated based on their people management skills as well.

cons:

- All the acquisitions make Cisco a very segmented and unfair place.  Different treatment for many of our big acquisitions still exist and their is no timeline to create a 1 Cisco mentality.
- Management doesn't like the HR processes, systems, and tools created to make a transparent, listening, fair, and engaging environment so employees suffer.

summary: "Not the Cisco of the 90's and early 2000's"
main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros:
Great benefits for employees outside Silicon Valley. Respectable benefits for Silicon Valley Companies.
Generally higher than average local salaries than other companies in RTP.
Many opportunities to learn and grow professionally, so long as you drive your growth.
Top-notch people to work with in US.
Complex technology.
Cisco culture. Have a serious family emergency, or even minor, most groups understand and always say take care of your family. wonderful examples of employees out for 5 months with medical issues, Cisco and individual team took care of them and family.  Child out with serious illness, again most groups really pitch in to help out.
Long term, short term disability outside California is not as good as CA, but better than most companies in RTP. Parental leave meets local laws, but not equel throughout company.
IC's allowed to make deisions
PTO at 4 wks starting can't be beat.
cons:
Cisco is very risk adverse for long term projects. Some are ahead of their time, but company not willing to develop market or save product for when market is available.
New products only seem to build on existing. Market share loss to cloud vendors, etc. New Security services along with Advanced Sere vices pulling in most of money
Work loads can vary by groups.  Yearly layoffs becoming a thing.  Seems that it's quicker and less expensive to lay off top technical people and hire new ones with some new expertise, rather that really invest in and develop current dedicated staff.
Mobile worker cubes and open work environments not conducive to burying your head into work.
I'm sure there are far worse places to work in North Carolina
advice_management:
PLEASE change risk attitudes from the top down, please! Take the big risks- ones that may take several years to pan out- just like Google, Amazon, GE, Tesla, Microsoft. 
Please stop being afraid of leaving core competencies. Use your world-class engineering staff to dream, and dream big. Develop products that rival the success Cisco IP Phones, CCM, and Unified Communications, capitalize on it, and promote the company brand with the public again, so that they notice the Cisco phones in Petsmart and Home Depot.
 
Finally, the mobile worker cubes don't actually help morale or productivity for core Engineering staff. Most of us couldn't hear ourselves think.  Engineer staff need to collaborate, but at the same time need a dedicated location (not at home) to think, plan, and code. I had difficult time staying focused, plus no room for my Webster's dictionary, Thesaurus, Marketing and Technical Doc Style guides.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Mature company,  can drive good strategic initiatives when it needs to.
cons: Switching market is under pressure, top line revenue is eroding.
advice_management: Think about new business models

summary: "innovative but paranoid and not very loyal"
main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: This is a big company with a lot of great employees and a lot of innovation.  Cisco does not want to join the long list of previously great Silicon Valley companies that missed a market transition.  They are constantly trying new strategies (which gets a little exhausting at times, throwing stuff at the wall and seeing what sticks).  I think the salary, bonus, and RSUs for top performers are very strong.
cons: 2005-2014 I thought Cisco was a great place to work, but not a good stock to own.  Now it is kind of the opposite.  If your Business Unit is not growing by 10% annually, you will get your budget cut proportionally and that money will go to the growing BUs.  Our BU growth slowed, and we got cut a little in 2014, a LOT in 2016, and now again in 2017 including me.
advice_management: Work a LOT harder to find homes for employees you are laying off,  because we are smart, hard working, and loyal to you!  You paid me a lot of money to go away in this LR.

summary: "Great company to have it on resume but not to grow with"
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: #NAME?
cons:
I have been at Cisco almost 20 years and I have seen it all. 

- You get the promotion in title but not in money or the direct training.
- They used to want you to have a 65% customer facing, now it is close to 90%.
- Terrible tools to work with, and especially exposing customer to it, frustrates everyone.
- No trainings being offered. We have internal trainings available but management dont give you the time to do it since they expect you to be almost 100% customer facing.
- Bonuses are being cut off all the time.
- Benefits are being cut.
- Frequent management reorganization is distractive.
- Everyone is trying to save their job so there are not many enabler managers.
- Layoffs every 6 months and outsourcing jobs to 3rd party contractors offshore.
- Don't expect this work to be 40 hours a week. most of us put double that. That is what is expected.
advice_management:
- Evaluate the employees who has dedicated and brought success to Cisco with their loyalty and commitment.
- Be an enabler again, improve their skillset and their mood by not cutting the benefits.
- It is Cisco, we are not reinventing the management wheel. If you are a director, then you probably know how to operate in Corporate world. Stop the guessing game and provide steps to success for not only for the company, but also employee growth.
