summary: "Great place to work, not so great to get stuff done"
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Cisco has great benefits, decent compensation, and is generally a great place to work.
cons:
The company is greatly held back by the weight of its previous successes. Its flagship products (router/switches) are powered by an OS written in the early 90s. The groups that work on these products are typically 10 years behind the rest of the industry, and are so large that the rest of the company is held back by them. 

Management has been aware of this for years, and so has been acquiring other companies to do the development work that its core engineering groups are simply incapable of doing. This makes the company a bit schizophrenic as there is no real coordinated effort to move the company in a specific direction.

This is not a condition unique to Cisco; Microsoft famously has similar problems with Windows. It does not make the company a bad one, but it's certainly not as forward looking as you might think. The siren call of several billion dollars a quarter for basically not changing *anything* is tough to ignore, and I certainly don't blame them for it. But as an engineer, it's frustrating to watch this happen.
advice_management:
Embrace public cloud technologies for Engineering as a whole, not just the switching/routing groups. Most modern teams desperately want to use AWS but are constantly held up by ancient Infosec rules.

Recognize that dog-fooding UCS is very difficult for engineering groups without huge budgets. UCS is a premium product, with premium prices even with internal discounts. The current approach of centralizing UCS support to a single team is not allowing teams to actually use it the way Cisco recommends using it to customers.

The old-guard IT teams need to be shaken up. There are far too many IT teams composed of hundreds of contractors that do nothing but answer cases. There is barely any automation in the core IT areas (compute/networking). Whatever you are being told by the VPs/directors about "modernizing IT" is either not happening or happening much more slowly than you realize.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: I love the people that I work with - they support me and challenge me every single day!  I also love that Cisco places such importance on giving back to the community.  We are encouraged to give back with our time, and we even get 5 days of "giving back" time every year, in addition to regular time off.  I also love that no matter my passion, or how I want to grow, there is a role for that at Cisco.   I also love that I have had the chance to take a TON of leadership training throughout my career.  There have been opportunities specific to being a woman - how to navigate an industry where I am a minority, and helpful tips on managing my career, and opportunities available to all, to grow as a team leader, a strategic leader, and as a person.
cons: Every role has his ups and downs, as does every company.  But what I have found is that we work through them all as a team and as an entire company.  We all have to do our part, and we never lose alone, because we have the whole Cisco team behind us.

summary: "Not what it used to be. Random layoffs means they have no direction"
main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 8 years
pros:
I loved being challenged and learning new technologies. 
The people I worked with were like a family; everyone was always looking out for each other. The engineers I worked with were some of the most talented in the industry.
cons:
They started massive layoffs and are laying off good and critical people. 
They no longer care about the employees and only care about their quarterly earnings. 
Cisco keeps chasing innovation when they should be the innovators. They have the reputation of killing off products. 
Management changes every year will eventually hurt them. Just because it was successful while John Chambers was CEO doesn't mean they will be successful in the future. Always doing the same thing will not always result in success; by constantly changing management every year they are doing the SAME thing.
advice_management: CEO needs to be replaced by someone that knows engineering. Cisco needs to hire leaders that understand technology and innovation. Currently the leaders have not technical background.

summary: "Cisco: Stay profitable/Support "what you call" your most valuable resource"
main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for less than a year
pros: Interesting technology and intelligent colleagues make unpleasant working conditions *almost* tolerable (though not quite).
cons:
Congested, noisy work areas
Little to no support for writers working remotely. Overcrowded freeways  guarantee a 1.5 to 2 hour round trip commute from my home (10 miles from the Milpitas campus where I worked). Factor in the after-hours conference calls and last-minute deliveries, Cisco gets approximately 10-20 hours free in addition to the 40-hour weekly salary the company pays exempt employees.
advice_management:
Stop investing in bricks, mortar, and reorgs. Short-term gains are not worth long-term losses caused by 
* managers who fail to support telecommuting because they aren't allowed to work remotely themselves. (I don't understand why writers and engineers who communicate primarily by Email and WebEx are forced to work onsite, elbow to elbow, at cramped tables with  constant background noise.)  

Cisco claims that the open office floor plan encourages communication, although most of the conversations I experienced involved subjects that were not work related and were often quite distracting.
* untrained staff and managers hired to fill gaps when ad hoc layoffs threatened contractually obligated deliveries.

Start investing in training for managers and project-related training for individual contributors.

summary: "Hope I never have to work anywhere else"
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: I love the flexible schedules and the ability to work from home.  The culture, the people, the constant learning... it's great.  In 12 years I have only ever encountered one bad manager and that person was released within 6 months.  They really listen to the people in all levels of employment.
cons: the hours... while the schedule is flexible, when working in a sales support role, the hours are not the typical 8-5 m-f.  I have worked many late nights and many weekends.  There are some weeks where my hourly pay is minimum wage due to being on salary.  Answering the phone or responding to texts and emails outside of the 8-5 hours is required, not just expected.
advice_management: stop with the you must hit this target this week vs it's okay if it hits Monday... it's the same fiscal quarter... it forces sales teams to pull in people from all areas of the business and our partners on a Saturday when they should not be expected nor required... and I do mean REQUIRED to work.  If we don't, it's understood we might be cut in the next round of restructuring.  We report quarterly earnings... booking a deal in week 6 vs week 7 should not be a life or death situation.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 5 years
pros: This company has a culture of consensus, which means that we can take a lot of time to make decisions, but at least there's no bully in the room dictating one way or the high way. What I enjoy the most about Cisco is that it has given me the opportunity to be truly me: I have been promoted twice in 7 years, while having a 1 year old son when I started and a baby 4 years after starting at Cisco. Whenever my kids are sick, or I had to take them to an appointment, my team always had my back. This is the main reason why I am at Cisco - this employer will make sure men and women can have exciting opportunities at work WHILE being a parent. We have 40 hours a year of volunteer time, I use it to attend my kids field trips and volunteer at school. There is true worklife balance and a lot of flexibility when it comes to working hours. As a woman, I value this tremendously.
cons: This is a very very big company and if you don't network and get out to meet people, you'll miss out on opportunities.
advice_management: Please stop the annual LR Cycle. Let it be easier to manage low performers out,

summary: "Help us attract more diversity to Cisco"
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 8 years
pros:
-innovative company 
-moves quickly despite large size
-sales driven
-management makes the right decisions to correct the course
-provides large responsibility to the individual contributor level
-excellent management
-I believe this company provides as close to equal pay as possible
- I am fortunate to work for a woman who is an executive's multiplier who lifts me up with her access to execs.
cons:
-not as diverse as I would like it to be
-doesn't provide the opportunities for exposure at higher levels (need multiplier effect to be multiplied)
-women at the top tend to be viewed as ruthless and not helping other women succeed 
-not a lot of ODs are women - which appears to be a big differential
- without my manager's support I would be very lost in this culture.
advice_management:
- double down on the multiplier effect at all levels - and follow through
-more accessible career options for women and diversity 
-include more women in highly visible events - Salesforce forced management to go down levels for a strategic meeting/event to include at least one women from each representative department - lifting women up to levels they had not been exposed to before.  After the first forced event, it became natural to lift women up.
-make the executives like Alison, Wendy, Fran more accessible to high potential individual contributor women
- let's see more diversity at the  OD level!

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros:
I feel that I am the Sammy Sosa of Cisco.  What does that mean?  Sammy Sosa used to say when he played baseball for the Chicago Cubs that baseball had been very, very good to him.  I feel that Cisco has been very, very good to me!  

Flexible, open environment with challenging work that pushes me outside of my comfort zone.  As a female at Cisco, I have had a good working environment working for both men and women.
cons: Political issues do get in the way.  The yearly LRs are tiresome and sad to see good people go.
advice_management: Recognize that each individual on the team can bring different strengths to their role.  Not everyone needs to be a Type A, all types contribute differently.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Great benefits, time off policy, stock options
cons: It's a company full of old, white men
advice_management: stop trying to make promotions impossible for women

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems part-time
pros: The environment in Cisco is very nice and the leader of our project is responsible and willing to help
cons: It seems like that the development in Cisco is not as promising as it was before.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Within my organization, inside Cisco - leadership continues to raise the awareness on I&C.  Individuals are aligned to a mentor to assist in their role for today and the role they want tomorrow.  Those that perform are able to turn mentoring relationships into sponsorship's.   A mentor talks with you and a sponsor talks about you.
cons: Even though Cisco is moving the needle, diversity - on all levels - is still something that needs work.
advice_management: Create more awareness to what each role is within Cisco.

summary: "3 Maternity Leaves Later... Still Going Strong"
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Flexible schedule, meaningful work, competitive pay, career path
cons: Fast pace industry has employee health implications
advice_management: Keep developing women aspiring managers

summary: "Cisco is a great place to be!"
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 3 years
pros: At all levels of the organization, there is emphasis and value put on diversity in the workplace.  Many leaders understand the beauty and strength of our differences, and are not interested in creating a cookie cutter employee.  Many of the perks of being a Cisco employee highlight how much they want to take care of their employees, such as the onsite health and fitness centers, family events on campus, etc, but they go beyond these "nice to have" items and back up their words in the work.  My opinion is appreciated most when it differs from those around me and offers a fresh perspective.  We also have very strong communities to support each other and enable success of the individual.
cons: There are very few cons when it comes to working for Cisco.  It certainly isn't like a startup environment and ideas can take longer to put into action because of the bureaucracy that comes with a company of over 70k employees, but you can learn to navigate these waters smoothly.  There is vibrancy and learning at Cisco that you won't find elsewhere.
advice_management: Coach middle managers to appreciate the case for diversity and take action.  Provide more coaching and training for first time and young managers to lead in this new era.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 5 years
pros: I am a professional woman who has worked at Cisco for 6 years and have loved the company culture since Day #1!  Cisco values and respects its employees and I enjoy working in a diverse environment of mutual respect where all ideas and points of view are welcome.  I also enjoy the flexible work environment and Cisco's commitment to work-life balance.  I also love Cisco's commitment to giving back to the Community.  Cisco's Corporate Social Responsibility is strong and that is important to me!
cons: Change is constant at Cisco and, in order to be successful at Cisco, employees must be agile and be able to adjust to change and sometimes work and push forward amidst ambiguity.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than a year
pros:
Cisco has the perfect balance of innovation, from a technical perspective, and established business practices with a strong customer base. A primary benefit to employees is a reasonable pace. It's possible to do excellent work without sacrificing one's personal goals and the work environment is definitely more collaborative than competitive. An additional benefit is the ability to move about the company to work on different products and projects. 
The employee population is remarkably diverse and both the executive leadership and HR underscore the value of inclusion and collaboration (diversity) in both it's composition and everything it says and does. Cisco takes diversity very, very seriously.
Deep support for working remotely is absolutely outstanding! We're able to draw  talent from all over the world instead of limiting ourselves to only those people who are willing to live in or near Silicon Valley.
cons: The overall culture isn't quite as tech intensive as the culture I've experienced at major software  and services companies such as Microsoft.  At other companies for example, demos of products in development were a critical component of any meeting. At Cisco we tend to focus on the bigger business picture.
advice_management: Create more roadshows of products in development to generate excitement about our offerings.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Working at Cisco is very flexible.  Cisco is all about work-life balance.  There are lots of opportunities to succeed and add value.
cons: Expect to work hard, competition is stiff.  Women are still paid less than men, however, they are working on it.
advice_management: Continual restructuring and reorganization can be disruptive.  Congratulations on slowing this down and stabilizing the teams.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Excellent job opportunities; Remote work; Technology; People
cons: Global company so timezone issues when working on projects; Pay not always equal to men although this SHOULDN'T be an issue
advice_management: Continue providing mentoring/training opportunities to allow women more growth chances; continue promoting women into more visible roles (SLT).

summary: "I can't say enough good things about Cisco"
job_title: Current Employee - Program Manager New Products
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Flexibility, inclusive, fun activities,  respectful and collaborative environment, innovation. Compared to lot of other companies, Cisco has a variety of events and activities to engage people from all culture and generations.
cons: Need to employ more Women in the work place
advice_management: I greatly appreciate that Cisco has continue towards the path of achieving greater diversity in work place and keeping up the "One World" vision in spite of the change in the political goals of the country.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: The customer centric culture is sensational. Willingness to work together to make the customer successful is paramount. Growing opportunities for women - Chuck Robbins has advanced topic of gender and overall diversity during his tenure.
cons: Not sure we have the right strategy to speed up and execute more quickly. Ongoing. rolling quarterly layoffs are destabilizing - but not sure there is a better way to get to our goals at quickly enough.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than a year
pros: Cisco allows for lateral rotational opportunities, a number of give-back programs, and there are employment resource organizations which allow for networking opportunities.  There are a number of employees with tenure grater than 4 to 6 years.
cons: There are often layoffs every 6months but these which can be countered by lateral rotations.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Collaborative, challenging work environment. Pushed to create your own role and goals, lots of opportunities to stretch and develop.
cons: High expectations and always challenging work, sometimes the many disparate tools make it more difficult to find solutions in a timely manner.
advice_management: We have excellent managers and leaders at Cisco, I think if we did a better job of showcasing/highlighting those managers, they would be a great role model for the average or less than average managers to look up to.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than a year
pros: Good pay. Good challenges. Good autonomy.
cons: Work/life balance can be horrible during busy periods. You probably won't get much chance to take vacation.
advice_management: Settle down on a workable business plan, execute. Don't rely too much on junior staff.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Results driven atmosphere, and a company designing technology that runs the backbone of the industry.   Very dynamic and fast paced (at least, in my role), and very customer focused.  Very easy to "rally" people due to a customer need.
cons: Very unclear requirements in regards to career pathing, raises, and future growth.  Lateral moves are the norm, but upward movement is a mystery, and appears to be shrouded in politics.
advice_management: Figure out what kind of company you would like to be, and focus on that maniacally.  Right now, Cisco is very focused on attempting to drive into many spaces of the industry, and that's driving diffusion of focus.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Still knowledgeable people, extensive product line.
cons: Too many lay offs, rehire to contract seems to be the current business plan.

summary: "Always changing, never boring - which is a blessing and a curse ..."
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
Great company culture, with no penny pinching, solid training and amazingly intelligent colleagues.

Opportunity to make some great money.

I support and sell a mature, industry leading product.

Full time work from home, with a reasonable travel schedule.
cons:
Things change constantly. Every year is another guess as to wether our team stays together, or not.

Despite selling a great product, it's not getting the focus is needs to stay innovative.
advice_management:
Support the good products better - more development, more training.
Stability! GSSO is barely 4 years old and already changed dramatically from it's early days. Let us get comfortable in our territories, products and teams!

summary: "Bright, generally decent people, good culture; some concerns"
main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros:
- Generally speaking, the majority of the people that are hired are bright,  passionate and decent.
- Cisco culture is generally good: geeky and business saavy
- Executive Team is solid and reasonably visionary (though this varies)
- Cisco has automated a lot of the low-hanging fruit of administrivia - e.g., expense reports - to reduce some of the clutter
- You are part of a very large and powerful force in technology.  
- The company encourages people to do a lot in their communities, etc.
cons:
- Cisco has gotten into this weird habit of doing small lay-offs ~ every 6 months.  Some of this is just a forcing function to help Managers who are not doing a good job of moving out under-performers.  The list goes out and managers are allowed to put people on it.  But it also creates an environment where everyone feels vulnerable. At the wrong place at the wrong time?  Got re-orged to a Team managed by a former rival, who sees you as a threat?  Regardless of performance, you can be RIF'ed.
- Company is transitioning from traditional hardware/rout/switch & accompanying on-prem software dominated company to have a bigger emphasis on cloud-delivered software and subscription based business.  It's a bit of a bumpy ride.
- a little stodgy/old world tech (IBM-ish) in some areas.
- all the things that go along with a being a huge company: e.g., grinding bureaucracy
advice_management: Keep doing what you're doing in terms of walking that fine line of transitioning to Cloud-delivered software without killing the existing business.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than a year
pros: Great benefits, awesome culture, ability to work with intelligent peers and managers who are willing to help when you need it. My position is also highly flexible, which is one of the greatest benefits.
cons: Cisco can operate as a large company and sometimes this impedes the ability to get things processed quickly. In addition, the diversity at Cisco can be improved. Cisco is great about hiring women but can hire professional of different ethnicities to improve overall diversity. Overall, awesome place to work!
advice_management: Please continue to hire diverse candidate and improve company tools to ensure teams are most productive.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Great company to work for, especially with constant focus on cutting-edge technologies and diversification into new areas of IT infrastructure and applications. Benefits are excellent.
cons: Constant reorgs over the past few years means slim chances of moving into a position that is a better fit for the employee. Getting your "foot in the door" may not necessarily be the best way to advance your career, whether an employee or contractor. I have seen good managers with 10-15+ years get laid off during these reorgs, so no one is safe.
advice_management: Hiring and firing in the same year is basically cherry-picking the best of the best, and while it is beneficial to the company as a whole, it doesn't serve the individuals, those who are let go or those that are left behind. Most people would rather take a pay cut or no bonus than to lose their jobs.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Good work life balance. Decent compensation. Challenging work environment
cons: Competition is coming after Cisco. Past few acquisitions failed.
advice_management: None

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
Good work environment
Good product will billion dollar yearly revenue runrate
Good benefits especially health plan & number of PTOs
cons:
I hated the layoff culture! Frequent layoffs affect PERM processing of H1B holders, but I guess the company is hardly bothered about it. 

The second issue I encountered was the willingness of people to learn new stuff slows down as the team dilutes. Not everyone is focussed to learn cutting edge tech, the attitude seems to be like a 9-5 job. 

Lot of bureaucracy!
advice_management: Stop frequent layoffs. If you have to do it, do it one go and be done! My suggestion is take a pay cut across the board rather than laying off people.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Good people working as "individual contributors"
cons: Extreme demands on time.  No work life balance.
advice_management: Use individual's skills. Don't expect people to be happy being a replaceable widget.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for less than a year
pros: Adaptability, Flexibility to meet the changing market demands. The people interaction and Innovation engine
cons: Accountability not just for projects but until it shows the result should be enforced

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
Generally being a TAC engineer is pretty flexible. You work 9 to 5. If a customer needs anything outside those hours you can have another engineer on shift handle the customer's needs.
You get access to a lab with all the newest equipment to test on.
If you need to make a little more money, you can work weekend shifts.
A lot of managers offer flexibility with the ability to work remotely once a week, however this position is not a remote job.
The organization does their best to recognize hard working individuals
cons:
Low pay compared with other customer facing roles at Cisco
High Stress - the account teams and customers expect you to be the one with the answers
You can get pigeon holed into one particular technology, especially if your technology is not 'hot'
Have to work weekends
advice_management: Promote from within the organization, especially in TAC. It's not a good optic that whenever a management position opens up, someone non-technical from another Cisco org takes the position to manage technical engineers.

summary: "Not the company it used to be"
main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Great people at your peer level
cons:
- Political nightmare 
- Incompetent sr. leadership 
- Incessant limited restructuring (layoffs) result in a gloomy work environment 
- Lack of upward mobility due to restructuring and flattening of the org structure
advice_management: Take a hard look at your attrition numbers and start asking why? The patterns may be surprising.

summary: "Commercial Sales Associate - This is more of a channel mgmt role. Face of relationship. (director, managers, & reps)"
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for less than a year
pros: Very flexible. 4 hour SLA, considered a remote/field employee, company card (monthly/yearly budget), great career enhancing role with a lot of opportunity to move up and make more $$$.
cons: Been in the role for 8 months and only thing I can think of is that being in the office 8hrs a day isn't needed but understand why they'd like you to be.
advice_management: Continue the growth and maybe offer a bit more training around companies products for next role.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Management. Ability to move within company.  Benefits.  Pay.  Flexible work options.
cons: I don't have any cons.
advice_management: Be the first.  Don't always wait to see what everyone else is doing.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Dynamic organization, excellent leadership team,great corporate citizen (community involvement),  inclusive environment, flexibility working arrangements, great benefits
cons: frequent restructuring causing layoffs each year
advice_management: Keep up the great work.  Let's find more creative and effective ways to retain women and minorities in this great company.

summary: "Early in career haven, cultural sate of flux."
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Great benefits, great opportunity for early in career.
cons: Minimal work/life balance.  Company is undergoing a directional change (HW to SW & Services) and the turning of the ship has many in flux relative to their career direction.   Culturally, losing the familial feel it once had, employees are treated as #'s toward the financial goals.  Annual lay-offs.
advice_management: Be more transparent, lose the p.c. messaging and say it like it is.

job_title: Current Employee - Virtual Customer Success Manager
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for less than a year
pros:
Cisco is far ahead of the industry in Customer Success.  Internal account managers, as well as customers, cannot believe that we are a free resource.

We are a newer team within Cisco that is growing rapidly.  We're able to help create best practices and pilot new offers.

Everyone has been great to work with and very willing to help when needed.
cons: Since we are a newer team, there are some growing pains, but that also brings excitement and energy.
advice_management: Keep up the great work!  You are doing an exceptional job of making sure our voices are heard.

summary: "Smart intelligent people inthe trenches,  stale senior leadership"
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: The people. The technology. The teamwork.
cons: Old School boys club still exists in sales. It's not based on capabilities but who you know. If your in sales there is a lack of opportunities to move upward. Very few women in sales leadership roles.
advice_management: Time to blow up the sales organization. The culture has changed and seems to have reverted back to 2000.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Great culture.  Wonderful teammates.  Challenging but fun.  Great work/life balance.
cons: Technology is ever changing and keeping up can be challenging.
advice_management: Keep appreciating your employees, stay transparent

job_title: Current Employee - High Touch Operations Manager (HTOM)
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than a year
pros: Cisco offers great benefits and an awesome work life integration culture
cons: I spent 3.5 years as a contractor to get full time status.  A lot of times doing very important jobs where I had a teammate that was blue doing the same job.
advice_management: Convert  your red badge employees if that's what they're long term goal is.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
+ Generous WFH. 1-2 days a week is normal.
+ Management trusts you to get the work done, so no micro managing (depending on which team/manager you have)
+ Opportunity to work on tough problems and work amongst the best in networking technology.
+ Work comes in cycles so the work-life balance is great during "down" time.
cons:
- Stagnant growth if you just do the work you're assigned. You have to do better than that if you want to move forward AND be visible to upper management (very important).
- Lack of innovation - competition has caught up and Cisco's position as the market leader is declining.
- Salary is average, not great.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 5 years
pros: World class recognition to work with and build great foundation enterprise execution processes.  And excellent place to work hard and really get global exposure in development.
cons: This behemoth is dated in implementation and execution of cutting edge technologies and advancements of career.  No real advancement in personal career growth if you don't share in the ethnic demographic basis

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Work hours flexibility, work from anyplace allowing better work/life balance. Empower culture
cons: High pace. It always more products/technology to learn

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Cisco Systems is a great place for a technologist, designers, project managers and other roles to learn. They will learn the latest methods, processes and technologies. It provides a foundation to advance within many careers.
cons: It is constantly going through reorganizations and lay-offs. No matter how talented, innovative and hard working you are, you never know if you'll be hit next.
advice_management: There a appears to be age and gender discrimination.  Similarly, although I was a Senior UX Designer and UX manager, and contributed long hours of support to my team and Cisco Corporate, my pay was below what it should have been, both within Cisco and across Bay Area.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 5 years
pros: I've been working at Cisco for 8 years. As a woman, the work flexibility I have to manage my work along with my family needs has been a key reason that I love my job. As I am coming to the end of raising two children, I can look back and feel proud of what I was able to do for Cisco and for my family. The work is always challenging and I have been given almost endless opportunity to use my skills and experience to add value to Cisco. I have been consistently well rewarded for my work, and I have never felt that my gender was a hinderance in what is often considered a male dominated industry. In fact, there have been many opportunities presented because I am a woman, as Cisco takes it's commitment to diversity of all kinds very seriously and they put their money where their mouth is.
cons: As with any large company, there are some disconnects that exist in strategy and approach alignment, but I believe this is very difficult to completely overcome in any large company.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: very nice teammates to work with. Flexible and pleasant teammates
cons: slow promotion and growth. top heavy.
advice_management: need to hire more fresh-graduates to make hierarchy balanced and allow employees to have a chance to grow

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 5 years
pros: There's a reason why so many employees stay for 10+ years and/or come back after leaving Cisco. Great benefits, diverse workforce, excellent work/life balance, reasonable pay.  Good training and career opportunities for women right out of college.  Dedicated people. Strong executive team. Very competitive.
cons:
1. I recommend that mid-career women joining Cisco enter at a level they can live with during the rest of their time at Cisco.  Only lateral career moves will be available to you after you join. Don't expect to see a raise or a promotion.  
2. There is a layoff EVERY year at Cisco. Work slows and morale tanks the moment the rumor of a layoff begins to circulate. Bottom line: one quarter a year is lost because everyone around you is terrified of losing their job.
3. Engineering org is predominantly male and engineering  leadership is almost universally male. It's easy to get used to men talking over you in meetings,  and promoting your ideas as their own. 
4. There is a lot of finger pointing at Cisco. People have a lot of responsibility but little accountability. 
5. Extremely hierarchical. You talk to your manager, they talk to their manager, that manager talks to their manager. Only Director level and above have any authority.  
6. Every career movement is dependent on your manager's approval. If your manager is a dud, your opportunities at Cisco shrink to zero.
advice_management:
Promote mid-and late-career women and leverage their intelligence and experience. Recruit from the pool of women who have left Cisco -- and listen to what they have to say. If they return they will bring a fresh perspective and new ideas.  

The work/life balance at Cisco is truly unique.  If there were opportunity to *grow at all stages of our careers*,  Cisco would be unbeatable!

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Good benefit friendly culture  good team work
cons: I love working for Cisco
advice_management: none

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than a year
pros:
Constant communication 
Focus on the present and the future while learning from the past
Work/Life balance is a priority
Culture of trust, honesty and respect
cons: With the rapid change is our environment it is sometimes difficult to keep up with all of the new technologies

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Great benefits; flexible work schedule; mobility culture.  Excellent pay scale for the area.  Fantastic teammates -- everyone hired here is top notch.
cons: The company is so large that sometimes the messaging that comes from management is not embraced by the entire vertical and it leads to mixed messages to the employees.  Constant pressure to "cut opex" which leads to layoffs.
advice_management: Make sure that whatever messaging you send out to the rank and file is actually what is embraced and followed by all levels of management.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than a year
pros: Cisco has a multitude of internal resources for women to learn.  Cisco HR has become very aware of how many women they hire and managers advocate for equal treatment and opportunity for women.  Although the balance is still mostly male, I constantly run into women in cybersecurity, and it's a refreshing change  from my old employer, where I was the only woman.
cons: Global company = some early/late calls
advice_management: Keep it up and thank you!

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Flexibility, culture, collaboration in a virtual environment, ability to adapt to changing technology landscape
cons: Lots of changes lately impacting morale...
advice_management: NA

summary: "Inspiring co-workers and great work life balance"
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: At Cisco I find myself surrounded by smart and motivated individuals who constantly challenge me to be innovative and to improve.  This is especially true of the amazing women I work with who  inspire me to challenge the status quo while at the same time continuing to evaluate and evolve my own perspective and actions.  Additionally, the ability for me to define where, when and how I work is truly what enables me to be successful both at work and in managing the rest of my life.  And the technology we use on a daily basis to do that is truly AMAZING!
cons: As in any big company - patience, persistence and perseverance are key character traits you must rely on daily.
advice_management: Continue to challenge managers, especially males, to contemplate different versions and views of success in a role that may not look like what you have seen before.  Employees of different genders, generations, ethnicities may have a different approach that gets to the same or even better results.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Cisco consistently upholds the standard that our days start at 8 and we take weekends and holidays. I do end up working out of hours and on holidays but by choice and not requirement. My managers have consistently supported my professional development. I had the opportunity to attend the Simmons Leadership Institute and this made a huge impact on my professional and personal life.
cons: There is little awareness that men talk over women. I am often the only woman in the meeting and have never had a man say "wait, you just talked over her." I often have to wait until every man has finished talking before I can speak when I am running a meeting - when I am not running a meeting I often don't get to talk at all.
advice_management: Specific training in men's and women's language styles makes a big difference. If we can enlist men to recognize and step in when women are being cut out of the conversation this would be very helpful. I gave one of my managers a copy of Deborah Tannen's "You Just Don't Understand" and he subsequently supported me in meetings. Also I would love to have the chance to attend Simmons again, we are stingy with our seats.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 5 years
pros: As a new hire out of college, I was trusted with managing an application a few months into my role. This was very empowering and showed that leaders in the group were accepting of my talents and skills and they did not make assumptions about my inabilities just because I was fresh out of college.  When mistakes were made, they were acknowledged and treated as learning opportunities and individuals who genuinely work hard get recognized.  We have a great Inclusion & Diversity team and there are diverse leaders that help individual contributors gear up to bringing their whole selves to work. If it were not for the Employee Resource Organizations (EROs) / Employee Resource Groups (ERGs), working at Cisco would not feel impactful. I am grateful that we have an Inclusion & Diversity team and leaders that support the EROs so that leaders of the EROs can work to change the culture positively throughout Cisco.
cons: Not all organizations / teams in Cisco are open to all diversities and do not promote inclusion & diversity. It is not easy to be an LGBT employee in certain groups at Cisco and bring your whole self to work for fear of being treated differently.  Cisco tends to be a follower in inclusion and diversity trends rather than a leader in trends when it comes LGBT employee needs.
advice_management: Listen to your employees and their needs and be sensitive to their backgrounds. Not all diversities are openly visible, and making assumptions can lead to losing great talent.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time
pros: Great Benefits, Great company to work for, Stock options, 401K, Tough problems, High level of contribution to the company and customers, excellent skills building position
cons: (Not really a Con...but; you gotta love what you do). If you are placed in a role you will have high output requirements. You are expected to be really good all of the time. So only apply if you're looking to do something challenging every day.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Lots of internal opportunities for career growth
cons: No cons come to mind.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Flexible work schedule, great benefits, team orientated.
cons: workforce adjustments yearly.
advice_management: more training for women

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for less than a year
pros:
Work life balance 
good family culture
cons:
Legacy 
more focus on routers and switches
advice_management: Need to change the mindset that cisco cannot innovate

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Good work life balance. Decent pay and benefits.
cons: Will be working on stagnant technologies. Personal growth will be less.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
Clarity and inclusion on company strategy
Most women on a tech ELT in the valley
Innovation 
They give me a month every year of almost free in home childcare
cons: It's big. Campus is in San Jose.
advice_management: Could do more in on campus sustainability

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros:
Smart, caring people, lots of opportunity to shine and make an impact, as well as give back to causes you care about and support the community.  

Leadership is truly compassionate  and caring and will work hard to support your career journey.
cons: If you don't have a solid career plan, you can become stagnated and for those of us who have trouble with direction and asking for help, it's a challenge (but that would be anywhere!).
advice_management: Continue to support employees and their development, while understanding that not everyone is comfortable taking advice or showing weakness (or what they perceive is a weakness or failure).

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Flexibility, great pay, innovative and good people
cons: No annual appraisals so managers can do what they want, most upper management has no clue about the bad moral, no promotions, no stock options, no recognition
advice_management: Stop trying to bring on new in career millennials to replace seasoned employees that have a wealth of knowledge and experience.   Understand that you have great talent that you should try to keep.  Offer them a stake in the company such as stock options, currently in our team, only executives get stock.   Figure out a way to promote those that have done a great job and stop making excuses due to their already high level.  Want to keep people, not constantly replace them.

summary: "Great place to work, some patience necessary"
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than a year
pros: Fantastic benefits, flexible hours, interesting problems to solve, and fun people to solve problems with
cons: Older parts of the company (both Cisco HQ and recently acquired startups) are reluctant to change their ways, and enjoy grand standing on seniority.   Also, some colleagues have extreme alpha male tendencies, which can make for an uncomfortable new-hire environment.
advice_management: Look at how current employees treat those who are less senior, or less high-status, when considering their potential for management.  Those who are only pleasant towards upper management, yet difficult towards colleagues and team members, are not good additions to the company.

summary: "Cisco continues to inspire me to be my best at work every day"

pros: Flexible work hours, plenty of training classes offered by company

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 8 years

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 5 years
pros: There are a lot of things to like about working for Cisco; A fantastic, flexible, 'work-from-where-you-are' policy, great benefits and PLENTY of projects to work on.
cons: Cisco is a company with old values, expect age discrimination and little to no training. It can be frowned upon to take time off, or take time for learning, which results in most of the workforce woefully overworked and sadly behind the times in training. The cult of positivity is also very strong at Cisco, which makes trying to change processes or culture VERY difficult, any suggestion of change is usually taken personally and can result in active obstructionism to your goal.
advice_management: Updates to operations and then training would be fantastic. The new 'Check-in' tool is great, and would be especially useful if tied to good training. Our current internal training offerings are slow, expensive and frowned upon. Adding training requirements to every managers goals and a subscription to Coursera could dramatically upgrade the culture and workforce. Cultural updates that would help combat age discrimination and toxic obstructionism could be: Synchronized company release cycles, a single company interaction platform, a company communication guide that gives best practices on communicating across cultures and ages, an innovation guide that addresses how to bring new ideas to your management and department and ALSO how to accept new information and ideas. New priorities that set time aside to innovate across all job levels and actively research other options would also be fantastic.

summary: "good place for women bc of work life balance"
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 8 years
pros: work life balance has been great, the main reason why i stay. important for women who become mothers to have that balance.
cons:
lack of clarity around opportunities & requirements in order to obtain a promotion
very little salary increase year over year, i see a lot of colleagues going to other companies and obtaining a 20-30% salary increase. hard to want to  stay at cisco when there are other opportunites out there
advice_management: let women (& people in general) know & understand how they can get promoted, how to get a salary increase, what are the requirements, and how to achieve those

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Leaders truly care about employees and the whole employee experience at work. Cisco's cutting edge collaboration tools make meetings a breeze and enable employees to work from just about anywhere. The flexibility to get things done from wherever you are is a perk bar none!
cons: As a company and as individuals, the amount of giving back Cisco does is HUGE, but not publicized well enough to engender collective employee pride or talent attraction. The many ways Cisco uses its technology to change the world, provide disaster relief globally, and truly make a difference often happens in stealth mode.  It goes unnoticed. A big miss. Need to redouble PR efforts in this front!
advice_management: Focus on telling a unified story and celebrating innovation and innovators more often and broadly. Also invest equal focus in touting CSR.

summary: "Great until senior management lost interest in the strategy"
main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than a year
pros: Excellent culture and collaboration with coworkers. Great reputation with customers.  High ethical standards with both employees and customers.   Driven to virtual work environment well supported with the latest technology.
cons: Ever changing strategy. Lack of commitment to products beyond core networking, collaboration  and server products. Very internally focused with far more internal meetings than are needed.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 5 years
pros: great benefits and doing great things
cons: Not very good at helping one to transition to new team when no longer needed on current team
advice_management: Keep the good employees and help them move to new team.  Also, with the collaboration you offer, most Cisco jobs should be able to be remote.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Gym and health facility, large campus with 3 cafeterias and one specialty coffee shop, casual dress code, large parking lots with plenty of parking, new managers who care to succeed and improve, you are able to bring your laptop home and work from home if needed.
cons: Layoffs every year create very low morale especially during year end which is in July.  When people do get laid off, those jobs go to people who are already working a full time job. You end up with people who are doing the job of 4 people which is unsustainable. It creates a bad reputation for that person and causes poor customer service because it is too much work for one person.
advice_management: When doing layoffs, strongly consider shuffling the work of those who were laid off. If you overload your best employees, they will leave.

Throughout my career I worked with Cisco employees and I was always impressed with their abilities.  When given the opportunity to come and work here I came with high expectations of myself and Cisco.  Cisco has not disappointed!    
Cisco provides an amazing work environment with the perfect work-life balance.  the opportunity to learn is off the charts.  You can push yourself in any direction you choose, be it technical, project based or managerial.  If you are willing to put in the time, the training is made available to you for self development.
cons: As it is a large company at times internal divisions can make it difficult to align resources but once you find your way around people are always willing to engage

The company is a tech giant, and is also focused on innovation and community engagement. There is a focus on developing women in leadership roles and connecting women within the organization

many different opportunities.

advice_management:
Need to have stable roadmap for any project investment.
I was affected by LR in August 2016 and I left in October. I was hired back in a month for new project. As per my manager and director SVP was very interested in investing in this project. However, project was closed in 5 months in May 2017 LR. Week before SVP was convinced to continue efforts in this project and still it was plugged off to keep numbers up for next quarter.

summary: "Women at Cisco - how is it to work at Cisco"
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for less than a year
pros: Balanced work life, flexibility in hours and working from home
cons: Limited opportunity for promotion, still long ways for women to get considered for managerial jobs. Low rate of sponsorship vs men and getting support needed to move up.
advice_management: Women who are high performers need sponsorship, not mentorship. Women are overlooked even when high performers and have leaderships skills. Men project more confidence and position themselves better even when less qualified. It's a known fact which every one needs to be aware of and pay attention to when considering women for leadership roles. Women need support via sponsorship, not mentorship.

summary: "Once upon a time, it was great."
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Depending on team, flexible work options especially remote work. Decent benefits but health benefits keep getting chipped away more and more every year. You can become a real pro at giving PowerPoint presentations. If "fun" and "culture" is learning how to play politics and reduce your conscience to,the level of betraying your mother without blinking in the name of corporate ladder climbing, then welcome to Cisco!
cons: Favoritism, nepotism, cronyism is rampant. The People Deal employee review system is arbitrary, vague and not defined and it opens the door for management to play favorites. Survival of the fittest political player is the name of the game. No real innovation, just acquiring smaller companies now and not successfully integrating them.
advice_management: Too many layers of management. Too many VPs reporting to Sr. VPs and too many people managers who should not be managing people. Too concerned about the stock price instead of customer satisfaction.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Best place for networking
cons: Networking Product teams don't work on bleeding edge cloud/distributed system technology

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than a year
pros: Strong company with a great work environment, very talented people I get to work with on a regular basis across different groups and departments, and great partners and customers who make what I do on a daily basis matter.  New leadership to virtual sales organization has brought some good change to processes and systems to help us do our jobs more effectively.  In virtual sales, the training program sets you up to be successful in your role.
cons: Virtual Sales org is much more than a 9-5 job.  Most people that are putting effort into their jobs spend a minimum of 10-15 hours a week working outside of the office.  It is strongly encouraged (or required if you want to do well long term) you put in the hours at home.   I work 55+ hours a week, myself and many of my coworkers have no problem with this.  What is a problem is that we work 15 hours at home during the course of a week, but in exchange there is no flexibility in the 40 hours per week they require us to be in the office.
advice_management: Virtual Sales is a very talented organization within Cisco with a history of success.  Treat the team as adults, and give back flexibility.  It does not even have to be a guaranteed work from home day once a week, but a simple as i've got these 10 things to get done at home that i've been putting off because i'm at work until 6 and then come home and work some more, so i'm going to head out an hour early to get some errands done before i'm back to working when i get home...  The strong players will continue to put extra hours a week, does not matter if they are in the office or not.  If people take advantage or abuse the system, then address those people individually, take it away from those who abuse, or move them out of Cisco (it would be a good way to weed out the weaker links and to keep a strong hard working team bringing continued results to virtual sales.)

summary: "Cisco is a wonderful place to work and wants more diversity--apply now!!"
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than a year
pros:
1. Benefits are awesome: 10K tuition p/year, matching 401k packages, 1 week to volunteer for a nonprofit of your choice (fully paid and Cisco will donate $ 10 p/hour worked to the nonprofit), San Jose gym is top notch, and much more! 
2. People are great and highly collaborative. I can't speak for every single person at Cisco but I can say that almost everyone at Cisco is always willing to help a peer! 
3. Great programs to get involved--Conexion, Connected Black Professionals, Men for Inclusion, Connected Asian Affinity Network, and Pride are just some of the excellent programs and groups we have. This is a really great way to network with people all over the company!
4. Great work/life balance. Need to work from home? Work with your manager and if they're okay, then life is made easy for you! 
5. Exciting place to work in terms of the industry! Working in tech is fun and exciting!
cons:
1. There isn't much diversity in Engineering or IT but Cisco is actively working on attracting diverse talent 
2. Cisco is HUGE and it is easy to get lost in a 73K+ employee company. The way to navigate is participate in the Employee Resource Organizations and subscribe to mailers that have events!
advice_management: I would advise management to continue doing their best and encourage people to be their best!

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Being a large company means you have good access to resources as long as your BU is profitable. Compensation is good under the same conditions.
cons: Too much infighting, lack of leadership at upper levels to resolve conflicts, project and project managers are difficult to engage, continual drift of positions to international locations.
advice_management: Fix the environment where it feels teams are in conflict, hire and maintain strong leaders, don't chase every new trend and burn through cash buying startups you don't know how to integrate into the company, Get marketing and project managers to engage with all the teams. engineers can't develop what the market demands if they don't know what the market is demanding.

job_title: Current Employee - Senior Manager, Product Management
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros:
Cisco is a great company, it empowers and give employees the freedom to deliver to their full potential. It is a company that is constantly looking for excellence.
It is a great diverse place. As Hispanic/Latino, I feel my unique values are not only welcome but even encouraged. It is a true global company. I am part of Conexión, Cisco's Hispanic/Latino ERO, We help Cisco to hire and retain the best Latino talent as well as helping the Latino Community at Cisco and in our neighborhoods. 
As a large and successful corporation, benefits are very good and employees are given the necessary resources to succeed. We work on the newest technologies, with modern processes that help Cisco (and us as employees) to stay ahead of the curve!
cons: Change is always good, but sometimes there are collateral impacts of the way Corporate America is handled, basically with a clock that shakes every quarter. Cisco being a large corporation is no exempt from that, with constant role and leadership changes as well as more than desired limited restructurings. This might affect your career if you don't know how to deal with constant change.
advice_management: Better tracking of past performance of employees. With constant changes to the competitive environment, then to internal organizations (and new leadership), it might be hard for employees to adapt and excel in an ever changing environment.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 3 years
pros: You get to work with smartest people in the tech world, you never spend a day without learning something new, excellent work-life balance, potential to grow all the time,  superb benefits
cons: I am surrounded by great individuals, so i cant think of any negative.
advice_management: Management always strives to be the best in the industry, countless trainings, off-site meetings, given chances to individuals to grow and so on. My managers are always there for me, that i am very grateful for. Please keep up the great work. Keep the Cisco Culture exemplary

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Access to technology. There are a lot of good people within the company.
cons: Your happiness and future within the company depends heavily on your team. Mid-level managers are constantly fighting for funding and attention from higher ups. Your future will be largely determined by their success or failure.
advice_management: Semi-regular layoffs are inadvertently cannibalizing good people from the organization. Find another way to trim the dead weight. Stop buying companies and products that you do not intend to support.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 3 years

cons: Many teams are not aware of the adoption motion and not fully bought in, yet. Change will come with time. Process sometimes gets in the way of the larger picture.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 5 years

cons: As technology is always changing, it is sometimes a lengthy process to implement change as with any large company. However, it does get done through proper follow up, ownership and leadership.
advice_management: Continue to provide the proper tools that allows us to me successful.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Really enjoyed working in security sales at Cisco. Positive but intense work environment. Teams that want to do right by the customer.
cons: The security sales leadership turns over every 12-18 months. This creates direction instability that shows itself at every level of the organization. When the leadership is good, it's good. Every other turn they promote someone from a new acquisition (IronPort, Sourcefire) and it's a friggin mess.
advice_management: Stay the course. Promote from within. Leverage creative input from outside but groom your security execs the same way you groom core team leadership.

summary: "Inconsistent Culture, But Opportunity for Work/Life Balance"
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros:
Generally, the people are friendly and smart.  It's been that way since I started over a decade ago.  The pay is good, benefits are good, and in many areas of the company, you can arrange your working time around your life/kids.

The Hispanic/Latino group - Conexion - tries to create a sense of community, encouragement and support among the Latino employee base.
cons:
There are a lot of sub-cultures within Cisco, making it very difficult to work cross-functionally.  Some groups are punctual, data driven, their word is their bond.  Others are undisciplined, political, unreliable.  

When John Chambers was CEO, we used to talk about the Cisco family, and our mission: changing the way the world lives, works, plays, and learns.  More recently, it doesn't seem we talk about that anymore.  There's less talk about the family, and we lay hundreds of people off every 6 months.
advice_management: Apply the lessons being given by the guest speakers like Simon Sinek who teach us about building great teams.  Improve the ability of managers to manage people instead of just the technology and processes.  Find a way to unify and inspire the old timers again.  We see the new hires excited, but many veterans are jaded.

summary: "Good company that must prioritize hiring top talent and reducing layoffs"
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Industry leader for 20+ years, Cisco manages to re-invent itself during market transitions, leaving competitors in the dust. Plenty of challenging work, you're surrounded by strong talent willing to collaborate in cross-functional projects to achieve goals. The complete compensation package & benefits seem better than industry average. Cisco manages finances as I do: Being frugal and debt free. The company has an enormous amount of cash available to survive tough times and take advantage of acquisition opportunities.
cons: More political and more turf wars than it used to be. Still a good place compared to other companies though. No job security, more layoffs than similar companies - that's the price you pay for being a large company that must move fast through market transitions. Cisco is quick to let go of investments that aren't paying off and lay off people to cut costs when the quarter didn't go as expected.
advice_management: Layoffs may cut costs, but also scare people away. Not a good thing when Cisco hasn't appeared on the top 50 companies to work for in a long time (probably for that same reason). Leaders must prioritize attracting the best talent in the industry and find ways to reduce layoffs. Cisco used to pride itself as a company that hires the top 5%. That's when Cisco consistently appeared on the top 5 places to work in the nation. Cisco dropped off the top 50 companies to work for many years ago. The best talent graduating from schools don't even know who is Cisco. New hires are usually those that didn't get a job with Google, Apple or Facebook; and they come into the company nervous about layoffs.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
- Great exposure to global business
- Flexible work schedule
- Decent work-life balance
cons:
- "Limited Restructuring" in 2017 meant 16% of workforce or roughly 15 to 20 thousand people looking for new work. 
- "Limited Restructuring" always looming overhead with disregard to performance..it's all about reducing expenses to make shareholder price so if you perform well and make a decent salary, get ready to be "impacted" at some point. 
- Incredibly challenging for Cisco to make necessary changes and implement solutions quickly due to size and complexity of organization
advice_management: Be more transparent in your strategy. Execute to the strategy. Quit terminating your workforce on an annual bases. It's oppressive and your losing great talent to competition.

job_title: Current Employee - Virtual Sales Account Manager
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
Great Benefits
Talented Team
Strong Products
Market Leader
cons:
Work Life Balance
Very High Goals
Extremely Political
Nepotism
Poor Management Strategy In Our Segment
New "Collaborative" Environment has us packed like sardines and is VERY loud

Over the last 18 months there has been major changes in Cisco as a whole.  Some of this change is for the good.  Especially our moving to more of a licensing model.  The main issue is that goals have shot through the roof and the culture has been hit drastically.  

Prior to these changes we had the freedom to work in an atmosphere that promoted and strong work/life balance and a culture that was second to none.  Our team was one of the most successful in all of Cisco and you could not find a person on our team that was unhappy with the culture/environment.  Now it's hard to find someone that wouldn't jump ship if the opportunity presented itself.  

As for goals, the first few years of my tenure with Cisco our uplifts year over year ranged from 12% - 20% which, dependent on territory, gave everyone the opportunity to be successful.  My personal goals for the last couple years have exceeded 50% year over year growth and I know of teammates who's goals have exceeded 80%.   When your OTE (On Target Earnings) are based on a 50/50 salary to commission structure, this kills your income.  My understanding is one person on our entire team of 25 that is on target to hit goals this year.
advice_management:
Cisco for years has promoted publicly the concept of Changing the Way We Live, Work, Play and Learn.   The concept of being able to have a work life balance and how this was a priority shared by Cisco.  To have the opportunity to be productive from anywhere at anytime.  The idea of trusting it's employees to work from home or anywhere for that matter.  And in return the employees trusting Cisco to make decisions that were in the best interest of the company and themselves.

It has become obvious that the decisions being made are no longer taking into account the people who are the backbone of Cisco.

summary: "Top Flexibility but Culture Politics Determines What You Work On"
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for less than a year
pros: Top Flexibility, okay pay (below avg)
cons: Culture Politics Determines What You Work On. Especially if you are a minority (not Indian or White), there seem to be cultural "cliques" that play into favorability. In addition, Cisco's political neutrality generates a lack of culture, particularly for younger employees seeking companies that stand for something
advice_management: Focus on business AND culture change - one will die without the other and we don't focus enough on culture. The youth are the future of Cisco, many of our employees will be retired in 20 years (and the majority of our leadership), and we need to innovate for the future - not the present

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Everyone in my area is very passionate about the product and I enjoy my immediate peers and folks I work with.  I am able to take pride in the immediate work I do. It is a good company starting out from college as they allow very gradual ramp-ups for their new hires.
cons: The benefits are ok, but the pay is definitely no where near comparable to the rest of the Bay area. Cisco prides themselves on their work life balance, but since joining I've always had a minimum of 3 nights per week where I'm pulled into night meetings. The Upper management is horrible and doesn't seem to care about their employees at all - they all seem incredibly out of touch with everything.
advice_management: Take pride in your employees and try to encourage each person's individual talents. Try to find more ways for employees to actually get some free nights so they don't feel like they're always-on.

summary: "If you work hard you will get rewarded."
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than a year
pros:
I'm very passionate about security and I get to work for one of the work leaders in field. I feel like the work I do is actually making a difference in the world. I enjoy the work that I do on a daily basis.

I'm very well paid. My base salary is very competitive. The bonus percentages are very high at Cisco. I've had double digit percentage raises and double digit percentage bonuses in the last year.

I get to work from home multiple days per week.

There are a lot of smart people who can do really cool things.

My office gets free lunch, free coffee (good coffee too), free drinks (red bull) at the vending machines, all snacks at the vending machines only cost a quarter.

I could wear a t-shirt, gym shorts and sandals to work at my office and nobody would care. Almost no dress code at all.

The office is very nice, clean, etc.

Good benefits like healthcare, vision, dental, etc. They also have stock options that are good.
cons:
Politics regarding acquisitions and merging teams can get in the way of doing actual work or event prevent projects from being able to be completed at all.

I can't bring my dog to work anymore.

That's about it for complaints.
advice_management: See cons section.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros:
It's a large company, so the scenario in different business units and teams can be wildly different.  In a long career at Cisco (1996-2015), I worked in many different teams.    With only a small number of exceptions, the colleagues and teams I worked with were excellent, motivated and professional.
When working onsite (San Jose), promotion path was good, career aspirations were well supported.  
Lots of money - good pay relative to industry, good benefits.
Fascinating, hard work.
Generally a lot more openness, and startup feel than you'd expect at such a large company.
cons:
Management became a bit top- and middle- heavy.  Large company problems, projects would be cancelled (usually justifiably!) later than they should have been.  Some business functions that fell across Business Units would be hard to co-ordinate.
Only ran into 2-3 bad apples in almost 20 years, which is great ratio, but it was impossible to get rid of them even though they were well identified as such.
Standard big company demotivational stuff.   But less than you'd expect at such a large company.
advice_management: Can't comment (been a while since I worked at Cisco).

Great work culture and flexibility especially work from home is very convenient.
Lots of interesting problems to work upon so you can always keep yourself busy.
cons: Not any cons that I can think of.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than a year
pros: The work life balance at Cisco is incredibly unique. All you need is your laptop and wifi and you can work wherever you'd like (in most cases, some functions do not have complete flexibility). I live thousands of miles from my family & friends, but Cisco encourages me to go home and visit whenever I'd like, without having to take any time off. I can only imagine how wonderful this flexibility will be when I'm a mother some day. I've had numerous coworkers stay home with a sick child or take some time out of the day to go pick up their kids from school. Cisco supports it all. It would be extremely difficult to leave and lose all this flexibility. I plan to stay here as long as possible.
cons: Nothing sticks out that is any different than working at any other company. Typical downsides of being in a business environment.
advice_management: Keep putting your employees first, and people will continue to want to come work here.

summary: "Great when and where you find the freedom to work"
main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than a year
pros:
Initially after we were acquired, we were hopeful about finally having the stability to continue working on our technology with the resources of a bigger company. Cisco was pretty good about leaving us alone for the first little bit, but the corporation has got to corporate at some point you know.

The benefits were solid, fair and generously doled out on regular schedules. This is a great place to maintain and build with a moderate pace of progress professionally.
cons: Cisco as a company isn't really doing anything innovative, and really feels like a stagnant hardware company trying to pivot into software in many ways.
advice_management: Hold on to the voices that are working towards change and listen to them.

Decision making is very slow at the top causing it to continue to trail in technology and adapting to today's tech business needs.  Only the big mature business units are able to succeed.  There is a great lack of accountability and responsibility due to politics.
advice_management: Keep pruning internal fat, especially internal administrative and operational organizations which continually hold back development teams.  Good processes and practices for building solid businesses have been replaced with process for process sake.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Specific teams have great people, I'm sure this is true of any company. Really good work-life balance since virtual culture was embraced long ago. Hiring from outside brings fresh perspectives.
cons: Lack of diversity, and a diversity office/leaders that has little idea of what it does but catch phrases that make it appear as if it's doing something. Should be entirely revamped with people who truly care about diverse workforces and perform. Ongoing policy of laying off an older workforce. It's sad to see great partners being let go over the past 4-5 years. Migrating internal technologies get launched too often, right when we get a grip on the one that was just launched.
advice_management: Layoffs cut the company's intellectual property since they focus on older workers with experience and know how. Treat teams equally based on performance and balance promoting from within with hires from outside.

Some managers sometimes do not share  whats going on better. Mentor ship in my case was minimal, and not conducive to success. But I know that this is an exception.
advice_management: New employees from other companies, bring a fresh perspective. Currently there seems to be a lot of talk of innovation and evolution, but still stuck with the older employees paradigm of doing business the old way.  Its evolved from a hardware world to Software defined, cloud world. Cisco needs to get there fast.
