summary: "Had good experiences during internships, but full-time is a different story"
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than a year
pros:
+ Internships were enjoyable because I got to work on small but interesting projects in an easygoing environment. That said, compensation is very much below average compared to other tech companies in Silicon Valley.

+ Work/life balance is good. Rarely is anyone ever expected to work more than 40 hours per week. This might depend on your group though.

+ They are making a good effort to update their offices in San Jose from the old cubicle farms to the newer open-floor setups with free amenities (coffee/tea/espresso, snacks, etc.).

+ They do not skimp on developer machines and peripherals like monitors, headphones, etc.
cons:
- Very bureaucratic, lots of reorgs and movement at the middle and upper levels (e.g. new directors, mid-level managers, upper-level managers).

- The pay is below average in comparison to other tech companies in the Bay Area. Promotions/raises seem to be few and far between. It will soon be my third year here, and all of my developer peers have also complained about slow growth within the company.

- Due to the bureaucratic nature of the company, communication among the many groups is slow and sporadic.

- It may be different for other groups, but there seems to be a general lack of expertise when it comes to software development best practices:
-- Everything is hacked together
-- Quantity of features and speed of development > quality and stability
-- There are no design/architecture discussions that include all of the developers ("design" of the product usually happens as informal conversations between mid-to-senior level developers, without including the newer/entry-level developers). These discussions are ad-hoc, informal, and often not even documented.
-- No standards followed for releases/deployment
-- Very little effort spent on documentation of anything
-- We are one of the many groups that tries to follow Agile/Scrum, but since we don't follow a lot technical practices that actual make Agile work (e.g. unit tests, code reviews, decent documentation, reasonably-sized & well-defined user stories, etc.), it isn't working as it should. The end result is shoddy code and constantly accumulating technical debt.

- People in non-technical roles (middle managers and product owners) push for features and user stories without really knowing what they want. User stories are often a terse title and an empty description (no behavioral/functional specifications, no summary, no consideration for inter-dependencies among other user stories).

- Projects often lack clear direction. This point applies to my group and our project, but I think it might apply to other groups as well. There are many technical leaders in our group, but for our project, we lack a TRUE lead technical architect who:

1) has a clear vision of what the product should be like
2) plans architecture & development tasks for the group
3) mentors less experienced developers
4) maintains standards on code quality and development processes

Bottom line: If you're looking for a place to hone your technical skills and grow as a developer, look elsewhere. Some of the other reviewers who mentioned a culture of complacency absolutely hit the nail on the head. I have observed first-hand many times where our group has accepted mediocre work or shortcuts without hesitation "if it gets the job done," creating more technical debt. When developers ask for time to address technical debt, we are rebuffed by managers who claim that it is "good enough" and that we should focus on pumping out more features. If you stay here too long, your skills as a software developer will only continue to rust.
advice_management:
Invest in your developers and encourage them to have high standards. Maintain those standards yourself, and don't ever let politics/pressure from above compromise the quality of your product.

For each project, appoint a true technical leader that everyone can follow, and encourage senior developers to mentor less experienced developers.

Cultivate a culture of software craftsmanship by respecting software development best practices. Raise the difficulty of the hiring bar, i.e. don't hire blindly based on a person's pedigree and evaluate each candidate based on their skills today, not what they accomplished many years ago.

The companies that Cisco acquired are mostly successful ones with talented engineers and development processes that work (otherwise they wouldn't show up on Cisco's radar). We should be working more closely with them and learning from each other.

job_title: Current Employee - Senior Product Marketing Manager
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Interesting work and many very bright colleagues.  If you are in the right organization, the fast-paced leading edge work can be very energizing.  Many opportunities to learn and keep skills and knowledge current.
cons: The culture has shifted tremendously over the last 5 or 6 years and politics is rampant.  There is a systematic effort to get rid of older employees despite their qualifications.  Although there are some very good managers, there is an equal number of poor managers.  Too many shoot from the hip decisions being made.

summary: "You Can Grow, Reinvent Yourself, Create Your Best Ideas"
job_title: Current Employee - Senior Director Employee Experience & Communications
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Amazing, talented people with a passion and mission for changing the world. Culture that supports growth, reinvention, innovative ideas. A strong vision that places listening, partnerships and advocacy for the customer at the heart of everything we do.
cons: Yes- we're big but anyone who can connect/collaborate will thrive. Yes- we have too much process in places but anyone who is curious, respectfully disrupts and seeks constant improvement will be valued. Yes- change is constant here but leading companies transform with a purpose. And that's how we roll.
advice_management: People- their ideas, actions and values- make the things and relationships that make a company great. Never stop LISTENING to or ATTRACTING the best people. The best people produce the best results.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Very good work/life balance, and flexibility to work from home.  You are not tied to the clock as long as you show results. Lots of perks and Cisco branded freebies.  Great benefits.
cons: Don't feel the job security that I felt when I first started.  As technology changes and evolves, teams and priorities change = lots of lay offs.
advice_management: Maintain a balance between keeping long-time employees with hiring fresh grads. Being surrounded by people who have been at Cisco for many years is more motivating than being surrounded by a bunch of newbies (or contractors) who have less company loyalty.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Empowerment, many different business units, benefits
cons: Matrix Management, politics among acquired companies (corporate culture clash), marketing lacking clear goals, 6-month recurrent re-org cycle, easy to have all work and no life
advice_management: Try to minimize the impact each re-org has on the individual contributors.  At times, it felt like we had no connection to the new manager and were passed over for raises or promotions as a result.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Telework, customers, partners, global ops
cons: Internal politics, constant re-orgs and layoffs, passive aggressive corporate behavior
advice_management: Stop telling you experienced employees to leave the company, because we will go and join startups and you will need to pay us much more in the acquisition model than to retain good people with knowledge skills and expertise

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than a year
pros:
Work life balance is huuuuge with Cisco. Most non-engineering employees are completely free to work remotely. Cisco practices what it preaches by allowing employees to use webex and work from ANYWHERE. 

The pay. In general, Cisco pays in the 80th percentile so if you work their, it's difficult to leave for financial reasons
cons: Remote work has real downsides. If you're not in San Jose, exposure and career growth can be difficult. Engagement can be an issue when your only encounters with real life people come at starbucks
advice_management: Invest in culture outside of san jose.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
-Work from home.
-Flexibility in work hours 
-Tons on internal documents and repository given cisco is a pioneer in networking industry.
-Good Support Documentation.
-Better Technical Support than other vendors as per customer comments.
cons:
-Way too many frequent org. changes which makes you feel less motivated as this changes in no way benefits to a engineer but only management and business.
- Salary in Advanced Services is average which according to me is poor standard when compared to other big IT companies.
- Flexibility in work hours and work from home does not mean pay less. Actually you end up working more hours from home.
- Advanced services always have budget issues and there are tons of people to compete for promotions.
- Management need to make sure not to create same processes and giving it different names. It just confuses what model to follow.
- Too many processes are created by Directors/Managers just for the heck of to show management is doing something better in terms of time management and fast learning for engineers to come up to speed.
-You get trained but never implement all of what you learn and hence another waste of dollars on training.
- Way too many people out there in the company wanting to prove themselves. 
-You get promotions based on amount of years spent at the company and not based on your achievements. 
- They will make you do the same work as the done by higher grade people and still less pay.
advice_management: Give more budget to Advanced Services and increase the pay for NCEs. Shame that in comparison to other IT companies Cisco does not pay better. All i hear from management is that cisco gives flexible work hours and less stress of which later is not true, I still work more than the regular work hours and stress at times. Try recognize the hard working engineer who actually achieves success for their customers and give them raise in salary rather than just going by the number of years of spent at cisco. Also, cisco advertises as ONE FAMILY, but in reality it is not 100% at the level and far from reality. Also please give some lab access to NCEs so that they can get hands on and can help answer customer questions , after all it is for Cisco business only.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Good salary, excellent benefits, bonus. Work from home friendly but that is going away. Most people friendly but such a big org mileage may very.
cons: Constant threat of layoffs, managers usually remote unengaged with staff, pretty cold about layoffs. Lots of offshore work taking USA jobs. Difficult to understand or communicate with co-workers because they do not know English very well. Required to work all nighters or face layoff. A very politically correct company.
advice_management: Help people impacted by layoff find other work at Cisco. Such a big company should have the resources to move people to other roles.

pros: Easy nice firendly useful awesome yep
cons: hard difficult pleasent no yes
advice_management: none

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Cisco pays pretty well and offers good flexibility and some perks, and some of the administrative things work surprisingly well for such a giant corporation.  Cisco does a lot of good work in the community and encourages staff to give back to various charities, etc. and does a good job of promoting mobility across job functions, etc.
cons: There is a constant threat of a "Limited Restructuring" - nearly every year, you will lose some colleagues if not your own job, which absolutely kills morale.  They make a lot of noise about how great their culture is - which if you have to say it so often, means it is likely not the case.  They can be completely tone-deaf, for example, scheduling all-hands, AMA-type town-hall meetings with execs on the same days they're laying off hundreds of people, making "The People Deal" complete BS.
advice_management: The effort to re-cast itself as a SW company is sensible, but it will require a better understanding of how that industry works.  Cisco got huge by selling technology everyone needed as the internet age grew, but that approach will not work now.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than a year
pros: Great people, great team, the best place to work!
cons: Can't really think of anything.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Great products, positive corporate culture, corporate giving in community, lots of talented people and great support from colleagues, ability to work remotely, good employee development opportunities
cons: lack of visibility into requirements for promotions, very difficult to move up in the organization

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Good benefits, good products, brand recognition, global opportunities.
cons: Slow to provide salary increases once hired, yearly layoffs, management is often more technical and lack people skills.
advice_management: Offer yearly salary increases.  Train management to have better people skills.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Amazing people and partners.  Good compensation and benefits.  Work from home allows good work life balance.  Although work is on 24/7
cons: No one is safe.  Annual and sometimes semi annual layoffs with no way to predict if your on the chopping block other than being over 40 and at the mid-top of your pay grade.  There is no loyalty anymore to its employees.  People put in 10-15-20 years and get a 30 min call with their manager and they are let go.  Gone are the days that John Chambers used to say that he wanted people to retire from Cisco... tell their kids and grandkids how they loved working at Cisco.  Now its all about the shareholders.
advice_management: Hiring "Early in career" maybe cheap in the short run but inexperience and young does not make for a success enterprise class solution.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Respected name, large company, smart people, flexible work environment
cons: In decline - layoffs regularly, struggling to find strategic direction with the commoditization of hardware, very political environment
advice_management: Embrace the cloud movement, push investments in IOT to the edge, reward the folks who can deliver outcomes, not powerpoint presentations

summary: "Decent Company in the middle of a transformation"
job_title: Current Employee - Senior Software Engineering Manager
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Good work life balance, very wide breadth of scope for engineering
cons: Politics, Legacy Business, Brand Value, Management and Board is very C-Suite Friendly, Too much redundancy at Director and higher levels
advice_management: Be Bold and let engineering take tough decisions, ensure pyramid scheme don't form in the organization

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Good Benefits, lots of flexibility in the working environment.  I worked for the company for 13 years with school age children.  The flexibility that there technology and culture provides for working remotely made being a working mother so much easier.   Interesting work, even though internally we might feel like we aren't very progressive, most of the company is way ahead of what is happening in most companies.  Great work experience.
cons:
While the culture is improving, it still has many challenges.  Way too many people that are in leadership positions that shouldn't be. They think that bullying their employees is fine as long as they can effectively suck up to senior management.   Lots of implicit bias in the organization, and women definitely suffer from the classic double-bind:  if you are decisive you aren't likable, and it stalls your growth.   Continual churn of executives creates whiplash in employees, as a new executives come in with new plans, throw the baby out with the bath water, and then move on when they figure out there ideas aren't so great after all. 
Worklife balance is only achievable if you know how to set boundaries.
advice_management:
1.  Stop letting the jerks in management get away with it.  Really, it just hurts the company. Even if those jerks are your friends.  
2. Stop promoting people who make upper managements' life easier, but make employees lives miserable.  You've been talking about fixing the management culture at the company for over 10 years.  It really isn't that hard.  Reward good managers, instead of it being an optional behavior.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
Respectful culture
Great Work-life balance
Inclusion and Diversity
cons:
Issues that are typical of large enterprises: too many overlaps, slow, talents are lost in shuffles.
Design by committees
advice_management: Digitalization needs to happen fast, can't remain a slogan or slide.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Well paid, great benefits, RSU's if you can get them.
cons: getting too big, politics, not nimble anymore

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Flexible work hours and location, ability to contribute and make an impact, ability to work with different cultures around the globe, good benefits package
cons: Networking industry is tough at the moment, with fierce competition among incumbents and disruptive smaller companies, software-defined everything is eating away at traditional product-based sales so the need for more creative networking solutions is paramount
advice_management: Flexibility in work hours and locations makes working at Cisco great, and is a unique selling point in the market place versus the competition.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years

summary: "Worst company to work for especially for older employees"
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Can't think of anything good about working for Cisco now, though they used to be a great company ~15 years ago
cons: Treat employees like garbage. Recognition depends on who you know in the senior management chain not how well you do your job. Target older (50+ years old) employees for layoff.
advice_management: Watch for class action lawsuit!

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than a year
pros: I enjoy having the option to work from home a couple of days a week. The benefits offered are pretty nice, but not unique in Silicon Valley. I enjoy having lots of opportunities to volunteer time and donate to causes I care about.
cons: There are constant layoffs and reorgs, and I don't fully feel that I can trust management. Conversion from contract worker to full-time is either glacially slow or impossible unless you have connections in high places. You have to play at politics too often to keep your position and be online constantly, sometimes sacrificing a healthy work/life balance.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Smart people, decent pay and benefits.
cons: Very siloed positions, most people are under-employed since very talented people are hired into job silos that limit the full expression or development of their skills.  There are constant layoffs, accompanied by all of the unhealthy cultural by-products that come with layoffs: paranoia, lack of motivation, managers pitching smoke-and-mirror programs since you will never be held accountable to deliver based on the constant reorganizations and priority shifts, lack of trust.  Very talented senior leaders who have the confidence to speak the truth, name the dysfunction for what it is, and try to be agents for change are always the ones to announce they are 'pursuing other opportunities' (aka, forced out), leaving the sub-par leaders to run the ship.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 3 years
pros: C-level management has done great work to change the brand from a just networking company to a services company. Alot of work is required, change in mindset, but C-level execs can def. achieve it. Work is challenging and people are fun and friendly.
cons: Employees can be very laid back at times, and, of course politics and layers of un-needed management.
advice_management: Get rid of politics and streamline process for promotion and growth.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Lot of options to choose, which field you want to work in.
cons: Less overall compensation, and slow growth.
advice_management:
Please have a good vision and stick to it.
Don't keep hiring and firing people.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems  for less than a year
pros: Great culture, pay, benefits and people
cons: Lack of flexibility when it comes to work schedule.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than a year
pros: Focus on culture and adapting to a changing, challenging environment
cons: Not changing fast enough to survive and prosper.
advice_management: Cisco is becoming a cloud company, as it should. And I admire them for treating veteran employees pretty well. But some are simply hanging on until they retire. Some need to be retired and new ideas brought in to adapt to the new cloud world.  The approaches and tools of the 1990s are no longer working.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for less than a year
pros:
You get the sense that cisco really cares about their employees and at the individual contributor level they will provide lots of flexibility (no strict 9-5 hours, possibility to work remote, etc) to ensure that employees feel comfortable and valued.

Cisco has been around for a while and is good place to learn and grow as a professional engineer at a large company.
cons: It will depend on your team assignment but the overall atmosphere at cisco is geared towards older and more established professionals. As a fresh grad straight out of college it can be a bit of a culture mismatch, but everyone is still incredibly nice and easy to work with.

summary: "Great place to work, but going through an identity crisis"
job_title: Current Employee - IT Business Systems Analyst
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Excellent benefits, flexible working from home using WebEx, and transitioning into a more competitive relevant company. It's also easy to find new opportunities and grow within the company. There are many folks, especially more middle-aged folks who've been with the company for multiple years and who maintain and excellent work/life balance.
cons: Cisco is massive and there'll be lots of big corporate headaches with communication. You'll find dozens of teams working on similar things, but no centralized approach. This is getting better with reorgs and aligning to the industry, but still a big issue.
advice_management: Recruitment and retaining new grads is critical for Cisco to continue remaining popular and relevant. It's common for those to join for a couple of years and quickly find new jobs. This leaves a gap of knowledge and forces Cisco to rely more on vendors to be subject matter experts. Please find constructive ways to recruit, keep talent, and provide more negotiating and competitive counteroffers.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years

- Work/Life balance
- Great benefits (total package: vacation time from day one, health, dental, vision, life, etc. insurance coverage, employee discounts for lots of things, annual bonuses, & the list goes on :-).
cons:
- Very challenging to get promoted to the next grade level just based on performance (even for top performers), which is what you're told will get you to the next grade level.
- Salary low as compared to other Information Technology companies (though total compensation package is very good).

cons: Quotas - Cisco is making it harder and harder to be successful  (make money) - YoY quota growth is high in an increasingly commoditized, software-driven world; Annual restructuring is distracting and unsettling.  Cisco's size.  (Yes, its strength is also its weakness.)
advice_management: Get real when it comes to quota growth...  There are "cherry" areas that are greatly overachieving, while the mainstays/core technologies are struggling.

job_title: Current Employee - Senior Manager, Product Management
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Great co-workers, great benefits, good pay for higher level grades.
cons: Current leadership is lacking.  Executive leadership team has no real focus growing the business.  Most BUs are loosing market share and there are Layoffs nearly every quarter.
advice_management: Hit the reset button, bring in a real CTO, a real strategy leader and go after new market opportunities.  Focus on building a company and not cost cutting.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Flexible schedule, good medical and dental
cons: Long hours, little recognition, constant reorg, lots of layoffs, top heavy,
advice_management: Cut layers of unqualified management.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Excellent compensation/benefits for Silicon Valley employees; possibility to obtain exposure to a broad range of technologies and product development. Career development resources are available.
cons: Company has been going through a transitional period for the past 18 months.  This is something that has been very disruptive, with a reduction in workforce occurring approximately every 3-5 months.  Additionally, for the past 10 years, the Company has been in a mode of buying promising Companies in order to acquire new technologies or solutions, and then after about 2 or 3 years, shifting a chunk of software development resources offshore or in some cases to Canada -something that may be a concern depending on job role and department.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems  for more than 8 years
pros: Market leadership in most areas which is a good place to be as a marketer.  Despite weaknesses, many of Cisco's customer's have no real options other than Cisco.  High salaries/bonuses and good productivity tools.
cons: Leadership that's indecisive and often inept - certainly in Marketing. Chamber's departure was probably due but they've slipped since then. Strategy that's seldom articulately communicated.  Put's on a good face that they care about employees but it's a very low energy, poor people management environment.  They have a thing they call "the people deal."  Never really understood what that meant but the inside joke is that it means yearly layoffs, which is not a joke. No stock appreciation.
advice_management: Make sure you promote managers who actually can lead and motivate.  Do 360 reviews (of executives too) to find out who only manages up and layoff up-managers.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Big company and good culture
cons: Big company and not efficient
advice_management: average

job_title: Current Employee - Security Consulting Systems Engineer
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for less than a year
pros: Excellent manager, lots of professional growth opportunities, training is supported at all levels, great team environment, remote work, definitely feel like I am daily making a real impact.
cons: Some product QA issues are allowed to create false impressions with customers. Customer technical support can be a bit too much by the script resulting in long ticket queue times to resolution.
advice_management: Focus on tightening up the customer experience and stability of new releases.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than a year

summary: "rudderless & hopeless -- a colossal waste of motivated talent"
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
* Excellent technical talent
* Many excellent leaders
* Executive leadership cares about the quality of leadership & management (and appreciates the difference)
* Deep security awareness
* Ambitious people who want to make a difference
* Strong compensation possible for the lucky
cons:
* If you think of VSEM (vision, strategy, execution & measurement), the executive leadership seems to be focused on financial execution to the exclusion of all other concerns.  Short of the obvious need to diversify from the embattled networking equipment space, we have yet to hear a cogent vision or strategy from the ELT.
*  Constant squeezing of all groups to protect the dividend, frustrating the need of Cisco's varied businesses to grow at different paces
*  Fancy lip-service towards innovation (complete with voting competitions, &c.) but no executive buy-in towards actual innovation within its existing businesses
*  Cisco is swinging towards being a software company, but has almost no-one who knows how to build viable software businesses -- Cisco risks becoming an also-ran low-margin services business if this continues
*  Consistent, persistent fear of being laid off to protect the dividend completely saps morale and undercuts HR's efforts to ensure Cisco is a good employer (the constant threat of financially-driven layoffs terrifies our H-1B holders)
*  Executive focus seems concentrated on the few lines of business that can compensate for the networking business's lagging margins... to the detriment of any future businesses that might develop
*  Acquiring new businesses then requiring them grow while undercutting their OPEX and forcing them to take on Cisco-internal systems/practices that don't work for the acquired business
*  Laying off the sales organizations of businesses that are meeting Cisco's top-line margin requirements
advice_management:
*  If you're trying to turn Cisco into an Oracle-esque holding company where you no longer innovate, but instead wait to purchase other businesses, you should get out of those newly purchased businesses' way and let them operate.
*  You need to address employee's fear -- rank & file are losing confidence that Cisco is a place where excellent work will result in continued employment, much less career advancement
*  The statements that employees are disaffected & disconnected isn't cause to lay off more of them: it's the logical consequence of the fact that Cisco is no longer an organization where it feels safe to be employed
*  Stop eating your seed corn -- you're rapidly turning Cisco into HP
*  Cash-on-hand and dividend payments are not a substitute for future relevance

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
1. Remote work is the norm 
2. Even contractors are empowered to make big decisions
cons:
1. Unannounced layoffs are the new normal at Cisco ... literally every month there are big layoffs 
2. a large number of jobs at Cisco are going off-shore so be prepared to repeatedly prove that your skills cannot be outsourced without a serious loss to the product/team/bottom line
3. highly political organization & lots of disinformation ... assume you really do NOTknow what is going on even if you are being given information 
4. contractors are treated very poorly, even if they provide a big value add to the organization 
5. Cisco is in crisis ... there are re-orgs with alarmingly high frequency; this is to be expected with the massive changes brought in by Chuck.
advice_management: With such a high turnover, moral has really started to suffer.  I left Cisco in early 2017 because I no longer felt it was I had stability and was constantly looking for other jobs "just in case".  Also Cisco has lost its' ability to innovate without acquisitions and all the layoffs will compound problem because talented engineers are now departing.

3. Extremely inefficient meetings. Huge amount of time wasted in digressions from the main agenda. Infact some times the agenda is not even communicated before the meeting.
4. Complete lack of focus on individual contributor skill development and training. Individual is left to fend for him/herself.

1. Need to manage work projects such that team is more engaged, and not always in fire fighting mode. 
2. More communication and messaging which should be very customized and relevant to smaller groups. 
3. More training and support for talent development should be provided.
4. Meetings should have a agenda outline way BEFORE the meeting starts.

summary: "Been a great ride, but might be time for me to move on"
job_title: Current Employee - Technical Leader/Escalation Team Lead
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
I have been at Cisco for almost 2 decades and have been blessed with the opportunity to perform 7 different roles over that time. There is almost always a way to reinvent or morph yourself given the wide range of opportunities.

The compensation has been pretty fair for the past decade or so. It really helped that I've had some top-notch managers that have gone to bat for me with HR. My last two managers have been pretty awful, but *all* of the ones prior had my back and helped me grow my career... even if they knew it meant I'd move on to bigger and better things. I can't state that strongly enough. I have never been as happy with my immediate manager in any job as I have been at Cisco (save the past year or two).

Cisco prides itself on hiring the right folks - as anyone subjected to the myriad of interviews can attest - and I have to say they generally hit home runs. 90%+ of the people I work with have been excellent, self-starting, and knew their stuff - or learned it on-the-job and jumped right in.
cons:
I know that Stack Ranking gets a bum rap, but you know who really likes it?.. folks who rank well and bust their backsides to get there. With the move to "The People Deal" (still have no idea WTF that means), Stack Ranking went away - as did the RSUs. I get nearly 1/3 of my total compensation from RSUs, so these are the "golden handcuffs" that keep me here. No more RSUs, no more cuffs, perhaps time to look elsewhere.

Why leave? I have been on the cutting edge of new markets for Cisco for be better part of the last decade. These are places where they make big bets, but quickly grow into a bureaucratic model that sells its soul to the first customer to sign a PO, then slowly drown and sink as that customer (or customers) weigh us down and not pivot with the rest of the market.

As I look around the landscape and view Cisco's attempts to pivot to Cloud and recurring revenue models, it is very clear that they are not learning from these failures. They burn out or run off all of the folks who could help prevent the next failure, thus do not learn the lesson. Or, in other cases, they do not allow enough time to get things rolling. You basically have 3 years to be #1/2 in the market - or else. 

Reference the recent death of Intercloud as an example of what I mean. They committed $1 billion to the project, but had a massively flawed business model from the start. After all, who can compete with AWS when it comes to plain IaaS? They were far too late to bring the other table stakes bits that go along with that (VPNaaS, LBaaS, FWaaS, Big Data as a Service, etc). Many of those were just about to launch when they canned the entire engineering portion of the project. One of the major distractions - and reasons for the delay in getting that stuff in place - was being saddled with their two external partners. These partners contracted one thing, then asked for a wildly different deployment model or Roles and Responsibilities. These held back any further evolution and improvement of the platform. 

Don't get me wrong: We screwed up alot, too, but those early commitments killed our velocity and ability to pivot.
advice_management: Figure out what you want the company to be. If you are really committed to Cloud and a services-led model, understand these things take time. Don't pressure teams to get sales early. Yes, they have the resources of Cisco, but you can't have a startup-like group deliver at Cisco scale just because you don't want to wait for us to mature. Tossing cash at the issue isn't the answer (e.g.: Intercloud).

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Market leader and a lot of cash in the bank. Flexibility to work from home. Culture to care and help each other. There are many employee resources available. Global presence and connections.
cons: It's like a joke but this is not uncommon a SVP reports to another SVP under another SVP. You can imagine this only creates slowness, politics, and duplication. "senior executives" care only about their promotions and compensations.
advice_management: Slim down senior executive community and create more flat company. Seriously, we can create more innovation, move much faster, save a lot of money, and motivate hard working people!

advice_management: When buying companies don't add the additional overhead of Cisco executives and their entourage.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems
pros:
Flexibility, great benefits, competitive salary, positive work environment
Have worked at another company since leaving and realized how well Cisco takes care of their employees.  Current employees should be very thankful because the grass is definitely not greener on the other side.
cons: The area the company needs to focus on is laying off the employees who are not performing or are on performance improvement plans.  I saw a lot of very talented and intelligent employees with proven track records get impacted by the layoffs and noticed the under performing employees are still there.  They also need to spend some time focusing on the international employees as well.  I worked with a lot of international folks who were not performing but managed to not be impacted by the layoffs due to country laws.  The company really needs to take a closer look at that as well.
advice_management: Spend more time having meaningful 1 on 1 conversations with employees.  Understand that as a business leader/manager it is your job to do what is best for the business and at times that means managing people out of the company or realizing they are in the wrong job, but good for the company and helping them find a new home for themselves within the company.  Management needs to be accountable.  The company needs to do a better job of ensuring the right person, someone who has leadership skills and enjoys coaching and mentoring, is selected for leadership positions.  Being a manager needs to be taken very seriously.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Good benefits.  Flexible workplace is fantastic.  Depending on the team, great colleagues.
cons: Lots of talk, little want to actually change.  Toxic managers who are managers, not leaders and don't want others to succeed, only make their team look good.  Promotion of the best looking and non-team playing members.  Not really free to take risks, fail and learn.  Lots of bureaucracy, red tape, and processes slowing down decisions, etc. Lot more, "Tried and true, vs. innovate and new".
advice_management: Lead your people, stop managing.  Cut the red tape, listen to your team, truly listen.  Do what you say you will and have their backs for real.  Don't let it just be talk.

cons: Meetings. Meetings. Meetings. With no agendas. No accountability. Work falls on the base level employees. Tons of middle management bloat - expect 6-7 layers of management above you if you are a worker bee. Communication is not direct - expect every announcement to be lengthy, full of fancy words that run around the point.
advice_management: Be more direct and to the point with all methods of communication. Encourage reduction of meetings, or at clear agendas and action items. Reduce middle management. There should be less layers between senior management and base employees.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems
pros: Laser focus on customers-partners has always been embedded in the company's DNA.
cons: Constant layoffs-  dismissing senior technical talent who are loved by their customers  and/or are recognized in the industry; gross mis-steps in cloud;  a toxic environment of fear has set into various organizations because of these sudden dismissals especially when the company is profitable.  As one would assess a product for fair trade, I strongly believe the treatment of people should be a factor in determining whether or not one wishes to do business with the company. Should you work at the company -- go for a very very short ride only. As a shareholder - I am deeply concerned.
advice_management: When you agree to such dismissals: be an example and depart first and/or ask for volunteers transparently.  There is no People Deal -- it was broken sometime ago.  Wearing jeans-dancing in the corridor insults the very people you wish to attract and retain.  The company I once worked for has lost its way. Shame....

summary: "Was once a great IT department, not anymore due to a corrupt CIO."
main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
You get to work with greatly talented people. 
Flexible work arrangements are good.
cons: The leadership team in IT is corrupt starting with the CIO. People are promoted for the most vague reasons. The claim they act with integrity till you find family relatives of the CIO working in her reporting chain. She actually continued to manage family members, who benefitted financially from outsourcing deals even after moving to her role as COO under new CEO. The new CIO is one of her watchdogs, who also is known to promote people based on racial agenda. He has no achievements and just a talking head. It is still Jacoby in the house with G keeping the status quo. They witch hunted many good people managers who were forced to leave.
advice_management: Get rid of both the COO and CIO. Bring some of the great people managers who made this IT house great once.

pros: Fast paced.  Challenging.  Most finance people are very intelligent, knowledgeable and highly professional.  Teams typically are very collaborative and work to help all succeed.
cons:
You never know when Cisco will outsource your job, downsize or exit your business.  So all constantly worry when their last day will be.

Very little investment in training finance people.  Internal job rotation program is not actively managed well so movement is slow as people are afraid to change jobs for fear to lose their job.

Finance teams are a reporting function to enable management by numbers.  Finance organization needs to really and truly be value add to their business partners rather than managing their business partners like Monday morning quarterbacks.
advice_management: Value your finance teams by investing in them....in the United States

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Cisco placed a great deal of value on its culture. There has been massive change at the company in recent years, and whether the company will be able to re-create that amazing culture that it had for so many years, is still TBD.
cons:
Huge turn over in recent years. It might be a good thing for the company longer-term, but with so much change comes challenges. 

I think Cisco needs to focus on developing better people managers. That goes hand-in-hand with a great culture and that is where I think they lost their way in recent years.
advice_management: Return to that great culture that set Cisco apart from other tech companies.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
I decided to wait almost a year after leaving the company before posting a review.  The primary reason being is that when you decide to leave an organization it is usually because there is something there that isn't aligning with you or what you want anymore however, the grass is not always greener someplace else.  This has been my experience.  In fact, the appreciation I have for the company has grown so much in my time away that I would really like to return.

The company truly believes on promoting within and as an employee you are encouraged to grow your career within the organization and learn new skills by taking different positions.  Benefits are excellent.  Cisco is the industry leader for networking and now cloud.  It is sometimes easy to forget that on the daily grind but you are working for the company that everyone looks to for network and infrastructure standards.  Culture within the business units managing product lines give you a lot of freedom to be innovative and creative in your approach to your role.  In most cases you are given a fair amount of autonomy and control over how you do your job provided that it aligns with the strategic objectives.  Benefits, 401k match, RSUs and ESPP are amazing.  And while the salaries aren't the top of the industry, they are above market and pretty competitive.
cons:
Cisco can be a machine.  There isn't an overt demand for all of your time (even the time outside of work) but more of a subtle, slight encouragement to always be on.  If you are not careful, you will live, sleep and eat Cisco 24x7.  Don't get me wrong, this is 100% a choice and if you are aware of this subtlety in the culture it is very easy to set appropriate boundaries that will be respected by the company and leadership team.

If you don't like where you are in Cisco or what you are working on, give it 6 months because you will be reorg'd.  While it is sometimes necessary to realign the company to meet competitive threats or market demands, reorganizing the company once a year is excessive and tends to create a distrusting environment for the rank and file which makes being a leader in the organize challenging.  There is a loss of momentum and motivation that occurs a few months before and a few months after reorgs so this leaves the company being effective at delivery and execution only about 70% of the time.

While Cisco attracts some bright, motivated people the truth of the matter is you are either cut out for the company and its culture or you're not.  If you aren't it will be painfully obvious to you and those around you.  Sadly as a leader it is hard to cut dead weight from the team and the only really accepted way is via layoffs, which is why the company reorgs once a year despite the company line about the reorgs.
advice_management:
In my time at Cisco I was a part of 3 different and distinct business units.  I enjoyed working for each of them and found that I was able to contribute value in every role I held.  What was painfully obvious to me was that the company is (or was) going through a bit of an identity crisis.  Consumer vs no consumer.  Social media vs no social media.  AWS like cloud offering vs Cisco cloud offering.

My advice to the leadership team is this.  We (Cisco for life) are *Cisco*.  *We* develop the standard for networking, infrastructure and cloud.  *We* are the industry leaders in our segment.  *We* stand a cut above and make no apologies for it.  Own being Cisco.  We don't need to compete with Apple, Facebook, Google, or Amazon.  *We* don't chase our competitors.  They chase us.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Solid benefits, good pay.  You'll meet a lot of good people.
cons: Management is weak.  Promotion from within is very much based on social connections not necessarily earned in every case.  Those promoted are not trained in managing people nor are they educated on company policy and process so when direct reports go to them for help it is seldom given.  The annual layoffs are unfortunately required as the company is poorly equipped to manage the bottom 10% out of the company, again, due to poorly trained managers and a weak performance management process.  I left on my own for a promotion but more importantly to feel valued, challenged and to get away from a really arrogant and incompetent management structure. I could have stayed and had the easiest pay check in the world but I respect my capabilities more than being a guy that fits the suit.
advice_management: Truly get respect for the individual down and if someone is not a good fit, move them to where they can contribute or move them out.  If you don't start truly managing the company, you will go the way of the typewriter.

cons: Difficult time transitioning to a software / as a service company. Being left behind by big 5 (Facebook, Amazon, Apple, Google, Microsoft) in terms of setting the Cloud / Networking direction of the future. Revolving door of executives focused more on their own politically driven advancement than setting up the company for long term success.Employees are burned out from the yearly purge of employees at the end of the fiscal year
advice_management: Need to make some big bets ($10B+ opportunities) before you fall too far behind and become HP/IBM.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years

cons: Culture of layoffs every year is always a worry.  Its always stated as something that won't be constant but always it.   Promotions now heavily favor women and is unfair to men.   Good if you are a woman.  Health insurance benefits not as good as Microsoft and other tech companies.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems  for more than 10 years
pros:
- The people are incredibly sharp and supportive (with a few exceptions). 
- Pockets of leadership are outstanding. 
- The benefits are second to none. Good restricted stock options, 401K, ESPP.
- Teleworking option - allows for better work / life balance (sort of - see below)
cons:
- ENDLESS meetings. Back-to-back-to-back...Think 8 solid hours starting at 6 AM. 
- It's great that so many of the employees have the flexibility to be remote. However, I noticed that it has meant many employees are dis-engaged, going thru the motions. 
- Count on the annual re-org happening -- which means annual layoffs
- I personally have worked at Cisco for more than 15 years and got let go. Cisco may say they want you to retire there, which I was convinced I would...I was so loyal to that company, then suddenly got let go. It was pretty brutal to say the least. I essentially got kicked out of the family.  
- There's "juniorization" of the workforce going on here. They are trying to bring down the average age so if you are 23, good for you. If you are 38 or above, chances are it will be difficult for you to make your case. Millennials seem to hold a lot of importance at this company. Experience is no longer prime currency
- Changes going on in leadership and the way work gets done is highly, highly distracting. 
- Employee morale is extremely low
advice_management: See cons. You are getting rid of a lot of excellent talent - to your competitors. Talent that took years / decades to build and very loyal talent at that. Not sure if you'll ever be able to get that back.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 3 years

advice_management:
Select the best people. As a manager, you are only as good as the people on your team. ...
Be a motivator. ...
Build Your Team. ...
Be a Leader, Not Only a Manager. ...
Improve as a Communicator. ...
Get Better at Managing Time. ...

On the surface Cisco is very friendly to minorities but hiring retention trends on the manager through the VP ranks until you get to the CEO board suggests otherwise.
advice_management: Limit every fiscal years purges and do a better job retaining quality minority talent.

summary: "Good company, but going through difficult changes"
main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems
pros: Cisco has incredible talent across the spectrum of networking. As industry leaders in corporate and service provider networks they generate a tremendous amount of revenue and incredible profit margins
cons:
There are two major external trends which Cisco has to embrace if they wish to be relevant in the future:
1. The advent of cloud service providers beginning to dominate the TAM
2. Increasing interest in network virtualization as opposed to dedicated routers and switches
advice_management: More tough org changes are needed. Cisco has gone through many reorgs and to some extent it's in recognition of the company's need to change. However, it's not clear whether they are comprehensive and thorough enough.

summary: "Great place to work but low job security"
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time
pros:
- Work Flexibility is the biggest benefit of working for Cisco. You can work from home or any location of your choice in most of the BUs. Majority of roles in Engineering are location independent. Cisco provides collaboration tools to all employees. 
- Great 401K (4.5% match) and Medical benefits
- Bi-Annual Bonuses often exceed 100%
- RSUs and discounted stocks
- Recognition awards
cons:
- Continuous layoffs; low job security therefore low employee morale
- Massive brain drain causing company to lag in dynamic tech world. Cisco is under tremendous pressure to perform and management response to it is - layoffs
- Dominance of one particular foreign nationality therefore a lot of nepotism and politics
- Constant re-orgs and management changes. In 5 years, I have seen 6 managers and 4 Business Units with just one internal job change
- Business priorities change frequently
advice_management: Cisco's old glory would restore only if you focus on the employees and earn their loyalty else Cisco would soon be Nortel and Nokia of Networking Industry. Innovation is possible due to smart employees and to attract and retain the talent continuous layoffs are not helping but only making Wall Street happy. Just a matter of time when Wall Street will stop loving you too. So People Deal please!

There was no product manager to refer to and no clear ultimate goal. The deadline for product launch kept getting pushed back because of project creep.

summary: "Great company overall, but localized internal practices vary"
main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Pretty good pay, bonus and benefits. Innovation is encouraged and supported at high levels, but not necessarily at lower levels. There is strong enterprise support for most internal needs, and flexibility when specific requirements come along.
cons:
It's difficult to run a company so large and varied.
Acquisition is the norm instead of internal innovation in many business units.
Management is focused on the investors before employees.
Company frequently pushes the same practices and expectations on different business units inappropriately.
Internal quality suffers as management struggles to meet goals with limited resources and mediocre engineering practices are accepted as the norm, in some business units.
The company standardizes on one-size-fits-all solutions internally, but every solution seems to have an 18-month lifespan.
Benefits are comprehensive and good, but the employee is charged for most options.
advice_management: You have the message right.  The execution is lacking as far as employees are concerned.  Don't be afraid to do the right thing for your people.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Opportunity to have work/life balance, work from home, and ability to volunteer a lot of community hours.
cons: The upper management is not great. A few managers I know treated their subordinates like children. It's really about who your manager is. If you have a great manager try to stay with them although it's hard as managers get changed all the time. I've had 4 different managers within the last year. I had to explain my role to each one every time.
advice_management: Have a clear plan what you want from your subordinates. Show that you care about their career and help them if they need help finding another career path within the company.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems
pros: Cisco is a great company to work for as well as the culture.    The Benefits were generous, fair and in line with most technology companies.   It was an excellent experience and you make it what yuou want too.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems
pros: Loyal customers if you do your job right as an AM. Flexible work environment as the majority of us in my area work remotely to maximize time and productivity. Good OTE but it's weighted less on the base salary. Vast portfolio and always something to talk to your customers about. Great sales engineers which are the key to success.
cons: Cisco has a weekly commit culture which comes with a grind and a narrow focus versus a big picture mentality which is a must for Enterprise and Large clients. When front line mgmt is only concerned about the weekly number, focus is lost on the big picture and doing all the intangibles to overachieve your number. This is my perspective only based on my situation and may not be the case elsewhere.
advice_management: Focus on the month and more importantly the quarter versus the weekly grind. AM's are too busy chasing down the weekly commit versus developing strategic opportunities that result in major deals and will really impact the numbers that everyone is looking for.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than a year
pros:
Management are very good in general; technical, but with appropriate soft skills. Demands are reasonable, time off, flextime, and telecommuting are all accepted easily. 
In general, your personal time is valued greatly, and although I tend to work 45-55 hours a week, I can always count on being able to schedule some time for myself if the need arises.
cons: Tenured employees can sometimes stifle innovation, tend to not understand agile and continuous delivery, and also don't appreciate how flat team structures work.
advice_management:
Encourage new hires to challenge the status quo, and do a quick scrub of some of these old timers: who has been proactive and learning about continuous delivery, agile; conversely, who has been cashing a check while scheduling endless meetings to discuss minutiae of a design plan for a feature we can tweak later (deliver the value now is the agile way.)

Consider evaluating whether or not these tenured employees are pulling their weight, or impeding the adoption of new agile and continuous delivery practices.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Competitive Salary, Annual Bonus, great IT department.
cons:
I worked at Cisco for 14 years - towards the end it was very difficult to get things done.  It used to be that if you saw a problem you could call together a team of people, explain the problem,  everyone would get on board and the team would go solve the problem. 

But once the Bean Counters took over you had to have a budget to get anything done - you could call together a team, everyone would agree that there was a problem, would agree to help you fix it, but you needed a budget. 

To get a budget you had to write up a proposal, submit it, go through multiple reviews and then submit it for the Next fiscal year's budget.   Then if you got the budget, you spent much more time managing the budget than fixing the problem.  The result - it became impossible to get problems fixed.
advice_management: Let people do their jobs, remove the barriers that have been set up that are a hindrance to productivity.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: This is a very good company to work for with many benefits, especially the ability to work from home.  Many opportunities to learn and grow, and rotate in potential roles, if interested.
cons: No life/work balance, work long hours, especially with global teams in various time zones.  Cisco is changing at a rapid pace in order to to stay relevant with their competitors.  Expectations from management may be high as a result.
advice_management: Ability to truly "listen" to their direct reports' needs, not just offer verbal support without any actual results.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Work life balance, working remote is part of the corporate culture, great teams.

advice_management: You have great people give them a chance to show you what they can do.  Folks are not being utilized to their fullest potential

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than a year
pros: At a big company like Cisco, you get a number of opportunities to network with other people by taking part in the several events that various organizations host. The size of the company also opens the doors to several different opportunities in tech, as each team and each department works in different areas and with different technologies, and employees are given opportunities to learn about what is going on outside of their team and perhaps delve into other areas of work.
cons: A big organization also comes with its fair share of problems. There does not seem to be a universal direction, as every team and department works so differently, and propagating a proposed transition throughout the entire organization is a difficult thing to do. As a result, every group does things their own way, and one is bound to end up in a team where the processes do not follow what many other teams may supposedly be doing.

advice_management: Allow for career advancement and planning.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Some of the best opportunities to work on enterprise-level projects, lots of training on different subject available, stock plan, great gym and year-round sports.
cons: Slow career development and growth, specially mid to senior level. The constant reorgs do not help either. Even though a technology company, it's heavy on the sales focus and most of engineering is pure grind. The 'fun' and exploratory groups are separated into business units (BUs). Also, innovation is typically acquired vs investing in in-house R&D, leaving the impression that the grass is always greener on the other side.
advice_management: Continue on the right path to maintain Cisco as an industry leader. Internally, focus on developing a culture of continuous learning by incentivizing further career development and internal movement. A company is only as good as their employees.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for less than a year
pros: People are friendly. Working for home is a plus but need to find a way where we can collaborate as a team to better Cisco. Benefits offered to employees.
cons: Lack of systems. For a technology company I am surprise by the lack of systems available within HR. Most of the work is done manually which impacts the data accuracy. Need automation within the organization especially in HR. If you say you are innovative, bring automation into the organization. This can be a cost saving at the end of the day but the company needs to be willing to make the investment upfront. The compensation programs need improvement so it can reach 100% of the workforce and not a small percentage. The company needs to look to fund the program on an annual basis in order to attract the talent needed to take the company to next level. Losing key talents to organizations that offer higher salaries and an annual compensation program.
advice_management: Leaders need to have a proactive approach. Very reactive in this company. Better way to develop your employees and provide them the training needed. Internal training should not be a fee for employees. Needs to be a better way to deliver training. Simplify approaches/communications. The company makes it difficult and complex for our employees/mgmt. Stop over complicating things.  Listen more and act on the ideas. Streamline Jive sites....so many. Spending so much time looking for information.

pros:
I work in Cisco Security services,  and the last 2 years have been horrible.    This used to be a great company and great culture.  The last 2 years over,  great caring and capable managers have been replaced with newbies who operate without a care for employees and in lockstep with the new senior management.

Sadly,  much of the senior management is now from places like Pepsi and sourcefire.  These senior folks are dishonest, calculating and manipulative.   They also have super fragile egos and fire people for simply knowing more than they do.
cons: Having Cisco on your resume used to be a huge strength.  But nowadays it's becoming a liability in the job market.   That combined with the annual summer picnic and layoff,  it's become a truly bad place to work.
advice_management: Fire no nothing management clowns who joined from Pepsi and think running Cisco Security Services is like running a soda-pop company.   These clowns have destroyed Cisco Security Services and everyday, do more damage with their dishonesty and fragile egos.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than a year
pros: Excellent Work-Life Balance. Flexible with respect to day-to-day roles and responsibilities. Depends on which team and business unit you land in.
cons: Slow growth. If you are a fresh graduate, it will be a long career path ahead.
advice_management: Recognize the efforts of individuals and consistently encourage them by providing monetary and appreciation benefits.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: It used to be a good company
cons: Now they have toxic culture.  Annual layofffs has become a norm
advice_management: Value the employees

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 3 years
pros: A truly flexible work life balance that most leadership and employees emulate and practice in.  This can be a great benefit for those that are more mature in their life and require the flexibility or just need the ability to take care of errands and tasks without being bound to work hours.
cons: Cisco under pays their IT staff which is predominantly made up of contractors (over half).  It's as if Cisco believes it's still in its early 2000 heydays hiring cheaper contractors to manage their ever-growing supply of products and software services that never achieve a respectable integration.  Any engineer worth their salt would immediately turn away from the lack of respect in their woefully below market pay for IT Engineers while asking for the cream of the crop.  The greed is evident in their low base salary for the position to accommodate for their loose definition of what they constitute as an IT Engineer.  Yet, they will still have the gall to go recruit for quality engineers with the position and continue to be surprised when they lose recruit after recruit to their more informed competitors.
advice_management: There's a huge slew of managers, despite the much needed rounds of layoffs, that should have never been promoted as people managers that eventually burn the goodwill of new hires with their inability to think outside of their own careers.  In addition to their lack of good mentorship, these managers often double as low level "directors" setting the course for the team that often goes down a giant pit of ambiguity and mediocrity.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems  for more than 10 years
pros: flexible time options are great for working parents. Benefits are awesome with onsite clinic and fitness center. The site is great. Working conditions are good.
cons: There are so many departments and positons that is hard to keep track of who is working on what and how to contact people. Career advancement are pretty hard to get as people get fossilized into the first position they get.

summary: "Cisco is not the place it once was"
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Flexible work environment, golden handcuffs, the people you work wih
cons: Lack of leadership direction, layoffs layoffs layoffs.  This company is a shell of what it once was since John retired.  Management no longer has employees best interests at heart and half the year is wasted preparing for layoffs and then reorganizing.
advice_management: Remember what made Cisco such a successful company, the employees and start treating us with respect.  THe people deal is just an excuse to lay folks off without cause.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
* Work / Life balance due to flexibility to work anytime / anywhere
* Benefits
* Choice of Windows or macOS
* Got rid of forced rankings as part of annual performance reviews
cons:
* Annual layoffs
* Stagnant pay
* Little-to-no promotion or internal transfers
advice_management: Stop bleeding talent and replacing with younger (cheaper) workers.  My productivity was easily twice that of the contractors you'll be replacing me with.  The contractors & Wipro staff you brought in to learn my job were still coming to me asking questions a year later because they couldn't cut it on their own and now I'm gone.  Who will they turn to now?

summary: "Senior marketing manager caught up in Massive layoff"
main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than a year
pros:
Great resources; company tries to provide great benefits and tools to employees (it's just up to you to find them); excellent new executive leadership has vision and a plan.
Nice bonus structure and plenty of 'surprise' bonus opportunities
Supports a remote workforce, which made us all happier and more productive.
cons: HUGE, matrixed and therefore, political company. Lots of 'territories.' Base pay is a little low. If your job requires international travel, they send you economy class! In my short time there (14 months), there were 3 large layoffs, and I think that's not unusual.
advice_management: If you're going to re-organize every 6 months, figure out how to keep the employees worth keeping that want to stay--how much is it costing you to fire thousands of people and then hire new people ?

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems  for more than 8 years
pros: Flexibility, great benefits ( healthcare, travel,education and additional perks), positive work environment if you are within the right team. You will create relationships, friends and maybe even family. Respect, acknowledgment, equal rights. Its a great company to work for. Look for divisions like Channels and Meraki.
cons: Hard to move up or lateral. Lack of company vision and strategy towards the cloud, data center, and hardware commoditization. Services are too expensive. Sometimes they push AM's to sell solutions and the company eliminate the BU in less than a year causing sales teams and customers to suffer. The company is struggling to move fast, keep up with technology. I believe we lost our WHY and what we were good at... Tried to do too many things and can't deliver just to stay competitive on the market.
advice_management: Hurry up! we are becoming Dinosaurs in the IT/IOE/IOT/Services/HW world.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than a year

Core networking jobs
Great Benefits
Decent packages
cons: Too much turnaround of talent
advice_management: Find ways to retain talent

summary: "Nice people, good programs for college grads."

advice_management: Reduce middle management, a lot of them only look out for their job and add nothing to the mix.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems
pros: Nice team environment, managers help you with promotion, good metrics to measure your performance.
cons: Did not offer work from home option , when it is not a customer facing position - work can be done from home and save on commute time.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than a year
pros: Good work life balance.  Pleasant working environment. Surrounded by smart people.
cons:
Constantly "reorganizing" the internal structure.  Once a year you have to worry about getting laid off.  Not because you or your group is underperforming but because the higherups' mismanagement. 

Also, The manager to engineer ratio is too damn high.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 5 years
pros: The technology makes it possible to work from anywhere in the world. the flexibility is great, the compensation package is nice, the paid volunteer hours is a plus and the paid birthday is great.
cons: Cisco is slow in helping employees with professional development. It can be almost impossible to move around within the company.
advice_management: Be personable and really care about your employees. Take the time to know them and build a relationship that will make them feel valued and a part of something bigger. If you truly care about your employees and invest in their growth, you will get the best out of them.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than a year

cons: Does not automatically adjust salaries for inflation on an annual basis.
advice_management: Provide leadership training to employees who have potential to become managers.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than a year

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems  for less than a year

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
Lots of opportunities for career growth
Good work/life balance
Liberal transfer policy between business units (1 year at BU)
Strong business that generates lots of cash
Great place to find a mentor
cons:
Very politicized environment at BU leadership level
Some senior management hires are questionable quality
Often, budget is cut at cash generating businesses in favor of investing in future growth
Very fast pace product development, not much chance to build for the long term
advice_management:
Invest more in the cash-cow businesses, less in the future growth opportunities
Increase people management effectiveness in BU leadership, go for less political actors and more doers and builders

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Interesting work, fair compensation, flexible hours, occasional work from home allowed, high quality coworkers, development tool and infrastructure, good teamwork.
cons: Lateral and upward mobility is not great at satellite locations and they don't get the best projects. Different groups have very different processes. The spin in products (Nexus OS based switches) were done seemingly without good software quality processes in place more for time to market than long term sustainability.
advice_management: Value your remote teams more.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Great compensation, large product portfolio, plenty of mobility within different groups and technologies.
cons:
Not keeping up with salary changes.  Yearly layoffs.  Constant changing of direction each FY.  Culture died years ago and the little guy doesn't have a voice at all anymore, not matter how loud or cuss filled it is.
Honestly the yearly layoff alone should keep anyone away, it's toxic
advice_management: Stop laying people off

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Solid company with a mostly-wise executive steering team. Cisco offers a place doing decent work where one can maintain a solid career.
cons: This is a big company. I've been here since it was proud of being the biggest small company around, and that's no longer the case. It's still a decent company from the perspective of work, but if you're looking for an edgy workplace this isn't a good fit.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than a year

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems
pros: Great Company, Great Culture, Family Oriented, Very Structured, Great documentation
cons: Frequent Layoffs, Lot of Politics, Micro Management, Work is mounting not like before
advice_management: Stop this recurring layoffs. If you need to, do a massive one and end with that. By doing recurring restructuring you are loosing trust which is very IMP. Hope the management gets it!

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Flexibility and ability to rotate across different function allows learning while working and keeps you from getting stale. Also, Cisco has been generous to its employees and has gym, cafe, and health center. Till 6 years back, it used to be a really great company and very employee centric but for last few years, it is struggling to find its place and unfortunately it has taken a toll on employees and culture when priorities are constantly shifting .
cons: Layoffs every year impact employee morale and shows flawed hiring policy. Company needs to create a culture of trust and performance by ensuring that there is some stability and not constantly laying off people every year.
advice_management: It would be great if the management aligns hiring and firing with performance of the individual employees and not to the leaders of functions that are impacted. If an employee is a great performer, even when a function is impacted, employees should be realigned and not given a package. This creates an atmosphere of distrust and paranoia for the remaining employees and not good for company's performance. Practice what Simon Sinek said about leadership!!

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Loved the connections and relationships made. Great place to work to get the name on your resume.
cons: No longer a place for long-term career. Too many organizational changes that seem to be never end. Promotions are not possible unless you know someone. The yearly rounds of layoffs keep you guessing if you will even have a job. Senior management seems out of touch.
advice_management: Wake up.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time
