main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems  for more than 8 years
pros: Good work life balance. Plenty of opportunities to work on different projects. Great team collaboration.
cons: Constant organizational changes every six months, which fuels low employee morale.
advice_management: Articulate a strategy and stick to it. Give the org changes enough time in order to see the results.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems  for more than 10 years
pros: Ability to work anywhere any time made Cisco's growth.  Most employees spent ma lot of time ensuring their work was completed on time no matter what.  Great teams that worked together to accomplish their goals.
cons: New "People Deal" has lost the accountability of individuals.  No goals set, no way to demonstrate what you did and how much you accomplished.  Great for those that only want to do something for a week and then jump on something else, however it impact the rest of the team as they have to do the heavy lifting.  Not the exciting goal accomplishing org it once was.
advice_management: Stop adding VP/EVP/Board members and look at the folks actually doing the work...although that may be hard to do now that the only review is a "chat" with the manager.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
Laid back, positive environment, decent salary, good manager, forgiving environment. Some times there are inevitable frustration and hard times but it quickly vents away. Great technologies to learn. 
Free ev charger.
Some of the cafeteria are decent.
Employees can go to any of the numerous building covering massive area any time (except lab) and sit anywhere and attend meeting or do whatever.
cons:
Public newspaper says Cisco is getting fatter in the middle and need to get rid off excess mid level management. In some way, it might be true but also I saw talented and experienced engineers impacted and incompetent engineers have stayed. They really need to be careful in this respect because many many good employees have left during last year. More jobs are getting done by fewer employees as a result and quality suffers too. 

Encourages new ideas but quality/experiences takes a back seat. Quite a lot of times, there are turmoil

I feel like it is impossible to move within the company. Few other job inquiries resulted in no-reply.
advice_management: Train employees to be technically sharp, many of the employees are sloppy. Focus on quality in parallel with new ideas.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for less than a year
pros:
benefits are alright though most start past 6 months
pay is good

-everything is dependent on your relationship with manager (remote work, any shift in hours from 9-5, etc.)
-job duties are unclear 
-team not involved in technical decisions
-remote work is discouraged for most but not all employees even of the same position on the same team. 
-non technical managers leading IT teams (database, etl, developers)
-very inclusive environment, not for people who keep business professional
-everyone wants to be friends, lots of managers show outright nepotism
advice_management: Stop trying to make everyone seem like friends and just let the workplace be a professional environment. Non technical people should not lead technical teams, it takes longer to explain things to them than it would to just complete the task.

summary: "Marketing products and solutions pre and post launch"
main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 8 years
pros:
Flexible work location and hours. Open to telecommuting. 
Incredibly collaborative environment with extensive use of Webex video conferencing. 
Exposure to diverse technology and market segments depending on function.
cons:
Too many reorganizations. Frequent change in functional reporting and team management. At times group has barely settled into the new function before the next re-org.  
Slow top line growth has shifted focus on controlling costs. 
Infrequent salary raises.
advice_management: Accelerate transition to XaaS business model using Cisco Capital.

advice_management: Be more employee friendly in the AS GDC. No raises no promotion no advancement. Hiring a college educated person spending three to four years training them just to run them away to a competitor and then do it all over again seems like a really bad business plan.

advice_management: If there is one thing that can be fixed, improve the standard of hiring. Current hiring practices are very poor and the quality of hires is exceptionally low. You need best people to make best products. You can't keep thinking OpEx and hire anyone with a pulse. Hire people with passion.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: ok working environments, sometimes slow pace.
cons: lots of politics, constant cancelation of projects, lower pay, constant layoffs, bad for career with not so advanced technology used. sometimes unreasonable schedule.
advice_management: stop the political fights

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros:
Plenty of new technology and challenges.  Worked with many great team members over the years at Cisco. Always had more work than I could do in advanced services.
Work from home, virtual office.
cons:
Experience means little, they will replace anyone they can with younger, cheaper or H1B import.  
No time to get training on the new technology. 
Constantly changing product direction, often driven by acquisition justification.
50 hour weeks are common place, and they still want you to rack up Cisco certifications in your spare time.
advice_management:
Quit abandoning in-house development efforts in favor of something you acquired; try teaming groups up instead of breaking them up.  Work on understanding the concept of team synergy, because it is nearly non-existent.
Finally, quit with the H1B crap, there are plenty of qualified Americans that can do the jobs, you just can't hold them hostage with visas.

summary: "Mostly Good, Depends on What You're Looking For"
main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: It's Cisco. Great in terms of employee benefits, professionalism, and fair policies. Very good in terms of social presence (progressive, diverse), community engagement, social welfare, etc...  Large company with options to move around, grow, and gain experience. Salary/compensation tends to fall on the upper side of range. Large product/solution footprint that covers a lot of technology. 800lb gorilla with worldwide presence. Good reputation, Hallmark technology company, lots of things to build with and sell.
cons: Big company with the classic downsides. Internal culture and drivers have been impacted over the last decade by rapid development and shareholder/profit pressures. Most innovation is now acquired and assimilated. Not so much a knock, but where the company is in its evolutional cycle. The result is constant fluctuation in strategy, priorities, organization, and management. Unfortunately, career advancement/survival these days too often is knowing what bandwagon to jump on, when to jump off, and when to blame someone else. Lot of hardworking talented people get flushed in the process with the regular LRs. Too many managers "manage up" and not down.
advice_management: Keep trying. Work on minimizing organizational and operational disruption. Become aware of those in management whose primary objective is 'controlling the narrative' with exec level instead of being a transparent conduit with objectivity. Reinstate anonymous 360 feedback from the working level to mitigate. Incentivize so managers manage their team and not up.

job_title: Former Employee - Test Engineer/Technical Lead Engineer

pros: Interesting projects, good people, great compensations, bonuses, etc.
cons: Unstable. Every year "limited restructure" (meaning layoffs)

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 3 years
pros: People were nice, respectful, tried to do the right thing.
cons: Leadership was disconnected from business groups.  Goal-setting and planning processes for business groups was insanely complex.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Pay and benefits were good.  Got the chance to do a lot of interesting work and increase my areas of responsibility and expertise.
cons: Richardson felt like a backwater for Cisco.  Not a lot of communication between us and San Jose.  Always felt like we had too few licenses to do our job.
advice_management: Involve satellite sites more actively, letting them in on planning and decision making.  Get more software licenses.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Fat margins and weak competition in core (but declining) routing/switching businesses mean you can milk the cow without working too hard.
cons: Every year, Cisco hires thousands of younger (and offshore) workers and fires thousands of mid-career professionals.
advice_management: $15 billion in stock buybacks?  You can't think of anything better to do with that money?

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros:
Very profitable
Wide range of products
cons:
Unable to make a product plan that lasts more than 6 months
Zero loayalty to their employees, change plans by laying off and hiring
advice_management: Start paying attention to the effect of layoff/hire method has on the people you want to keep. Cisco employees are justifiably no longer loyal to the company.

pros: #NAME?

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems  for more than 10 years
pros: Cisco is still a leader in the IT industry with a significant presences in most every business and government segments.   They are well respected for their keen attention to the customer and best channel program in the business.  The IOE strategy is positive and being well received in the industry.   Technology innovation and solution sales continues to be their strength and focus.
cons:
New strategic focus on recurring revenue and software is right direction, however execution is still lacking as Cisco tries to define themselves in this space that is more focused on what happens after the initial sale then the big deal focus that has been celebrated and made them a success. Lot of talk about increasing customer usage, expanding the  relationship and retaining customers but still and afterthought and reactive vs strategic and proactive.  
On a personal note, not living in one of their major hubs like San Jose or Raleigh is the reason I believe I no longer work there after over 10 years of being with them.
advice_management:
1)  Elevate recurring revenue, customer life cycle management  to a new strategic level  that is part of the over all offer launch and got to market.  Today it is still an afterthought
2) Don't allow your past successes to keep you from changes required by the subscription economy and the rapidly approaching utility monetization models emerging.  I have seen great companies disappear because the held such a firm grip on the business and sales models that propelled them to dominance.  
3) Utilize your technology to broaden your talent pool, provide additional career opportunities and demonstrate to your customers the value benefit of a mobile virtual work force.  Bricks and mortar office buildings may become a thing of the past.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Fast moving company with lots of opportunities to learn from amazing peers. Every team is different wishing Cisco choose wisely who you choose to partner with. Your team is your greatest asset!
cons: Lots of different acquisitions happening, good and bad. Lots of white noise with campaigns and different promotions, it is difficult to stay in front of the partners and the customers with same unified message as well as strategic partnerships. Partners that are faithful are an ASSET!
advice_management: More reviews and training.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Great company to work for. Lot of cash to work with so there is no cutting corners in the process.
cons: Each BU is like an individual company and switching within BU is hard. Slow growth.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 3 years
pros: good solid engineers; focus on detail; quality work.
cons: too much politics; too many managers.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 3 years
pros: good solid engineers; focus on detail; quality work.
cons: too much politics; too many managers.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems  for less than a year
pros:
Great work life balance : Great place to START and/or END your career at.
Great people.
Work from home  option can be exercised freely.
Decent benefits.
cons:
Perpetual organizational churn
Employees referred to as resources
No clear goals / targets (Talking about engineering depts here)
NO performance evaluation making it difficult to chart a growth course if you are beginning your career.

I think with all the Spin-In business Cisco forgot about internal organic growth.
advice_management:
1. Delegate
2. Trust and back the people you manage
3. Think a plan through and then let it run it's course
     Eg. : Moving a team from Waterfall to Agile is not going to give you desired dev velocities and quality immediately. Hold your judgement for a couple of sprints at least.
4. Focus on implementing changes in letter AND SPIRIT. Going back to the dev life cycle: Breaking a waterfall into a cascade is not Agile.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Most flexible work conditions. Allows for complete independence in driving your work and career. It's a great feeling to work for a company that values it's human resource and is at the cutting edge of technology.
cons: Big corporate bureaucracy. Difficult to move up the ladder as a lot of mid-management folks are stagnant and in the way.
advice_management: Trim the fat from the middle. Allow of some senior individual contributors to moe into management track and provide trainings for them to do so.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems  for more than 3 years
pros:
great virtual work policy....work where you please
great tools for collaborating, especially Jabber (IM) and WebEx
exciting to work for a major company that helps shape the tech industry
Good severance if you are let go in the layoff, ahem, limited restructuring
cons:
Horrendously unstable
Bad communications with employees
So much lost time and effort wiped out each time layoffs; teams spend years developing great process and tools and then its all wiped out in a few weeks
Employee paranoia -- when's the next cut coming
advice_management:
Do some planning for a year at least
Provide some stability to your workers
Stop saying the "Cisco family"...its disingenous...be honest, we are a ruthless business and you are just a cog...we'd respect you more

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems  for more than 10 years
pros: It's loaded with cash and you get to work with a lot of very smart people.
cons: Annual layoff and people are not working as a team. You have lots of rock stars with big egos.
advice_management: Stop making stupid decisions like acquiring a company then laid everyone off in two years.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems
pros:
Great Benefits
High Pay
Work from home
Friendly People
cons:
Lack of control over anything that you do. "Architect" teams in the marketing department make all decisions and promises without consulting the engineers. Due to management structure, these decisions cannot be appealed.

As an intern, I was put on a team that was in no way prepared to take on an intern. They had great difficulty giving me anything to do. The one real project I had took me 3 weeks, after that, despite asking for more work I was barely given anything to do.

My entire team was very upset with management and the decisions being made, but was powerless to even voice these opinions.

Satellite locations get overlooked a lot. You are a second class employee if you're anywhere but San Jose.

I saw multiple instances of people being hired as developers and then being placed into a sysadmin job under the guise of devopts.

Oh yeah, and they're laying off 20% of their workforce.
advice_management:
Give engineers a say in decisions.

Stop with the absurd leadership structures that prevent teams from cooperating.

If you need sysadmins, hire sysadmins don't hire devs and then make them work admin jobs.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Decent pay & bonus. company chips-in up to 4.5% of base towards 401(k), $ for $ and the employee stock purchase plan allows for purchasing company stocks at a 15% discount to the market price.
cons: no clarity on performance rating of employees. discussions are not actionable and outcomes are very subjective. since bonus and company stock options are tied to performance, one has to wonder the basis for such awards.
advice_management: set specific, measurable, attainable, relevant and time-oriented (SMART) performance metrics for employees so they know where they stand and what they need to work towards for success.

summary: "Who could be motivated or inspried by working at Cisco?"
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems  for more than 10 years
pros: No need to sell as you simply need to rely on the partner community to do all the work. Cisco management simply sits around all day and scrutinizes salesforce.com.  Meetings everyday over your forecast so they can push the number up to the top.  Sell without regard to the partner or customer.
cons: Nothing matters but your forecast which will be analyzed hourly.  But even if you hit your hourly, weekly, monthly and quarterly number chances are that another 5,000 to 6,000 empolyees will be terminated without regard on August 1st.
advice_management: Get your head out of the forecast and manage so that another market transition like Could computing isn't missed and another 6,000 employees aren't terminated without any explanation

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time
pros: If you are in a good group, you'll never find better people to work with.  The contacts I've made at Cisco are some of the best people out there.  The company is always one of the leaders in every technology it takes on - you always have a stellar brand and reputation backing you.  The company provides many perks, good salaries, and encourages remote working which helps balance your work/life/family needs.
cons: It is a big company, so there is quite a bit of empire building and politics. Just hope that you fall on the right side of the technology decisions.  Right now they have to make a huge transition from purely hardware to annuity-based xaaS and software, so they are shedding amazing talent in hopes that cheaper millenials will save them.
advice_management: Good luck in the transition to the new model. Be sure to treat your employees right, they are your best asset.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Very flexible with working from home; good benefits; smart people
cons: Constant layoffs; difficult to get a promotion or raise; difficult to get work done -- too any processes
advice_management: Retain the high potential employees

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than a year
pros: Flexible hours; robust "virtual office" program allowing to work from home very efficiently; great work/life balance; decent perks if you are working in home office.
cons: Software Defined Networking (SDN) put this company in headlock.  Once ubiquitous network gear is getting replaced by software; re-orgs and layoffs ensue; moral drops.
advice_management: Find new direction, communicate it clearly, and stick to it.

summary: "Cisco is a good place to work"

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 8 years

A very positive work enviroment.

cons:
Too frequent "workforce reductions" - we joked about being on yearly contracts. It plays havoc on employee morale

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems  for more than 10 years

cons: As a public company there is tremendous focus on bottom line performance because of the challenge associated with growing a very large revenue number.  This drives the company to take very ruthless costing cutting steps at times that make business sense but leave a wake of family despair
advice_management: Be thoughtful about talent reallocation when divesting to reinvest

job_title: Current Employee - Senior Product Marketing Manager
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for less than a year
pros: Worked with the brightest sales professionals in the industry. Never a dull moment. Worked with many talented product managers and engineers.
cons: Overlapped marketing functions in the central marketing organization (CMO). This makes it harder for marketing executives to manage people, process, technology, budgets, campaigns, and programs.
advice_management: Consolidate and integrate business units that have overlapped features and GTM. Pay more attention to veteran employees.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems  for more than a year

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Great company and culture. Great benefits and work environment. Most managers are pretty empowering and the culture motivates leaders to encourage innovation, great work and empower their teams. Values are still held closely and there are big changes happening to ensure the company catches up with the changes in the technology industry and with the market transitions. Big changes in the HR function as well to move towards team based leadership and coaching leaders to be effective not as individuals but as team leaders.
cons: As it is a large organization, one can lose focus and can get lost in the mammoth organization and its dynamics. It is important to have mentors and people who look out for.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time
pros: Top notch compensation.  Excellent work life balance.  Excellent training programs particularly for new sales engineers and senior leaders.
cons: Cisco is changing for the worse.  While compensation is top notch, the (at least annual) layoffs and re-org/strategy changes do take a toll on personal psyche as well as your organization's ability to deliver.  Senior leadership now seem to be "consultant MBA types"  or mediocre engineering program managers rather than people who want to build products that customers want to buy.  Accountability is completely lacking at middle levels of the organization
advice_management: Measure people and teams based upon execution and give them the flexibility to deliver rather than hamstring them with process and re-orgs

summary: "Annual layoffs and negativity the norm now"
main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems
pros:
-The people that I worked with were some of the smartest and best coworkers that I've ever worked with. 
-There is a lot of flexibility with your schedule.
-You do tend to get to work with newer technologies and tools.
cons:
-Visibility is really the most valuable skill anyone can have. If you expect that just doing good work and working hard will matter you will be disappointed. Making Excel spreadsheets and copying nearly everyone on an email is a far more useful skill.
-There's always a negativity from managers and false stress sent down from them. I had four different managers and even the best ones always seemed to be negative about something. I didn't realize this until I changed companies and realized just how much better the environment could be.  This must come from higher management because even the good managers were like this. My new job just doesn't have this nonsense.
-Annual layoffs just seem to be part of the culture now, enjoy July and August as the rumors start.
- Forced rankings is terrible. Most groups that I was in don't really have weak people but you knew someone was going to "need improvement" with whatever that entailed. Make sure that your boss likes you so that you're less likely to be the victim.
advice_management: I am so happy that I left Cisco. I am having a better career now with growth options and less manufactured stress. Yearly layoffs stress out even the good employees.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 3 years
pros: A lot of wonderful people work here.  They started adding snacks to all the newly configured blogs with collaborative workspaces.
cons: Upper management only rewards their friends and don't really care about the people.  The new collaborative workspaces are absolutely horrible!!!

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than a year
pros: Great people who are smart, knowledgeable and very collaborative.  The company lives its vision to change the world and they are developing some fantastic products that will positively impact people and the world.  They treat their employees very well, with respect and always want to do the right thing. Great benefits and rewards.
cons: Not as transparent as they think they are.  Not really open to change. Marketing is not cutting edge and hard to make an impact.  Strategies change daily.
advice_management: Need to figure out the strategy before acquiring new businesses that just get cut 6 months later.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years

cons: Career advancement is limited. The company is in the process of evolving it's business strategy. Some leaders have been in roles too long which they are not suited for. Once an individual turns 50+ they look to move on in many cases.
advice_management: It's time to move the company forward. Accept the fact that the business model which got Cisco to this point will not get it further. It is time for Cisco to evolve as a company.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems  for more than 10 years
pros: Cisco is a large company allowing it to invest in smaller innovative companies.
cons: Cisco moved its headquarters to India over the past several years. This has dramatically changed the make up of its workforce. Most of its strategic vision is for Global investment. This strategy comes at the cost of American resources employment opportunities.
advice_management: Globalization does not mean outsourcing.... Reduction of headcount in the US will continue investment in countries like India and China may look good on the balance sheet but we'll limit American creativity which is the cornerstone of Cisco Systems.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 3 years

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time
pros: Cisco has great package of benefits and good combination of work/life balance. There is great diversity of cultures in Cisco and opportunity to work with many people across the globe. CEO and Executive Leadership Team are seriously pushing the People Deal and seem to care about employees. There is "Freedom of Speech" and open friendly work environment.
cons: Salaries are on the lower side compared to competition. Lots of meetings and time zones across the teams, which makes it difficult to manage your normal working day. Lots of tools and abbreviations. Your experience will most likely depend on the team you land in. It can be both highly positive and negative. There is no clarity on how your performance is measured and what to expect in the next year or so.
advice_management: Continue to invest in workforce development and building trust across the company and employees. Introduce clear and efficient talent management processes. Increase the pay and help employees to grow.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time

My team is not flexible on work hours. Salary not competitive and not great at all if compared with cost of living. Managers have room to improve. It does not feel like a silicon valley company. It offers advantages of a startup but no benefits.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 5 years

cons: it's not what you know... it's who you know...  layoffs occur often (large and small)

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems
pros: Benefits are great.  Full medical/dental/vision, employee stock purchase plan and numerous arrangements with retailers for discounts.  In my role I was often able to work from home without recrimination, as were most people.  Generally really liked the people, but in a company that large there are bound to be some jerks.
cons: To this day it boggles my mind how poorly managed the company as a whole is.  They have layoffs every year and never seem to figure out that its because they have poor talent management.  All too often highly skilled technical people are promoted into leadership positions , and they have no idea what they are doing and the team suffers.  there is also no consideration for compensation given to employees for their experience.  If you get hired this year at a set salary, it does not have a cost of living increase.  Next year an identical person could be hired who would make more than you, even though they have less experience.  This is one of the major causes of employee attrition.  I can really only speak for IT but Mid-level management (director level) is just plain bad.  By every definition of the term, just poor leadership.
advice_management: Learn to manage your talent!!!  Both what you have and your future pipeline.  You can't keep prattling on about wanting "only the top talent" and then balk because it costs a few thousand more to hire that person.  Towards the end of my time in CIsco I would tell the new hires that Cisco was a great place to start your career, but leave as soon as you can, and I think that is still true today.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems  for more than 10 years
pros: Plethora of talent to work with
cons: Raises were few and far between
advice_management: It is 100% new management from when I was there

summary: "If You Value People Over Money, Cisco is Top of Class"
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time
pros: Amazing opportunities to learn different things, technologies, industries. If you enjoy twisting and turning your way through the day and jumping through hoops to make things happen, you'll enjoy Cisco. If you appreciate different challenges and continuous change, you'll enjoy Cisco. If you like consistency and a slower pace, you'll struggle to keep up. If you value leadership and the idea of learning from others as an early in career employee is important to you (over pay) then you'll enjoy Cisco.
cons: You won't make a million dollars in your first 10 years ... it might take 20. Pay, and promotional velocity aren't amazing, but you'll never have to worry about getting the things you need.
advice_management: Listen well, listen each week, act swiftly and in servant fashion, then close the loop to build trust. Excellence, and our experience as people, lives on the team.

summary: "A great place to work? Depends on your manager and reporting chain."
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than a year
pros: Smart people, excellent benefits, flexible schedule, supportive of family, and people tend to strive to do better. And you can't beat the collaboration technology.
cons: Layoffs are becoming more frequent (in marketing they are quarterly), which is disruptive to productivity and creates a stressful environment.
advice_management: Clarify your cloud strategy. Help new grads learn our business faster. In the rush to hire young people, you are devaluing experience. Both are needed.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years

cons: The culture is changing.  The senior management team is still trying to make their mark and find their way.  It is going to take some time and some pain to get through this transition.  Cisco needs to figure out how to stop the yearly "limited restructuring" and get the morale back on track.  It is not a happy place to be right now.
advice_management: There is no productivity when everyone believes they are on a yearly contract that will be up each July.

This applies specially to IT. Sales, Engineering, Advanced services are better groups
advice_management: Work on the cons to make it a good experience for ICs and not just management, Evaluate managers based on ratings from employees, Hear the voice of ICs and give them a chance to represent themselves in front  of senior management

summary: "Pretty good for a big company, despite the repeated layoffs"
main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems
pros: Cisco has excellent benefits for regular employees, including all the health, vision, dental, 401k, ESPP, family bonding leave, and other benefits that are part of big company compensation in Silicon Valley.  Cisco has a good internal training and learning site that gives you access to many resources for improving your knowledge. The culture is modern and socially liberal, embracing diversity is encouraged.  And, if you are laid off, the severance package is generous.
cons: I was part of an acquisition at Cisco.  And while it was handled well, and the transition went pretty smoothly, after a few years Cisco gutted our business in one of it's perennial layoffs. It was a disappointment, since we were making money and doing well compared to other acquisitions.  You cannot allow yourself to forget that Cisco is a big company, and if you are not working on something that's making a great deal of money there, Cisco is not likely to understand your business well enough to grow it.
advice_management: Take care when acquiring companies, to preserve these teams that work so well together.  The connections these people have forged with each other provide for improved productivity.  Don't put obstacles in their way, or blow the teams apart.

cons: Not all the organization in Cisco runs the same way.  Some organizations don't really care for their employee growth.

advice_management: Consider all the moving parts that make the company work. Not just the FTE gear makes the engine run.

summary: "They call it "People Deal", should be "Some People Deal""
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems  for more than 10 years
pros: The work is interesting and challenging and you get to work with some really motivated and talented people. Our use of vendors to augment employees allows us to be flexible with our headcount and ratios while getting a lot of good work done.  Change is happening so there is anyways something new to drive goals and initiatives; it doesn't get stale.
cons: Our executives are out of touch with the general employee population and if you aren't in the right circles, it is difficult to get heard or get promotional opportunities.  We talk a lot about our  People Deal and how each employee matters but it feels like it is really The Some People Deal, depending on who you know.  We do layoffs of good employees instead of managing our vendor population and don't facilitate moving impacted employees to open positions within the company.  As a manager and leader, I usually feel the good outweighs the bad and support the leadership but I'm starting to wonder.
advice_management: Do what you say; treat all your employees well, reward risk taking; be truly transparent, don't punish those that challenge the status quo or aren't connected.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems
pros: Great talented people, lots of creative marketing, good flexiblility
cons: too many layoffs and promos of "favorites"
advice_management: Cisco continues annual layoffs of thousands, but maintains a huge base of contractors in roles that should be filled by FTEs.  Contractors are supposed fill project-based roles.  Perhaps get rid of contractors, and see where some of your soon to be laid off employees might fill some of those roles.  Oh right contractors don't show on books and you don't have to pay health benefits.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Good people, flexibility to work remote, highly respected
cons: Difficult systems and processes, not agile, cutting workforce
advice_management: Focus on agility and arm workforce with tools for success.  Better planning on workforce reduction to reduce impact on customers, partners and internal teams.

summary: "Marketing is a hot mess -- morale at all time low"
main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems
pros: Employees themselves work hard to do the right thing IN SPITE OF the lack of leadership at director and VP levels.
cons: Regular layoffs specifically targeting over 50 long-term employees who's salaries are "high."   Pathetic senior management.  "People Deal" is truly a joke and incredibly disingenuous -- you'll get a free PTO day off on your birthday, but we'll stack rank you and NOT tell you how you fared or why or what your "rating" is.  Long-time employees (10 years+) laid-off with a moment's notice and a "generous" 3-month severance package.  3 months after 10+ years?  Targeting over 50 year old employees??  People Deal???   Staggeringly hypocritical management.
advice_management: It's "never been a better time" to fire yourselves with a 3-month severance package.  After all, you're all over 50, right?

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems  for more than 10 years
pros: Not many Pros in this company anymore. Most of what Cisco's management is doing to attract college hires is by spending a lot of money  on free food, snacks and weekly Pop-up Parties!
cons: Culture is changing--bringing in college hires --for every college hire, Cisco gets rid of two senior professionals. Then over loads the college hires, essentially paying them a 1/4 of the salary.  It was a great place to work now it is just trying to hang on with less talent.
advice_management: So many other ways to cut waste and reduce costs, but killing one culture just to mimic other cultures like it's a fun place to work.  NOT!

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems  for less than a year
pros:
- Good RSUs, comparable salary
- Great diversity
- Foresight on market transitions and hype/buzz building around it
cons:
- Too many layoffs
- ELT disconnected from what is really happening  (disconnect between execution & slides)
- Sr. Directors, Directors & VPs hired from outside (just because promotions are too political but getting a req is only a finance game)
advice_management:
- Stop doing layoffs every year
- Cut down the number of VPs, Directors and Sr. Directors and stop hiring Sr. Directors/Directors from outside with two years experience when you have loyal top talent within the company
- Develop and promote internal talent - and that includes retraining talented employees

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for less than a year
pros: Great Place to work, lots of options with regard to products, teams, locations. Great benefits too.
cons: Sometimes too big for it's own good.  Lots of overlapping products competing with each other. Looking to revamp itself as a subscription based software company ( understandable), but at the at the expense of massive layoffs of people that have dedicated their careers to Cisco and have survived many such transitions in the past.  This often seems to target folks they think make too much money, are not in a growing line line of business, etc.  We all get the need to right-size periodically, but there are less drastic means to do so.
advice_management: Stop the annual bloodshed of employees, and instead, be but much more proactive in coordinating with employees to move between sales to business units, IT, Engineering,  etc.  Lots of people at the pinnacle of their skills only to be cut loose without any real cause but being wrong place at the wrong time.

summary: "Excellent Work-Life Integration & Balance but Limited Advancement Depending on Group"
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Work remotely; make a real difference for over 70,000 employees by steadily improving internal systems. I'm lucky to work on something I love with a really fun and smart scrappy group. If not for this dynamic, would leave.
cons: Annual Big Bang and continuous rolling layoffs is difficult; despite all the layoffs, headcount has held steady between 67k and 73k for the past decade - so the company is essentially at least attempting to let go of low performing individuals and groups to hire in growth areas while keeping control on cost. Despite best efforts on this, many good people get sucked back out to sea in these politically charged restructurings. RSU funding is extremely limited for my team, only top 5% (key performers) of individual contributors get any grants. IMHO, comp generally not competitive with industry. If you join Cisco, be super aggressive on negotiating on the way in - once you're in the system, even harder to move the needle on your base comp.
advice_management: Quit widespread use of arbitraging labor to cheap geos. It's better to eliminate jobs through streamlining processes and automating systems rather than replacing Westerners with subpar offshore warm bodies.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for less than a year
pros:
-Everyone is very helpful, especially to new employees
-Generally surrounded by positive, intelligent people
-Great  benefits and pay
-Work/Life balance
-Flexibility with working hours and ability to work from home
-Gym and health center onsite
cons:
-Similar to other corporations for business roles, there is no "set path" for you to take. No promotions or raises scheduled. However this is also a positive. You are totally in charge of your own career. This is great for self-starters who are willing to be proactive and take control of their career, but if you are wanting to do the bare minimum and become promoted due to tenure, this isn't the place for you.

-Sometimes the first few months of a new role can be slow moving
advice_management: Create more consistent training for new hires. Require each department to have training matrices with specific tasks for employees to complete, training to take, and meetings to setup. This will streamline the onboarding process and save managers a lot of time.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems  for less than a year

cons: Cisco has a relationship-focused culture. Very political in spite of the visible leadership changes at the top. Lots of people are just coasting. Big words but not much follow through.
advice_management: Need to adopt a different method to select managers. That is generally a challenge in the tech industry. But cisco has the resources to create the right process.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than a year

advice_management: The most important aspect of your product is reliability. If you sacrifice quality for meeting schedules that are based on salespeople being able to sell new features at shows, you are undermining your business.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems  for more than 3 years
pros: Emphasis on people and culture. You can grow and do interesting work. Highly colaborative culture. Respect for diverse opinions. Smart capable leadership. People are taken care of very well while working there.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems  for more than a year
pros: Very professional and progressive. Grows you up as a corporate sector employee with great base salary, perks and quality work
cons: Ruthless about deadlines and target. The area the company needs to focus on is laying off the employees who are not performing or are on performance improvement plans. I saw a lot of very talented and intelligent employees with proven track records get impacted by the layoffs and noticed the under performing employees are still there. They also need to spend some time focusing on the international employees as well.
advice_management: Make employee clear about company direction in future and try not to make financial report better just by laying off valuable employees

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time
pros: There are no pros. Required word count.
cons: Doesn't care about innovation, people are resources and are disposable, efficiency doesn't matter, software engineering best practices are ignored, suggestions and feedback are ignored, internal tools suck, internal website unusable, frequent layoffs, outsourcing as much work as possible, speed over quality is their mantra, seniority is the only thing that matters not ability or being right.
advice_management: Send a poll to all employees asking what their career goals are or what they feel is their most valuable skill. Then send a poll to every manager asking them to describe what they feel each of their employees career goals are and what their most valuable skill is. You'll get an idea of what managers care about their employees and which are just climbing over them to get up the ladder.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Great benefits, good work-life balance, lots of opportunity for moving around in company (rather than quitting and joining another company because you want to try something else)
cons: resource wasteful at times, keeps some businesses / groups in play longer than they should
advice_management: BETTER integrate services with product so that the feel, pricing, and support (from the customer's point of view) is truly a 'One-Cisco' experience.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: The company cares for its employees. Cisco offers great benefits including salary, 401K match, bonus, etc.
cons: Considerable bureaucracy in some organizations, which can stifle innovation and risk taking. Too much time spend on politics vs. value add activities.
advice_management: Encourage more risk taking.

job_title: Former Employee - Cross Functional Business Operations Manager and Project Manager
main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros:
Individual contributor employees are top notch and great to partner with on solutions
Opportunity to work from home is a nice opportunity
Benefits and pay are market compatible
Volunteering and giving back opportunities are very nice
Products are quality and ground breaking
cons:
Loyalty no longer means anything, the company has become to stock value based
Experienced employees are no longer valued
Work life balance is hit or miss depending on the group 
RSU (Restricted Stock units) are given at the wrong levels and when they do make it to the individual employee they are too few
Many of the good perks are gone (drinks, food, social events)
advice_management:
Leadership has become more worried about stock moving 1/4 of a point versus making the company successful.  In many groups it simply comes down to counting the beans and not the actual value add of the employee.

Company focus is on bringing in new collage graduates which is a plus, however training these new recruits comes at the price. Senior experienced employees are asked to do double duty, their present role and the training of the new employees.  The new employees ramp up on the backs of the experienced employees.  Following this some experienced employees are laid off, the newly trained university highers quit, and then the remaining group is asked to do more with less.  This is an area leadership needs to rethink.  

Leadership also needs to think about reducing itself yet again. More leaders does not necessarily mean a better company.  The recent layoffs reduced this headcount each time, however this was followed by more promotions inside meaning the business remained complex.  If you are trying to flatten the business, you can keep back filling the higher ranks.  You need to increase individual contributors so that projects can be completed faster, with less politics, increasing employee satisfaction, and growing to the bottom line.  

Finally budgets are constantly being impacted.  Projects are stopped and started quarterly reducing effectiveness, increasing cost, and impacting employee moral.  The PMO needs to have better control from a central point.  If you start a project of value don't shut off the funding 2nd quarter and than turn in back on in 3rd quarter.  People have moved on and changed roles; you are basically starting the project over again.  Truly a waste of time, resources, and money.  Your leadership teams are type "A" personalities (competitive) and they are fighting over the dollars and resources creating an employees nightmare.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than a year
pros: Good pay, some positions allow a lot of creative freedom. Flex hours, telecommuting available.
cons: Lack of technical people in director and above roles, lots of politics get in the way of progress. not loyal to employees - your safest as a contractor.
advice_management: Less VP's and Directors. Lose non technical Directors leading technical teams.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems
pros: Challenging work, freedom to solve problems, good benefits, and pay is very competitive.
cons: Constant cycle of lay-offs.  New hiring is heavily focused on college grads, while lay-offs tend to focus on higher salary experienced workers.  Cisco uses a lot of somewhat unskilled contractors to fill the voids left by lay-offs, leaving some business units in near chaos.  Cisco is top-heavy in management.  There seems to be a line drawn between first line managers and the management team above, where the folks in the trenches making things happen don't really know what that upper layer of management is doing.  Then there's a slew of Program Managers that seem to have no other responsibility other than to feed information to upper management.  Employees in the trenches question the value being provided by upper management.
advice_management: Cut half the management team and flatten the company.  Stop off-shoring and hiring contractors, their skill set is sub-par and it's killing the Engineering team in some business units.  Do more hiring for skill rather than only college grads.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems
pros: Awesome time here. Met great people, and everyone was helpful
cons: It took a while to get access to certain things
advice_management: Keep doing what you're doing

summary: "Strategy and Execution is in a constantly in flux"
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
Decent Pay
Good 401k match at 4.5%, vests 100% upon match
Some of the best products for collaboration, data center
Flex time and telecommuting is the norm
cons:
Cisco continues to cut jobs through massive layoffs (5500 direct) and (another 8500 through early retirement). Some were double CCIE's and many were CCIE's. This does not show value in employee skills 
No strategy for IoT
Executive Management does a poor job communicating strategy
Internal transfers are difficult
Services margins are too high to build an IoT line of business
Sync-ups has replaced a poor personnel performance ranking system, but few managers follow,the policy on conducting the sync ups.
advice_management:
Be honest with your employees. Stop the constant churn of layoffs. Admit that Cisco is betting on Security. Exexutive leadership is betting their entire strategy (cloud, collab, IoT) on security and have been replacing executives with their prior colleagues specializing in security while those underneath are crushed by layoffs. 

With the mass layoffs and no performance reviews, Cisco will end up just hiring again in 30-45 days, costing more  money to onboard and train instead of placing existing employees in positions in those positions based on skill sets. Cisco is cleaning house and hiding the constant strategy churn due to protect their brand to Wall Street.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Flexible hours, can work remotely.
cons: Too much politics; management only concerned with their own image. They don't recognize "silent" workers who had contributed a lot, but just are not into tooting their own horns. I had a manager who was very condescending.
advice_management: Just because an employee does not send emails to everyone about each and every delivered task doesnt mean that they are not doing their job. You have to recognize everyone.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems
pros: WFH provide some flexibility (to make up for very heavy workload)
cons: Cisco Sr. Leadership continued to make really bad hiring, strategic, and tactical decisions as related to Cloud.  It obviously lost the race on SDN, Cloud to Amazon and Microsoft. Its strategy of laying off people annually to cut cost is obvious the wrong strategy. It really kills the morale within the company, divides the people (millennial vs 40+'s.)   Also it is a complete mess of bureaucracy among high and middle-management and a lack of advancement opportunities are stifling innovation.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros:
Working from home is a great plus.

cons: Layoffs, layoffs, layoffs - Cisco lays off every year and has it down to a science. It's easy to assume you won't be one of the ones impacted because you are a hard worker, are loyal and have received great reviews.  But, your reviews, loyalty and hard work don't really matter. At Cisco, you are a number.
advice_management: Manage better so you don't have to layoff employees every year so that you can claim your millions in salary. And, if you do lay them off, give them a good package.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems  for more than 3 years
pros: great benefits, work life balance.
cons:
Acquisitions are frequently abandoned after few years as non strategic - which raises the question on the process how due diligence was carried out during evaluation of the acquisition
Annual Layoffs in Aug-Sep time frame every year.

Execute on projects and build a road map that you will deliver not walk away because you have another shiny toy to play with. 
Also hire fresh new talents from industry not people who served as CTOs of big company's and failed.

advice_management: Live where we are going - keep helping individuals grow.

summary: "Sexist jerks who have no clue what they are doing!!"
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems  for more than 10 years
pros: Work from home, good benefits RSU golden handcuffs.  Has cutting edge products.  Minimal travel required.  However the cons far outweigh the pros.
cons:
Very poorly managed & cut-throat competition.  Duplicate efforts across departments.  Extremely territorial.  Very sexist "good ole boy"
ClubsI worked in a team they devalued women & targeted all the senior level folks in a recent LR.  

Double standard in place - if you at married man with kids but lousy at your job then Cisco will keep you. If you a female then you will be treated like dirt.
advice_management: Stop with the restructuring and quarterly layoff.  Eliminate more VPs/Dir who do not perform

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems
pros: Cisco has a culture that is very laid back. You aren't expected to show up in a suit - often times you aren't even expected to show up to the office at all. Many employees are able to work from home whenever they need. The benefits are also great as far as time off and healthcare.
cons: Being such a large company, there are definitely a lot of politics involved in projects and routines.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time
pros:
Good cafeterias -- with both healthy choices and not-so-much.
Some nice buildings, although the nicer buildings have smaller cubicles.
cons:
Cisco is an engineer-centric society, much to its own detriment.

Cisco had an HR department website instead of new-employee orientation.  Despite the steady stream of complaints from employees about the user hostility of the internal HR website, Cisco persisted in forcing its employees to rely on a highly unreliable internal HR website, much to the frustration of everyone involved.

Cisco management seemed hell-bent on working its employees days, nights, and weekends -- all the while chanting the Work-Life Balance buzzwords as hypocritical propaganda.

Other companies work hard to instill and encourage and maintain mutual respect so that each and every employee, from board room to mail room engage with kindness and respect.  Not Cisco.

Horrendous coffee.
advice_management: Your products are not appreciated by customer users because you encourage your engineers to overrule valuable input from non-engineer teammates with User Experience expertise.  You've grown a culture of arrogant engineers, both inclined and encouraged to treat others with disrespect and disregard.  Having been a Technical Writer at Cisco and having spoken with other ex-Technical Writers from Cisco, we've agreed that working at Cisco as a Technical Writer is an appalling experience.  One such writer said it was the first time in his career that he'd decided to quit a job without having another job lined up.  Stressful; thankless; annihilating.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems  for more than 3 years
pros: Will get a chance to work on variety of products, good work life balance, competitive pays.
cons: Restructuring and refining happens often.
advice_management: Focus on few areas and be good at that.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems  for less than a year
pros: Cisco is a very relaxed place to work with friendly people and a modern work environment.
cons: It's tough to get friends and family excited about networking.
advice_management: Give more frequent feedback

summary: "Cisco is unmatched for "how you work" flexibility."
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Most everything is project-based so when, where & how you do it is largely up to you.  Level of worker trust and autonomy is first rate
cons: No clear, efficient process to move talent around the company as inevitably some products are hits while others fail. Cisco over rotated on performance reviews. Went from onerous do it yourself yearly dissertations that direct managers "graded" to informal sync-ups that largely get blown off or skipped because they are too unstructured. Cisco needs to rethink performance reviews so they get better performance.
advice_management: Translation of broad strategy to focused strategic objectives from the CEO's direct reports to levels below down to line managers often does not happen. Every management level in every BU needs an articulated, validated strategy that is clearly traceable to what's espoused by Chuck and team. There's a lot of "make it up as we go" in Cisco.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for less than a year
pros: Good pay as well as loving people. Paid vacation and holiday pay as well as good benefits which starts upon employment.
cons: I did not like the one hour lunch, however, it a good rest time for those who want to but love 30 minutes.

summary: "Slow-Growing Company Where Marketing is a Disaster"
main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
Cisco the company is solid. Generally nice working conditions, perks, compensation, programs. 

The company, though, is growing very very slowly (5% would be a strong year), and not always in the hottest fastest-growth areas (cloud, security). So, it grows primarily through acquisition of other companies to bolster lackluster organic expansion. 

It's a bit like working at a utility company. Nothing too exciting. Shallow dips and small peaks; nothing to write home about. Nothing earth-shattering or particularly innovative on its own, so it acquires growth. In order to maintain steady headcount, layoffs are frequent and predictable.
cons:
As with most larger companies, there are departments and programs that are run well, and some to avoid.  

The Marketing & Communications team is an unmitigated disaster. Since a new Chief Marketing Officer (CMO) was appointed in mid-2015, there have been at least six layoffs of varying sizes in Marketing alone, with more always on the horizon. Marketing leadership has been decimated in a purge to remove anyone who might not be loyal to the latest CMO and her hatchet-man.  VPs, Directors, Managers, and Individual Contributors are all whacked -- and as usual, the best people have left.

Steer clear of Cisco Marketing, but otherwise the company is pretty good although slow-moving and middle of the road.
advice_management: Chuck Robbins is doing an OK job as new CEO except for his ability to pick good leaders. The CMO in particular and her inner circle are a mess, and the morale, productivity, quality and outputs/results from Marketing are awful. The rest of the company is mediocre and slow-moving.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems  for more than 5 years
pros: Ample training opportunities;  Access to a lot of resources, both hardware and software.  Access to some very smart people.  Good treatment of minorities.
cons: Went from having a bad rating system to having no rating system at all.  Performance makes no difference, compensation growth is well below inflation.
advice_management: A technology company cannot have a middle management layer that is completely ignorant of technology.  The first step to enabling innovation is to get rid of people who feel threatened by it.  No, a survey that asks "do you see innovation as a threat" is not the right way to identify those dragging the company down, either.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 8 years
pros: I came into Cisco through the Scientific Atlanta acquisition in 2006. Cisco has a good work environment. Benefits are good and they encourage working from home for most roles. Cisco encourages moving around within the company and they encourage professional development.
cons: Too many layoffs. Cisco seems to do annual layoffs. If you're working in one of the old SA BUs then you're days are likely numbered. On-call was tremendously stressful and the work life balance left a lot to be desired.
advice_management: Figure out what's going on in the company and stop laying people off. The number and frequency of layoffs within Cisco make it look like Cisco doesn't know what it's doing, and it's a believable perception at this point.

cons: Avoid business units that don't directly make money. Some of the business units that play a supporting role in selling hardware or for making product that are not directly showing revenue tend to have less bonuses and continued layoffs. The low level management in these BUs are out of touch with the market and don't encourage growth in employees.
advice_management: Have a business model that allows credit to be given to software services as part of the revenue. If that's the case already, make it transparent inside the company

summary: "Cisco - your ultra-conservative grandpa that doesn't listen"
main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems
pros:
Cisco is a prestigious company that is recognized globally as a leader in networking technologies - you will very seldom, if ever, have to describe what they do as a company to a stranger.

It's a good stepping stone into the younger, faster-paced tech companies.

Very good place to learn how NOT to interact with others, manage people, and approach problems. Great learning experience.
cons:
Lack of knowledge in the software domain - scrambling to find a way to brand themselves as a software shop while not putting measures in place to motivate the best software engineers to work there.

Very close minded to new ideas from the younger workforce. Probably due in part to the significantly older generation that dominates the workforce currently. I got the impression that older employees that hadn't established themselves at the VP/SVP/C-Suite/Director/Principle level were off put by younger engineers.

Not a hard working workforce as a whole. If you want to put in your 40 hours per week or less and have a life outside of work and not learn a ton of skills - probably a great place to work. If you want to pull 80+ hours per week and learn about cutting edge technologies and "outside of the box" problem solving methods - stay away.

Very much a "think inside of the box" and don't question the process environment. You are there to take orders and not address problems if you see them with the current structure.

The managements philosophy on employees is to hire "specialist" in one particular field, work them to the bone, and then not advocate for them when they want to explore or learn other areas of the business.

No free food - and the food available is horrid. Many interns were off-put by the food that was available, nevertheless that the company did not pay for the meals.

Extremely unorganized! I had a total of 4 projects cancelled due to politics and I was not told they were cancelled until I made the effort to ask managements - not conductive to teaching new talent.
advice_management:
Hire better software engineers. Fire the incompetent people who are not willing to listen to new ideas. Fire the people not willing to work more than 40 hours per week. Hire a consulting firm that will teach you how to pull gen-y and gen-z into the workforce or face the hit to reputation.

Take organization more seriously - fancy video conferencing can't mask a significant lack of communication.

summary: "Best company I have ever worked for."
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for less than a year
pros: You are treated like an adult. No micromanaging but I guess it depends on the manager/supervisor. Great working environment - 40 hours volunteer hours, 20 days paid vacation - first year; company shuts down for a winter break between Xmas and New Years. Work is challenging but very rewarding. Team works seamlessly with no drama or gossiping.  Flexibility to work at home as needed.  Bonuses are written into offer letter.
cons: If you work in a small office, there may not be the advancement opportunities unless you are willing to relocate.  Have heard that raises are hard to come by.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems  for more than 3 years
pros: Great place for career growth and energetic.  work and life balanced is achievable.
cons: nothing major, wish they were smarter on acquasitions
advice_management: keep up the good work

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems
pros: Good company for 50B plus in revenue.
cons: Too many politics.... need to promote based on merit.
advice_management: Turn your sales leadership.....stagnant.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than a year
pros: Good technology and many smart coworkers, I built my career here in the early days
cons: Lots of big company politics made it hard to collaborate well and enjoy coming to work
advice_management: Use industry standard job roles in marketing to help people understand who does what, and decrease infighting.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Challenging, Dynamic work environment.  I was always learning and challenged in every project.  Cisco also provided the flexibility for me to work from home.
cons: Project timelines can sometimes be unrealistic.  Long work hours are expected.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time
pros:
-Still some amazing people to work with and endless learning opportunities
-If you are early in career, this is currently the place to be
-Very flexible work schedule in most positions with a lot of latitude to work remotely
cons:
-If you are middle aged white male demographic, you have a better chance of becoming the morning weather girl than to advance
-Bloated corporate structure -- lot of unwritten rules about moving into new positions (did you do this job and this job first, etc.)
-Lack of excitement and lot of turnover right now...lot of long time pros are leaving the company which could be pro or con depending on your perspective.
advice_management: Don't forget the strength of Cisco has always been the people and hiring for the top 10%.....

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems  for less than a year
pros: Cisco is a great place to work
cons: No Cons at this time

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Telecommuting is available and fully supported. If you like big company culture, there is no shortage of that. The lack of talent makes it easy to stand out. Internal opportunities for movement always seem to be available.
cons: Layoffs are ever looming and a fact of life. no matter how much you contribute to the bottom line. Management is constantly shuffling people to new and/or different groups. It's pretty rare to work with the same group of people for more than a year or so. So many lemmings. And right behind them are the people just waiting to take credit for things they had nothing to do with.
advice_management: Too many chefs in the kitchen. Need more people doing work, and less people trying to monitor what's being done. The management chain is extremely top heavy.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems  for less than a year
pros:

-A great place to develop leadership skills along with technical skills
-Team colleagues as well as managers are extremely friendly
cons: #NAME?

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Solid place to work, very flexible on where you work from (home or office).  Interesting initiatives and lots of mobility within the company
cons: Too big, lots of bureaucracy.  Moving too slowly for the changing tech world.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems  for more than 5 years
pros: Good trainning, Good  own time management, Movility, Good products, Good Pay if you achive quota. A lot of resources.
cons: No profesional growth oportunities, Doble agenda at management level,

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems  for more than a year
pros: the comp plan was great, there are a lot of great and smart folks there, they make and sell some great technologies
cons:
annual re-structures/frequent direction changes/way to much executive politics

as a long time employee I got to watch a lot of the politics, executive squabbles, and regular direction changes. it is a tribute to how much can get ignored if the money is flowing in and you have smart people to make diving catches. they really could have been so much more (any maybe still can but am not holding my breath). despite great efforts it is still an old boy network with some major diversity issues.
advice_management: the world and market is changing, the leadership and their approaches were great when product and supporting services was enough but that is no longer the world we live in. get an executive blood transfusion......the leadership profiles and style that got you here have shown over and over that they can't let real transformation occur.

summary: "Just ugh. Really again with the layoffs???"
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: The people are in general great. It's nice to say you work for Cisco.
cons: Layoffs again and again and again, and they do it so poorly! You'd think after 6 or 7 years straight they'd have the process figured out by now, which is endemic and illustrative of so many failures within the company. Renewed focus on laying off more senior employees to replace them with cheaper less seasoned college hires. No stock. No real growth.
advice_management: Get your stuff together already! I have no idea how such a profitable company treats employees so poorly!

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for less than a year
pros: Flexible work practices, ability to take initiative and move around within company, growing, global networking capabilities
cons: Constant change in key leadership, multiple down-sizing of departments and re-structuring of other departments
advice_management: Strong leadership is key even in the face of uncertainty and inevitable change. One of the strongest factors to success in any organization is driven and highly-qualified employees; Without them success of the overall organization is tilted towards failure.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems
pros: Generous benefits.  Generous benefits.  Yes.
cons: Management (VP and above) only watch out for themselves
advice_management: Recognize who does the work and makes you successful

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems

advice_management: Lack of promotions and too much politics.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems
pros: Smart, hard working, committed people
cons: The constant "limited restructuring" leaves people anxious, ineffective and often politicking to hang on to their jobs instead of actually doing work

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems
pros: Very competent and friendly people.  Everyone very cooperative and willing to help you get acclimated, learn the various tools and systems, etc.  Lot of opportunities to volunteer in company-sponsored community service activities.  Large company, lots of opportunity to move to different jobs and acquire new experience.
cons: For contractors (at least in the department where I worked) not enough formal newcomer training and orientation to help you get up to speed quickly.  Needed a lot of help from co-workers which inconvenienced them (although all were very understanding and helpful.)
advice_management: none

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time
pros: Excellent educational resources, organization and products.
cons: This is a big company that has trouble with EEOC laws.  They don't pay enough attention and don't provide enough sensitivity training.
advice_management: Admit when you've made a mistake. Strong arming employees is thuggish and illegal .

summary: "Stay in the Core Business at Cisco"
main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems  for more than 8 years
pros: Good salary, lots of perks, although many are available in San Jose only.  Depending on your interests, you can work on some new techmology
cons: If you are not in the central core business, you are at risk for a layoff.  If you are not in San Jose, you will find your advancement opportunities limited.  Heavily political with regards to advancement, everywhere.
advice_management: Stop dumping staff when you stop a project - most of them are willing and able to learn the new skills needed in no time.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than a year
pros: Great place to work.  Lots of perks and supper from mgnt. Slower pace than smaller companies but that's expected.  Would definitely work there again.
cons: Slow pace and could use more perks.  Projects takes longer due to involvement of other teams and red takes.  Sharing workspace and desks doesn't work.  Employees end up in other buildings.
advice_management: More assigned desks, cubes, or office.  Could use better food and more locations on campus.  Move at a little faster pace and better documentation.  Plus more information available on intranet for support.

summary: "Fast Paced, Good People, Fair Pay, Positive Experience"
main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems
pros: Cisco hires solid performers. Most employees seem to have type-A personalities and are very results focused. For a big company, this is a fast paced environment. Compensation is good: bonuses historically have been generous and it's the same for restricted stock grants for more senior employees. Cisco is focused on innovating and leading in their respective areas. Cisco is also good about giving employees the opportunity to move around the company, take on different positions and learn new skill sets. The company also has a very forward-thinking mindset when it comes to working remotely.
cons: As with any big company, there can be multiple levels of management. This can be frustrating at times. Politics can be an issue in some organizations. Employees also have to set boundaries when it comes to the work/life balance. If you don't set boundaries, you'll likely get burned out.
advice_management: Stay true to the values that made Cisco great. Continue putting employees first. And, do whatever you can to keep top managers in place. Also, think about offering a sabbaticals to long term employees.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time
pros: Cisco was very accommodating in terms of schedule and flexibility. There are opportunities for training, skill advancement, etc. They were also happy to let employees give back to the community.
cons: Raises and promotions are difficult to come by regardless of performance. In such a big company it is easy to get a little lost unless you are really vocal and find a way to stand out.
advice_management: Keep developing your employees and asking them to stretch to be the best they can be. Pay attention to morale- it suffers in some groups and it doesn't seem to be recognized.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: If you have a good manager, it's a fantastic experience.  Overall the benefits are really good.  You have a lot of leeway to be able to work on various projects or programs.
cons: If you get a bad manager, it can be very challenging.  There have been a lot of re-orgs, some that have made sense and some that have not.  When they prolong the org changes, it really lowers morale as with each of these there are small lay-offs.
advice_management: When you do a re-org, figure it out ahead of time where everyone will go and then do the announcement, don't prolong it for a quarter.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than a year
pros: Excellent company to work for, loved my job and the people I worked with. The salary and benefits are very good and the company has a great industry reputation. I would work there again if given the opportunity.
cons: I was part of the Consumer Division of Cisco selling the Linksys home network products and Flip HD camcorder. Unfortunately, our division was not the focus of Cisco at the time due to low margin and heavy CE/Retail competition.
advice_management: The only advice I would have had for management back in 2012, was to give our division a chance to work through the profitability issues given out 75% market share.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time
pros: good for people looking for easy lifestye
cons: very slow, constant things about layoffs
advice_management: need more benefits like google, facebook

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than a year

cons: Massive company. Makes it hard to see value of work. Company values acquisition over innovations.
advice_management: Invest in your employees

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems  for less than a year

cons: Like any large company, some things do take a long time to happen. It can be hard to get things pushed through to the finalization point.
