summary: "Good in pockets and bad in pockets"
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems
pros: Certain groups and organizations do great work and have a great working culture
cons: Nothing right off the back.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems  for more than 10 years
pros: Large, robust company with a huge information infrastructure. Clean facilities. Great industry to be in in the information age. They've started adding small 'game rooms' to buildings with foosball tables, wall-sized scrabble, xboxes, etc.
cons: You can't get anything done quickly because there is always a process for everything, or because there's an expense associated and everybody's budget is tight. Because of legal issues, contractors aren't eligible to be recommended for awards or to give input on the performance of full-time employees (for or against). Whether you have any fun at work is highly dependent upon the attitude of your management.
advice_management: Sanity check your policy of diversity; if your employees in one organization are 90% from a single country's culture, you're doing it wrong. Restore 360 degree reviews of your lower level managers so employees can provide input.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than a year
pros: Good gig. Flexible. Pay is good. Prestigious, lots to learn. Benefits are pretty awesome. Not overrated. Best company I've worked for. I've been in the industry for over 20 years. I'm so glad to be with CISCO. I've joined two years ago in various roles. Being an SE at CISCO has been nothing short of awesome and I hope to retire here.
cons: Mean customers, so much to learn. Never ending amount of material to learn. Fast paced. Being in a remote office isn't the same as being at rtp or San Jose.
advice_management: Growth is hard to sustain.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems  for more than 3 years
pros: Not many .. just awful place to work as a contractor.   They have good cafe's though. But used to be more subsidized.
cons: They treat their contractors like garbage. People are unfriendly, rude.  mgt does not keep you informed of big picture.
advice_management: stop talking in front of people in a different language in the office

cons: Not a lot of Risk Takers and they wear you down in making presentation after presentation before acting.
advice_management: Numerous and I mean numerous employees are upset and many have not had a raise in years. I would stop the now annual layoffs as you have trimmed the fat.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems  for more than 3 years
pros: Great Tech, Great People, good bonus, good ESPP, and good benefits.
cons: Limited Restructuring regularly not such a good thing seen very good people get let go rather than allowed to move to open slot they would have excelled in.
advice_management: Please Hire technical types as managers.  They understand the business and customer needs while the PMs and Business degree type managers have no clue.  Please restructure if a LR comes the PM staff they never get hit.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years

pros: Great benefits, work/life balance is spoken.

advice_management: Give your talented, hardworking engineers a raise, and promote your best and brightest.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 3 years
pros: The Cisco GVS organization is so far the best, most challenging and pleasant environment I've worked in over my 20 year career. Sharp, accessible leadership. Clear, concise goals and targets. Excellent talent acquisition and retention made for me leading the best sales teams I've had. Compensation and environment are exemplary. I can't recommend Cisco GVS enough.
cons: The main con comes with being a part of such a behemoth of a company. At times, it does seem like all your efforts amount to being a small cog in a very large machine. Par for the course with a company this size.
advice_management: Keep doing what you are doing.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems  for more than a year

cons: Mgmt is a revolving door and no one knows how to manage up! Unrealistic quotas are set which means we make no where near our OTE!
advice_management: Set realistic quotas and goals for the Security Sales organization! 50% increases in yearly quotas is insane!

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 5 years

cons: 30% contract workforce is not saving as much money as management thinks it is.  How does a company retain SME knowledge with that type of structure?  It doesn't.  And it is chaotic and expensive.  HR is the worst I have experienced of any large company I have worked for.  Middle management are largely incompetent, many reaping the benefits of significant hiring 15 years ago and are now operating by the Peter Principle.  Employee morale is not very good amongst those who built this company during it's first 15-20 years.  Many are leaving with their knowledge.

advice_management: Don't list benefits to new employees without being able to execute on them. People managers should go though more rigorous training. Have an even playing field and avoid nepotism (extremely prevalent)

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems  for more than a year
pros: Great people and work-life balance.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems  for more than 10 years
pros: I have worked at Cisco for 16 years. I have been fortunate to have been paired with the best managers, so I write this understanding that I've been blessed with a little pixie dust when it comes to the manager lottery. I get to work with very smart people and the occasional crazy person. I work from home and have tremendous flexibility. Cisco really cares about giving back, which I highly value. I have also been able to develop my career and get the support through training, coaching and mentoring.
cons: Cisco has some work to do on diversity but I am seeing a change through the new People Deal which makes me hopeful. I believe in Chuck and Fran, they have the right plan in place.
advice_management: Focus and execute on the People Deal. It will be the key to improving the culture and company down the road.

summary: "Trying Hard to Get Its Groove Back"
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Great work/life balance, ability to work from home or work a flexible schedule. Great benefits (401K match, decent salary/bonus, ESPP, medical benefits, PTO, etc.). Brand name company with global recognition. If you're under 30, you'll be lavished with attention and promotion.
cons: Lots of instability due to quarterly restructuring. Poor mid-level managers who have been at Cisco for eons and are more concerned with managing up. Very passive aggressive culture. No annual review process -- if you're manager is weak, you will not be recognized for achievements. Layers of VPs who talk a good game but are poor on execution.
advice_management: Focus on customers, invest in modern technologies, and get rid of the middle bloat before eliminating lower level jobs. Stop pandering to those fresh out of college.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros:
* Flexibility to move with-in the company. There are so many business units working on so many products. You get bored on something, can easily hop on to different business unit. 
* Great overall compensation package
cons: Business units that are making lot of money for the company have hands full of work but accordingly gets compensated.
advice_management: # Bring in more efficiency (esp debug tools) in the development process.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Cisco has the money to provide engineers with equipment to do their work. So if you're an engineer and loves to be an engineer and you're lucky to be in the few business units that still value your work, then good for you.
cons:
Too many Cisco Business Units (BU) waste their times in useless talks leading nowhere. My friends at Cisco in other BU report the same thing. Cisco is no longer what it used to be.

These BUs are simply rotten with politics. Managers and directors falsify their work results to please their VPs. All they care for is to be "visible" to VPs and upper-management. Care for great product quality is the least of their priority. Of course customers are not happy. Product quality has degraded a lot.
advice_management: Silos and potilics have been accumulated for way too long. Chambers allowed that to happen. I have no idea how you would fix this. Hope new management can return Cisco to what it used to be. There are still a lot of potential. Still many good people around. Don't lose them.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Cisco has the money to provide engineers with equipment to do their work. So if you're an engineer and loves to be an engineer and you're lucky to be in the few business units that still value your work, then good for you.
cons:
Too many Cisco Business Units (BU) waste their times in useless talks leading nowhere. My friends at Cisco in other BU report the same thing. Cisco is no longer what it used to be.

These BUs are simply rotten with politics. Managers and directors falsify their work results to please their VPs. All they care for is to be "visible" to VPs and upper-management. Care for great product quality is the least of their priority. Of course customers are not happy. Product quality has degraded a lot.
advice_management: Silos and potilics have been accumulated for way too long. Chambers allowed that to happen. I have no idea how you would fix this. Hope new management can return Cisco to what it used to be. There are still a lot of potential. Still many good people around. Don't lose them.

summary: "Low salaries, long working hours, rough culture"
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time
pros: Big company and the industry leader. Overall pretty stable, though there have been annual 5-10% layoffs in the summer for the last few years.
cons: Pay is low for the effort, raises are meager. Employees are asked to meet ridiculously tight deadlines even if it means working 50-60 hours a week for multiple weeks. Work life balance is absent - employees are expected/required to be available in the weekday nights and weekends. Management comes across as self-centered and high handed. Growth/career advancement opportunities are minimal - those who are good at office politics get promoted, hard work isn't recognized as it should be. The culture leaves a lot to be desired - in my years here, I have come across a lot of rude and curt colleagues at the company. There should be more open dialogue/transfer of information between the management and the team.
advice_management: Salaries need to be competitive, employees deserve to be compensated better. Career growth should be encouraged. The culture should be made supportive and welcoming.

summary: "Good place to work, but lots of politics"
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Overall, good opportunities (if you know where to look), ability to impact the industry, solid benefits, great life/work balance and reasonable salaries.  There is a reason Cisco consistently makes "best place to work" lists.  The leadership change has been a huge positive.
cons: The closer you are to the core businesses, the more politics you end up having to deal with--it can be a huge productivity tax. The market is evolving and some leaders are in denial about this, which can be equal parts frustrating and entertaining.  The thing is, Cisco is so big, you cannot make a blanket statement, it really ends up depending on your manager and management chain.
advice_management: Middle management are the weak link when trying to institute change.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems

advice_management: At the time I left in 2012, Cisco was deep into outsourcing and offshoring mature software products.  The reasoning was sound but in some cases rushed.

summary: "Great benefits, good salary, uninspiring work, mediocre management"
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than a year
pros: The compensation package and work style is the best part of the job. About 3 weeks off per year and the ability to work from home is great. Seemingly stable job with good benefits  and relaxed work environment
cons: Depending where you get placed, the work may or may not match with your skill set or be of the most interest to you. Changing this can be difficult and must be fought for. Management changes can be frequent (3 in about 16 months) and political which can lead to a feeling of misdirection. Hard work can go unnoticed and so can slacking off
advice_management: Give clearer direction, lead the team instead of manage, leave politics at home

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Excellent executive leadership.  You will learn and grow a great deal if you are in your 20's or 30's.
cons: The environment can be challenging for those who are not able to move with change, create relationships across teams and look for opportunities to add value.
advice_management: Find a way to reward the producers in the organization and manage out the non-performers.  Too many good people are being laid off, causing the culture to lose faith.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems  for more than 3 years
pros: Great colleagues and many people who are collaborative and willing to work with you. The remote work policy is great with some flexibility. Used to be a great place to work for many years.  Company as a whole is actually pretty pleasant, certain organizations are not.
cons:
Most unprofessional managers in the last 6-12 mos who feel entitled to threaten and bully employees. Managers asks employees to do work even after having approved PTO days.  

Open space feels like a fish bowl.
advice_management: Prune your management teams that do not add value or deliver.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems  for more than 10 years
pros: Flex Time(but will work over 10 hour day minimum)
cons: Unreliable - Can lose your job anytime in a instance. Company has no allegiance to Employees or their tenure/hardwork and dedication. A lot of employees have been there since year 2000. They stuck through with the company hoping that it would turn around. They weren't re-issued any of the Stocks they lost due to being "under-water" and also stopped any new issues. When the company started to turn around, the first people they got rid of are the long tenured people. Furthermore, you will probably come into Cisco, smart and cream of the crop, however, please beware that you will have zero career enhancement. Their constant budget cutbacks take away the key elements that keep your job skills intact.
advice_management: Have a heart. Understand your employees on a personal level so that you are aware when you Layoff people. To you its all about numbers. You definitely have the insight on when things will shake up, at least start a plan to ensure the employees you let go, go away with some new skills. Dont just use words like "support", actually apply "support" when you let go of the employees. While there are a very few that have no choice in the matter, there are a number that do. For those that do. Just remember, it will happen to you. Think of how prepared you will be. So my advice is to ensure that all of your employees be sharp in their respective skills all the time. Help them, listen to them, let them take classes/courses. Let them take hands on training, etc etc.

cons:
High turnover. 
Leadership positions remain vacant for long periods of time leaving huge gaps and teams without proper focus and structure. 
No career growth. I have had 4 managers in 3 years time. 
No one is working as one unified team.
People who come in from acquisitions take leadership positions, create toxic environments, criticize existing efforts, make messes because they don't take the time to learn the history of things and demotivate teams. 
Politics, gossip and corruptness is permitted.
advice_management: Fix the toxic political cesspool. Hold people accountable for operating with our values.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years

cons: low pay raises or none at all even when company performs well, lots of bad managers, discriminatory work environment tolerated and managers who are leading such groups and who are also practicing such type of behavior continue to have senior leadership roles even when complaints come and people leave.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems  for more than 3 years
pros: Opportunity to work and contribute directly with industry idea / product leaders. Strong in place processes and methods for product management. Opportunity to affect very large scale sales base with exceptionally talented field sales/support teammates. A wide variety of offerings may provide some lateral opportunities.  Decent to better total compensation.  Executive management espouses and somewhat really means the high culture and values.
cons: Many visions and agendas that can openly conflict are not only tolerated but appear to be accepted by management. While in the past this could lead to good idea competition that could result in multiple winners, it's now become much more one side "We are the only smart, capable team, you are not us, so don't ever think you can" and other side "We must keep going and understand that other investments must be made...oh and ignore that you are often reminded that you are less-thans and treated that way".   Unfortunately this has significantly dropped the professionalism of the organization.  Last, the culture has also shifted strongly to a  high reward for the top few, low reward for the remainder, and removal of any who are not in synch at that time.  This is at odds with the culture and values espoused. The result has been a significant tide of mid-to-high experience staff turn over (8-15+ year staff) for which so many reasons management stated, but first hand knowledge from those staff says they just didn't want to deal with this any longer.
advice_management:
Don't allow organizational bullying.  
If there are certain agreed overall must win targets, allow all teams to support that target set instead of forcing (large) teams to be excluded under the statement of "some have to just keep the existing and old going".  Yes, they can keep the existing and old going without condescension and exclusion.

summary: "Great place to work, strong future outlook"
main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Strong work/life balance, Opportunity to work remotely, Improved market position in collaboration, Large organization but trying to bring in agile/startup culture and renovating a lot of the HQ offices with open floor spaces, etc. Would recommend working here to others.
cons:
Large organization still in the process of becoming more agile, so the bureaucracy and slow pace can be a hinderance at times. 
Many Cisco lifers are passionate about what they're working on, but some seem to be along for the ride, only to do the minimal amount of work necessary (I'm sure most large companies experience this). 
Lots of senior leadership changes in recent years leads to frequent strategic changes and internal bickering at times.
advice_management: I'd suggest focusing on promoting the strong performers and removing the less productive team members. It sounds obvious but doesn't seem to be the case.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Great caliber of people to work with.  The best and brightest in all areas.  Fast paced, great comp and benefits
cons: Recent years have seen a shift in corporate culture.  Thought Cisco has always been focused on profit and growth it was always done with the employees in mind.  Recent pressures of the stock holders and the IT market have seen a shift to more main stream corporate operating cultures.  Lay-offs are more common in Cisco now and there is less alignment between what the CEO "says" is the focus and what is actually executed.  The word "family" has a diminished meaning in the Cisco culture.  Less reward for performance at the discretion of line managers.
advice_management: Don't loose site of what made Cisco great and able to grow to be the giant that it is.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Fast paced environment (for a big company); Smart people that work hard and play hard.  Genuinely committed to our customers success
cons: Has become too bureaucratic; internal systems not built for shift to cloud/SaaS models, yearly layoffs hurt morale (we'll see if Chuck changes this); too many layers of management
advice_management: Chuck Robbins has breathed new life into Cisco, with more direct communications and monthly roundtables where all questions are fair game.  Continue to engage and communicate with employees and the Cisco culture will flourish.  Also, be mindful of hiring practices so we don't become like every other large tech company that has annual layoffs.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than a year
pros:
Overall, colleagues were simply awesome. Everyone is super friendly but your experience completely depends on the people you work with and the vertical you are in.
If your vertical isn't a focus area, you'll probably be bored. 
If your vertical is a focus area, you will get absolutely smoked but learn a ton.
Fridays are pretty laid back. If you aren't on a deal, you should be able to work from home or SF if interested.
Relocation assistance is probably best-in-class....make sure to ask for it $10-20K. It's baked into your fully burned opex cost, so theoretically the org has planned for it. Don't be afraid to ask: get the offer and then ask HR.
Bus Shuttle from SF->SJC
Yearly off-site
Executive exposure - you sit on the same floor as C-suite and work with SVPs often.
The engineers are super nice and approachable.
cons:
Wages stay flat YoY. No inflation adjustment for junior deal team members.
Working remotely isn't really an option outside of Friday
Unreal revolving door environment
Work/life balance can be non-existent
OG environment
advice_management:
Allow applicants to meet their potential team in person before joining even if it's a junior role. Small teams are a marriage. TelePresence isn't the same thing as meeting someone in person.

It's not aggressive to expect an inflation adjustment. The bay area is kind of expensive and younger employees rarely own property.

If you get called back while on PTO, you shouldn't have to cover the cost of the ticket and other miscellaneous expenses...that's just mean.

-all that work from home makes you feel like a shut in

advice_management: look for ways and workers who improve efficiency and let them lead. stop employing wasteful people.  Stop the managing up cycle and do some of your job as actual managers.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than a year
pros: Compensation, flexible work schedule, and travel.
cons: Aspiring marketing professionals in college, do NOT make the mistake of starting off your career in Cisco. I was lured by the great salary, tales of a terrific culture, and the promise that Cisco would help me continue learning and growing as a marketer. The salary was great, but everything else was a lie. It is important to remember that Cisco, especially the marketing department, largely consists of middle-aged to older people who are already settled in their lives (kids, marriage, finances, etc). As a young, unattached professional, you are at a career advantage where you have the time to 1)Go physically into work and develop real one-on-one relationships with colleagues. 2)Devote time after work to networking with other tech marketing individuals. 3) Work with other young people who are more willing to take the financial risk and devote time to develop a start up. Cisco culture assists those who want a "work-life" balance which is great for those who are more settled in life. For those who still want to do something crazy and change the paradigm, Cisco is not the place to do it.
advice_management: Be open about the downsides of working for Cisco.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 8 years
pros:

cons:
Many managers lack the management skills to truly develop their teams. Company has the people process but not a culture that promotes excellence in management of people.
Too much of the innovation investment and energy is wasted. Don't always see the tangible results delivered.
advice_management: Strengthen the link between excellence in management, measurement of results and the innovation investment.

There are too many managers with an inconsistent message.  Half of the managers appreciate their employees and work with them to help them advance in their careers.  Others want people that are going to stay in the same job forever.
advice_management: Start showing your employees they matter instead of just disposing of them.

cons:
Very big - tiny cog in big machine - hard to make a difference
Constant focus on you adjusting to change - just not changing any of the pre-year 2000 systems.
Lots of talk about digitization, but operationally really falling behind - unable to support new business models
Promotions are very hard. Raises and high bonuses are only really given to top performers
advice_management: Focus on making Cisco easy to do business with.  You make partners work too hard.  If it were easier, you'd make a lot more money off of the partners. Also stop doing share buy-backs and invest in the company. Rebecca is clearly not the one to revamp the antiquated operational infrastructure - bit the bullet and modernize.

job_title: Current Employee - Senior User Experience Designer
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Great work life balance. Work from home is a major plus (they own WebEx). Smart capable people. Amazing benefits including a full week of paid leave for charity volunteering. Love how much the company gives back to society.
cons: Very rare to get a salary increase, so be sure you're OK with the salary you accept. Lots of churn in mid-management, I've had 13 managers in seven years. Tough to get your ideas heard, unless you're politically minded. Since the company is so large, there are a lot of slackers who coast along just under the radar, which can be de-motivating. Very engineering driven with design, and user experience, as an afterthought. There is also no clear career path for designers. Design is not handled in a traditional manner, so collaborating with fellow designers is rare- instead you're assigned a product and become silo'ed in it.
advice_management: Implement a more detailed review of managers, and management, by their staff- in an anonymous method so that real feedback can be delivered and received. Current "Pulse" surveys are lame in that they are so high-level they fail to be actionable. Also, if you intend on continuing to talk about how important user experience design is to the company, you should update your human resources systems to include the job title "user experience designer" and "designer". Instead, we are all labeled engineers, which is not accurate and is somewhat insulting.

cons:
Big company - takes a while for anyone to connect all the dots.  You will likely find people in different organizations trying to achieve the same goal not knowing about each other
Work hours - global company means working across time zones, partly compensated by flexible working, but if you need a 9-5 job this may not be for you.
advice_management: Keep doing what you are doing - but need to emphasize e2e vision more, and put more investment into the future of the company, even if it means diverting investment from the "good enough" legacy business

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Friendly environment. Good culture.
cons: Prone to frequent lay-offs. Management needs to think things through before acting.

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems  for more than 10 years
pros: Flexible hours and schedules, open work space, helpful friendly people. The work has been interesting and fun.
cons: Contractors rarely get converted to full-time employees. Layoffs are so ongoing that people talk about them very regularly and when they expect them to happen.
advice_management: Think seriously about the effect that the frequent layoffs have one the employees who are left. These are very demoralizing and effects productivity.

summary: "Wish this was still working for me"
main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Flexible work from home, excellent benefits and employee services, access to key company services via mobile device, excellent reputation
cons: Too many people doing overlapping work, marketing resources very restricted since 2013, VERY slow to make changes they announce, no room for advancement
advice_management: Reduce marketing headcount to clarify roles and increase marketing budgets

main_text: I have been working at Cisco Systems  for less than a year
pros: Flexibility to work remote and constant learning experience.
cons: A big portion of the company is made up of contractors. Will continue to lose potentially great employees because hiring is so rare.
advice_management: Make it easier on the Engineering Leads that have to put up with training contractors on a constant basis because retention rates are low. Hire those who will fit in to the team and you will have better results.

cons:
Very Poor  Managers and senior managers
Managers are there to collect a paychek and power point pushers
Promotion and Job placements based on whom you know not merit
A good NCE does not mean he would be a good manager.
Displacing folks over a certain age is very common practice.
advice_management: Understand the issues inside the company. One is not in the Military.  Culture at Cisco is Grade levels cannot talk to 2 Grades up. Just like in the services. This is the downfall of Cisco

summary: "Got Cisco on the Resume for Internship Experience But Was Expecting a Little More"
main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems
pros: Lots of networking opportunities as an intern to learn about various departments and functions at Cisco.
cons: Did a lot of paper pushing as an MBA intern. Not much growth or knowledge gained from projects that may help within product management or marketing. Bit disappointment. Perhaps it may have just been bad luck on my part getting an internship on a team that did not value giving projects to MBA interns that would be challenging.
advice_management: Just make sure when you go for the internship interview, you make sure you understand what kinds of projects you will be working on and whether you will be challenged and utilize what you are learning in school.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems  for more than 10 years
pros: I joined Cisco in 1995 and left in 2014.  The company I joined was not the company I left.  The culture of family existed in the 1990's and early 2000's.  The products, technologies, and people were fantastic and still are very good.
cons: Cisco now does what large companies do, which is annual layoffs.  Sometimes these layoffs are actually ongoing just aren't reported as they are below 3% of the total employee population.  This systemic issue leads to a culture of CYA and backstabbing, especially at executive levels.
advice_management: Bring the original values back to life.  Treat all employees as family and focus on performance vs style...aka managing up rather than leading the team and business.

main_text: I worked at Cisco Systems  for more than a year
pros: Excellent opportunities to improve skill set, and flat management structure. You have access to speak to practically anyone in the company.
